vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.title: Managing Blueprints in VCF Automation
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.description: A blueprint is a declarative template used to define and automate the deployment of infrastructure, applications, and services. It allows users to model complex cloud resources, such as VMs, networks, storage, and software components. Blueprints orchestrate the deployment of multiple resource in the VCF platform. It acts as a reusable design for deploying resources and services consistently. A design canvas is used to create a blueprint. YAML code is automatically generated. It describes infrastructure as code. The code editor also allows to type code directly or enter values.Blueprint Features Blueprint designer.  The Blueprint Designer offers a single interface to create blueprints for various resource types, including single machines, multi-machi deployments, and multi-tiered applications. Declarative Infrastructure-as-Code.  Blueprints define the desired state of the infrastructure using YAML or a visual designer, rather than specifying step-by-step instructions. Reusability and versioning.  Blueprints can be versioned, imported, exported (YAML format), and shared across projects or even tenants, promoting reusability and collaboration. Self-Service provisioning.   VCF Automation  provides self-service portals where users can deploy and manage resources based on pre-defined blueprints. Inputs and Customization.  Blueprint inputs enable customization during deployment, allowing users to select options like machine size or image. Governance.  To ensure consistency, reusability, and governance across environments. Day 2 operations.  Blueprints support day 2 operations, allowing for updates, modifications, and management of existing deployments. Blueprint Concepts Versioning.  Blueprints can be versioned. At deployment time, you can select any of your versions to deploy. Resource objects.  Resource objects represent the infrastructure components and services that are provisioned and managed in a blueprint. Dependencies between resources in blueprints.  When you deploy a  VCF Automation  blueprint, one resource might need another resource to be available first. Instances.  Instances are created when blueprints are deployed from the catalog. Day 2 actions.  Actions that can be performed on the provisioned resource objects. Property groups.  Instead of defining the same properties repeatedly across multiple blueprints, property groups enable you to define them once and then link them to various resources. This promotes consistency and simplifies management, as updates to a property group are automatically reflected in all linked templates. Property bindings.  Sometimes, a resource property needs a value found in a property of another resource. For example, a backup server might need the operating system image of the database server that is being backed up, so the database server must exist first. Custom forms.  Allows users to design and customize request forms for catalog items, providing a tailored user experience for submitting requests. They can be designed with a drag-and-drop interface and configured with various properties, including conditional logic and external data sources. Custom resources.   VCF Automation  supports the use of custom resources within blueprints to extend automation capabilities beyond native resource types. These custom resources are built upon  VCF Operations orchestrator  workflows and can represent a resource. When to Use BlueprintsBlueprints allow you to streamline and automate the deployment process, ensuring consistency and reducing manual effort.With blueprints, you can model complex IT services by visually designing infrastructure components like VMs, networks, and storage. You can use blueprints when you want to hide the complexities of the infrastructure provisioning from the end user.You can publish blueprints to the self-service VCF Automation catalog which allows users to request and deploy services based on predefined templates.Best Practices for Designing Blueprints Leverage input properties in blueprints to allow users to customize deployments while maintaining a degree of control. Consider providing default values for required fields to improve user experience and prevent errors. Establish clear and consistent naming conventions for blueprints, catalog items, and other resources to improve manageability and organization. Using an iterative method to build and version blueprints helps teams adopt Infrastructure-as-Code (IaC) practices. Start with a minimum viable blueprint (MVB) and add features iteratively. Additionally, use tools like Git for version vontrol. Sharing Blueprints with Projects and OrganizationsWhen you first create a blueprint, you associate it with a project so that when you publish the blueprint to the catalog, users in the selected project can see request and deploy the blueprint. You have the option of making the published blueprint available to other projects in the organization either when you create the blueprint or at a later time.If you are managing a Provider Consumption organization, you can share blueprints with all other organizations under the same provider administrator or you can select specific organizations. After the blueprint is shared, whenever PCO administrator publishes a blueprint to the catalog, the catalog item is shared with the selected organizations. That means one blueprint backs multiple catalog items, one in each organization.When sharing blueprints with other organizations, consider the following limitations. Blueprints that contain any of the following resource types cannot be shared: property groups; custom resources; secrets; namespaces; VM images from provider tenant content libraries. If a blueprint is shared with an organization, a blueprint version with restrictions cannot be published to the catalog. If a blueprint is not shared with any organizations yet, and it has versions that have restrictions and have been published to the catalog, the blueprint cannot be updated and shared with any organization.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Automation/Cloud Services/App Authoring/Managing Blueprints in VCF Automation.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.title: Managing Content Libraries in VCF Automation
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.description: Content libraries are centralized collections of VM images that are used to deploy workloads. VCF Automation supports two types of content libraries - provider content libraries and organization content libraries.Provider Content LibrariesProvider content libraries are configured by the provider administrator in the VCF Automation Provider Management Portal. Provider content libraries are available to all organizations on a read-only basis. Providers can create one or more content libraries, each serving a specific need.Organization Content LibrariesOrganization administrators can create and manage their own organization-specific content libraries. Organization content libraries are not accessible to other organizations managed by your provider administrators. Organization content libraries can also subscribe to external content libraries if that option is enabled by the provider administrator.Content Library ConceptsRegions Provider and organization content libraries can be made available to one or more regions in  VCF Automation . Provider content libraries are automatically available to all organizations that have quota in given region. Organization-specific content libraries must be explicitly made available to every region where the organization has quota in. Storage Storage consumed by organization content libraries count towards the organization storage quota. Organization content libraries subscribed to external sources use storage allocated to the organizational quota as the remote images are downloaded and stored locally in  VCF . This could also lead to increased storage utilization than expected. Sometimes a region may be backed by more than a single vCenter. In such cases, organization content libraries created in such regions may be replicated in each vCenter, leading to higher than expected storage utilization. Check with your provider administrator to understand how this might affect your storage utilization. Namespaces Organization content libraries are generally available to all namespaces created by all projects by default. In some cases, organization administrators might want to create content libraries specific only to a namespace. This is achieved by first turning the toggle  Assign to all current and future namespaces  to off during the creation of content library. When a new namespace class is created, the organization administrator can add the special content library which makes it available only to namespaces created from this namespace class.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Automation/Cloud Services/App Authoring/Managing Content Libraries in VCF Automation.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.title: Tools for Building Apps
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.description:
Use VCF Automation to provision VMs, Kubernetes workloads and other cloud services by using self-service UI, API, and CLI. The Local Consumption Interface provides an alternative for access to vSphere Supervisor services for users who do not have access to VCF Automation.Building Applications with VCF AutomationVCF Automation supports two distinct organization types, All Apps organizations and VM Apps organizations, which have different consumption mechanisms. What you can do in VCF Automation depends on your organization membership.VCF Automation for All Apps provides a user-friendly interface for consuming infrastructure resources as a service, including Kubernetes and other infrastructure components. If you are a member of an All Apps organization in VCF Automation, you have two ways to provision infrastructure: Self-service catalog . The catalog in  VCF Automation  for All Apps is the self-service interface where you can provision workloads from blueprints and other objects that the organization administrator curated and published for you. Blueprints contain resources that can be nested, for example, a blueprint can contain a VM inside a vSphere namespace. See Request an Item from the Catalog in for All Apps.
IaaS Services .  VCF Automation  gives you access to modern services enabled by  vSphere Supervisor  and cloud native applications. You can provision resources including VMs, Kubernetes, volumes, storage, load balancers and networking objects, without involvement from your administrator. See Access the IaaS Services Console or Local Consumption Interface. Both catalog and services deployments support day 2 operations on workloads and services.In VCF Automation for VM Apps organizations you deploy catalog items from the VCF Automation for VM Apps self-service catalog. The catalog in VCF Automation
 for VM Apps is a self-service portal for users to request and manage IT resources from various cloud providers, both private clouds (VMware vSphere) and public clouds (GCP, AWS, Azure), independently through the catalog interface. See Request an Item from the Catalog in for VM Apps.Catalog items in VCF Automation for VM Apps are pre-configured templates that users can deploy, such as virtual machines, cloud templates, and other infrastructure components. The catalog items are provided to you by your administrator. The items that are available to you and your options at deployment time depend on your project membership.VCF Automation for VM Apps does not support IaaS services.Building Applications with the Local Consumption InterfaceThe Local Consumption Interface provides an alternative interface to allow access to modern services enabled by enabled by vSphere Supervisor and cloud native applications. Users can provision resources including VMs, Kubernetes, volumes, storage, load balancers and networking objects, without administrator involvement.The Local Consumption Interface is a vSphere Supervisor service. It can be made available in environments without access to VCF Automation, such as vSphere Foundation
. For more information on installing and configuring the Local Consumption Interface, see Using the Local Consumption Interface.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Automation/Cloud Services/App Authoring/Tools for Building Apps.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.title: Working with the Catalog in VCF Automation for VM Apps
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.description: As an organization administrator, after you configure your cloud infrastructure, you can continue to develop templates, or you can turn over development to the project administrators and members.Project members use VCF Automation to iteratively develop and deploy templates. The deployment locations are configured by the cloud administrator as part of the infrastructure. The administrator has the best understanding of your organizations resources and budget.The VCF Automation catalog is the streamlined user interface that you provide to your development operations and other teams. You import the machine and application templates that you need, and add governance in the form of projects to control who can deploy what resources, and to control where the resources are deployed. You can also apply policies and customize the catalog request form.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Automation/Cloud Services/Catalog and Consumption/Working with the Catalog in VCF Automation for VM Apps.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.title: Provision and Manage Kubernetes Clusters
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.description: You can use a variety of methods to provision Kubernetes clusters in VCF Automation and vSphere Supervisor.If you have access to VCF Automation for All Apps, the Iaas Services Console provides a graphical user interface for provisioning Kubernetes clusters.If the Supervisor Admin has deployed the Local Consumption Interface, the Local Consumption Interface also provides a graphical user interface for provisioning Kubernetes clusters.In addition, the VCF CLI and kubectl provide command-line interfaces for provisioning Kubernetes clusters. If you have the access to VCF Automation for All Apps, use VCF CLI and kubectl in the namespace of your organization, provided by your organization administrator.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Automation/Cloud Services/Provisioning and Lifecycle/Provision and Manage Kubernetes Clusters.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.title: Provision and Manage VMs
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.description: You can use a variety of methods to provision VMs with the VM Service in vSphere Supervisor.If you have access to VCF Automation for All Apps, the Iaas Services Console provides a graphical user interface for provisioning VMs using the VM Service.If the Supervisor Admin has deployed the Local Consumption Interface, the Local Consumption Interface also provides a graphical user interface for provisioning VMs.In addition, the VCF CLI and kubectl provide command-line interfaces for provisioning VMs. If you have the access to VCF Automation for All Apps, use VCF CLI and kubectl in the namespace of your organization, provided to by your organization administrator.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Automation/Cloud Services/Provisioning and Lifecycle/Provision and Manage VMs.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.title: Provisioning Resources in VCF Automation
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.description: VCF Automation, resources like VMs and VKS clusters are provisioned in namespaces either through blueprints or through the IaaS Services console.Provisioning Resources Using BlueprintsWhen using blueprints, namespaces and the desired resources are dragged and dropped on to the blueprint canvas. The resulting blueprint is then published to the catalog where end users can request it for deployment.Blueprints are recommended when the organization administrator needs better control over the exact resource that are provisioned by end-users. Blueprints are also used when the process of provisioning resources needs to be repeatable.Provisioning Resources Using the IaaS Services ConsoleWhen using the IaaS Services console, the desired namespace is selected from the Build & Deploy page. End users can create the desired resources directly on the selected namespace.The self-service IaaS Services console enables end users to provision resources without depending on blueprints. The IaaS Services console is suitable for development needs when agility and flexibility of provisioning resources are more important than repeatability.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Automation/Cloud Services/Provisioning and Lifecycle/Provisioning Resources in VCF Automation.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.title: Cloud Services
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.description:
VCF Automation provides a set of cloud services which are accessible on a self-service basis using multiple interfaces, including UI, CLI, and API.
With this interface, users can provision the following types of workloads: VMs Kubernetes workloads Networking Volumes Secret stores Databases Harbor container registries External DNS Certificates AI workloads
Additionally, application teams can also provision resources on a self-service basis from Catalogs which are backed by pre-configured workload templates.These self-service options help developers focus on application development instead of managing the underlying infrastructure.

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/policy.description:
You can import, download, edit, and delete certificates from VCF Automation.Trusted CertificatesYou can import certificates of servers that VCF Automation communicates with, such as vCenter, NSX Manager, and so on.For more information, see Import Trusted Certificates Using Your VCF Automation Provider Management Portal.Certificate libraryIn the VCF Automation certificates library, you can import certificates used when creating entities that you must secure, such as servers, Edge gateways, and so on.
For more information, see Import Certificates to the Certificates Library Using Your VCF Automation Provider Management Portal.

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/policy.title: Managing Policies in VCF Automation
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/policy.description:
Governance is one of the key aspects of building a cloud-like experience for an organization. In the VCF Automation organization portal, application teams can use the self-service catalog and the services console to provision resources depending on their project needs and permissions. As an organization administrator, you can impose guardrails around those provisioning requests. You use VCF Automation policies to enforce the governance through approval workflows and policy templates. Each VCF Automation policy is a set of rules or parameters that are applied to VCF Automation projects to govern deployment requests from application teams, freeing the organization administrator for other tasks.Policy TypesThere are two general categories of policies you can create in VCF Automation: Policies that can be applied to catalog requests. Approval Policy. Approval Policy adds a layer of governance before the requested resources can be deployed, approvers need to provide their acceptance Approval policies control who must approve resource deployment before the request is provisioned. If an approval policy is configured, approvers can view the list under the  Inbox  section for pending requests for their approval. See Configure Approval Policies in VCF Automation.
Day 2 Action Policy. Day 2 Action policies control what group of users can run the selected actions on deployed resources. See Configure Day 2 Action Policies in VCF Automation.
Lease Policy. Lease policies define the maximum amount of time a deployment can exist. When a deployment expires, it is destroyed and its resources are reclaimed. Lease Policy reduces the need for the organization administrator to intervene manually to reclaim resources, allowing administrators to specify when they want deployed resources to expire. See Configure Lease Policies in VCF Automation. Policies can be applied to IaaS Services requests.
IaaS Resource Policy. To govern application teams' requests to provision IaaS services, like Virtual Machine, Kubernetes Cluster, organization administrators can configure IaaS Resource policies to have granular control on the type of provisioned resources and their configurations. IaaS Resource policies offer policy- as-code capability to enforce custom constraints on IaaS resources, beyond the built-in policy templates. Modifying the policy template would need knowledge Common Expression Language (CEL) is used in the Kubernetes API. See Configure IaaS Resource Policies in VCF Automation. Policy Scope and CriteriaVCF Automation policies can be scoped to the entire organization or a selection of projects in the organization. Organization administrators can further refine the policy scope by defining policy criteria. For example, to apply a policy to all the deployments except the deployments named pipeline test, add criteria and construct an expression similar to name not equal to pipeline test
. Policy criteria can be based on project name, namespace name, namespace class, and so on. For details on constructing policy criteria, see Configure Deployment Criteria in Policies in VCF Automation.Organization administrators can configure multiple policies for resources, projects, or namespaces. First, policies are evaluated, ranked, and, where applicable, merged to produce an effective policy.On the Policies page, organization administrators can create new policies, delete any policy which is no longer required, view a list of policies defined in the organization, view policy assignments and an enforcement list. ** Policy Definition. ** A list of all the policies defined for your organization. You can view policy details or delete a policy which is no longer required. To create a new policy, click  New Policy  and select one of the policy types. ** Policy Assignments. ** On the Policy Assignment tab, you can view policies that are effectively applied to resources, namespaces, and projects, based on the defined policy criteria. ** Policy Enforcement **. Use the Policy Enforcement tab to audit when policies are applied. It lists enforcement date, policy name, and policy status. Any policy that you add is applied to current deployments and any new deployments.To get you started, use the full use cases that are provided for each policy type. The use cases guide you through the process of creating more than one policy. The use case provides contextual explanations of the choices and the desired behavior.The use cases are followed by more in-depth information about how multiple policies are processed.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/policy.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/policy.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Automation/Policy and Extensibility/Managing Policies in VCF Automation.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/policy.title: Managing Secrets in VCF Automation
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/policy.description: A VCF Automation secret is a reusable, encrypted value that project users may add to their blueprint designs.Secure access keys and credentials are typical examples of secret properties. Once created and saved, a secret's value can never be unencrypted or read.Create a secret Log in to  VCF Automation  as a project administrator. Go to  Administer Certificates Secrets  and click  New . Enter a unique property name for the secret, without spaces or special characters. The name is the visible identifier for the secret. Scope the secret to the entire organization or to specific projects. To assign the secret to one or more projects, click  Assign Projects , select your projects, and click  Add . You can't associate a secret with the same project twice. You also can't associate two secrets with the same name with the entire organization. Enter the secret value. When typing, the value is obscured by default, which protects it if the screen is shared. If needed, you can click the eye symbol to reveal and verify a value. After it is saved, a secret value becomes encrypted in the database and can never be re-exposed. Optionally, enter a longer description of the secret property. Click  Create . Adding a secret to a blueprintYou can add a secret property as a binding in blueprint code.Note that starting to type '${secret.characters reveals a selection list of secrets that have been created for the project.If two secrets with the same name but different values exist at the project level and at the organization level, the project secret takes precedence. The organization secret is not available for selection in the blueprint.properties: name: ourvm image: mint20 flavor: small remoteAccess: authentication: publicPrivateKey sshKey: '${secret.ourPublicKey}' username: root
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/policy.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/policy.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Automation/Policy and Extensibility/Managing Secrets in VCF Automation.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/provid.title: Managing Networking in VCF Automation
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/provid.description:
As an organization administrator, you can view what networking infrastructure is assigned to your organization by the provider administrator and you can manage networking infrastructure within the organization.Virtual Private Clouds (VPCs)A VPC provides an isolated domain of networking resources that can be associated with one or more namespaces. You can create VPCs for your organization and associate each VPC to one or more namespaces.Each VPC can leverage 3 different types of IP blocks that each have different levels of reachability: Private CIDRs are local to the VPC and require NAT to connect to any resources outside of the VPC. These CIDRs are managed by the VPC administrator and do not need to be unique across multiple VPCs. Transit Gateway (TGW) Private IP blocks are only advertised within the  VCF Automation  organization and its TGW. The available IP blocks are defined by the organization administrator. Project administrators can allocate subnets from within the defined IP Blocks for use in their VPCs. These IPs have direct reachability to other VPCs within the organization using the TGW Private IP space. External IP Blocks are managed by the provider administrator. IPs in this space are used for outbound Source NAT to enable external reachability for workloads using Private IPs. Organization administrators can assign subnets within the external IP blocks by the allocations defined by the Provider. You can create a new VPC for each namespace for workloads that require some degree of network separation. If no network separation is required, you can use the same VPC for multiple namespaces.The Network Service can be used to create, update, manage, and delete resources within the VPC by organization administrators and advanced project users.VCF Automation is compatible only with supervisors with NSX VPCs. For more information about networking, see the Virtual Private Cloud in NSX documentation.Connectivity profilesA connectivity profile is a template that allows simplified configuration of new VPCs. A default connectivity profile is configured by the provider administrator to simplify the initial organization configuration. You can provide one or more external and private transit gateway IP address blocks that are used by VPCs configured with a specific connectivity profile.Transit gatewaysDepending on the regional quota, each organization has a transit gateway which provides connectivity to the provider gateway within the organization. One or more VPCs are connected to the transit gateway, and that connection is defined by a VPC connectivity profile. Each VPC has connected workloads and a private subnet. SNAT rules translate addresses from this private subnet to a public address in the IP spaces block. This infrastructure enables the organization and its workloads to connect to external networks.You can view what transit gateways are available to your organization on the Manage & GovernNetworkingTransit Gateways page.You can also manage IP addresses that the provider administrator made available to you and create IP addresses that are specific to your organization.Best Practices for Organization Networking Effectively using VPCs. VPCs offer networking isolation. As an organization administrator, you can create VPCs and reserve them for use by certain namespaces and projects or share VPCs with all organization users. You can review the following sections for examples for effectively using VPCs to fit your organization needs.
For information about using a single VPC for the entire organization, see Multi-Tenancy Consumption Pattern 1: Resource Isolation with Single VPC for Multiple Businesses in One Supervisor Zone in the  VMware Cloud Foundation   Design Guide .
For information about how each Line of Business, represented as a  VCF Automation  project, can use a dedicated VPC, see Multi-Tenancy Consumption Pattern 2: Resource Isolation with Multiple VPCs for Multiple Lines of Business in One Supervisor Zone in the  VMware Cloud Foundation   Design Guide .

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Managing Organizations (merge)
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description: With VMware Cloud Foundation Automation (VCF Automation), you, as an organization administrator, and your application teams can view and consume infrastructure that the provider administrator made available to your organization. As an organization administrator, you create projects, manage users, and define resource limits for running workloads.The underlying infrastructure is based on vSphere Supervisors, which serve as the foundational structure for resource allocation. Supervisor-based infrastructure supports modern application use cases for provisioning containers and VMs. Provider administrators allocate infrastructure resources to organizations using regional quotas, while organization administrators distribute that allocated infrastructure to different projects within the organization using namespaces.Infrastructure ConceptsVCF Automation enables a private cloud experience by providing abstraction layers on vSphere infrastructure. Each abstraction serves a specific purpose.Regions. A region in VCF Automation aggregates compute, storage, memory, and networking resources from one or more zones. Regions are defined and managed by the provider administrator.Zones. A zone represents a vSphere cluster that provides compute, memory, and storage resources for the organization.Region Quota. A region quota defines the compute and storage resources that are allocated to an organization for a given region. The organization can receive quotas from multiple regions. The provider administrator decides from which regions to give a quota to an organization. The region quota can be split across more than one vSphere zone in a region. A region quota includes the following: CPU and memory utilization limits which represent the upper bound of quota in a region. CPU and memory reservations which represent the guaranteed capacity that is allocated in a region. VM classes which represent the T-shirt-sized classes of compute that are available to the organization. Storage classes which represent the storage policies and the quota that is assigned in a region. Resources for Application TeamsResources allocated to the organization in the form of a region quota can be further subdivided and allocated to application teams.Project. Projects are logical representations of users and user groups and the resource pools that those users are entitled to. The resource pools that projects use are called namespaces. Resources, like VMs and Kubernetes clusters, are provisioned on namespaces.Namespace. A vSphere Namespace is a resource pool that comprises CPU, memory, and storage resources that are assigned to projects inVCF Automation. Namespaces derive their quota from the overall region quota of the organization and come with controls such CPU, memory, and storage usage. Each namespace is bound to the scope of the project that it is associated with. Each project can contain multiple namespaces. Because the region quota can be split across multiple vSphere zones, the resource pool of a namespace can also be split across multiple vSphere zones. As an organization administrator, you can configure which zones a namespace can derive its resource limits from.Namespace Class. Namespace classes are templates for defining guardrails on parameters that are used to create a namespace, like CPU limits, storage limits, permissible VM and storage classes, and others. Namespace classes are a prerequisite for creating namespaces. In the namespace class, you can set default values for CPU and memory limits and reservations. If a namespace class has a zone defined, default values for namespace limits and reservations are used from the zone section. As an organization administrator, you create namespace classes that fit your project needs. You can create one or more namespaces using the default namespace classes that come preconfigured in your organization. You can also override those defaults in a given project to suit specific configurations.An example of an organization quota: Region  region-one  has three vSphere Zones -  vs-zone-1 ,  vs-zone-2 , and  vs-zone-3 . Organization  org-1  has a region quota of 25Ghz of CPU in  vs-zone-1  and 50GHz of CPU in  vs-zone2  for a total quota of 75Ghz of CPU in  region-one . Networking ConceptsVPC. Virtual private clouds (VPCs) are the foundational networking element used in VCF Automation to enable applications to communicate with each other and the outside world. A VPC provides an isolated domain of networking resources that can be associated with one or more namespaces. As the organization administrator, you create VPCs for your organization. In addition, organization administrators and advanced project users can use the Networking Service in the IaaS Console to create, update, and manage resources within a given VPC.Connectivity Profile. A connectivity profile is a template for VPC configuration. You can provide one or more external and private Transit Gateway IP address blocks that are used by VPCs configured with a specific connectivity profile. When the provider administrator allocates the regional networking configuration to the organization, а default connectivity profile is created. As an organization administrator, you can create additional connectivity profiles to use in your organization.Consumption ConceptsApplication teams can provision resources on a self-service basis in VCF Automation using the catalog or the IaaS Services console. The catalog contains blueprints that are curated and maintained by the organization administrator, while cloud services in the IaaS Services console can be accessed directly without blueprints. Both methods of provisioning resources require content libraries that host the images.Blueprints and Catalog. Blueprints are infrastructure templates that define the resources and cloud services you want to create to run an application. Organization administrators create the blueprints and publish them as catalog items for end users. End users interact with form entries of catalog items to request resources. These forms can be customized to hide unnecessary fields or to create dynamic entries.Self-service IaaS Console. The self-service IaaS Services Console in VCF Automation allows users to provision cloud services directly on namespaces from the VCF Automation user interface, the VCF Automation APIs, and CLIs without the need for blueprints and the catalog.Content Library. Content libraries host VM images that application teams use when deploying resources. Organizations can either use content libraries that are provided by the provider administrator or create their own organization-specific content libraries.Policies. Policies provide governance on resources like VMs and VKS clusters that are provisioned from cloud services. Policies can be applied to the whole organization or to individual projects. VCF Automation supports two types of policies: Policies that are applied to resources provisioned from the catalog, such as Approval, Day 2, and Lease policies. Policies that are applied to resources provisioned through the self-service IaaS console.

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Managing Organizations for VM Apps in VCF Automation
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description: You use VMware Cloud Foundation Automation for VM Apps to connect to your public and private cloud providers so that you can deploy machines, applications, and services that you create to those resources. You and your teams develop cloud-templates-as-code in an environment that supports an iterative workflow, from development to testing to production. At provisioning time, you can deploy across a range of cloud vendors.VCF Automation for VM Apps is a blueprint development and deployment service. You and your teams use the service to deploy machines, applications, and services to your cloud vendor resources.How do you set up a VCF Automation for VM Apps organizationBefore you begin, your service provider administrator creates the organization in the VCF Automation Provider Management Portal. Only one new VM Apps organization can be created from the VCF Automation Provider Management Portal. Additional VM Apps organizations can be created using the VCF Automation API.For more information about creating organization in the VCF Automation Provider Management Portal, see Overview of VCF Automation Provider Management.As an organization administrator in VCF Automation for VM Apps, generally referred to as a cloud administrator, you set up the provisioning infrastructure and create the projects that group users and resources. The system administrator does not allocate infrastructure to your organization. Add your cloud vendor accounts. Determine which regions or datastores are the cloud zones that you want your developers deploying to. Create projects that group the developers with the cloud zones. Create policies that define the cloud zones. As a VCF Automation for VM Apps administrator, you must understand the user roles and set up connections with your cloud account vendor and integration applications. When you configure the cloud accounts and integrations, you are configuring the communication between VCF Automation and those target systems.VCF Automation also provides a single point where you can request and manage catalog items. The catalog is the simplified user interface that cloud administrators make available to users when the administrator's teams do not need full access to developing and building the templates. You use the catalog to deploy templates to cloud regions or datastores associated with projects.As a cloud administrator, you create catalog items by importing released VCF Automation templates and Amazon Web Services CloudFormation templates that your users can deploy to your cloud vendor regions or datastores. Your users can then request and monitor the provisioning process. After deployment, users can manage the deployed catalog items throughout the deployment lifecycle.How to use VCF Automation for VM Apps user interfaceAn overview of VCF Automation for VM Apps includes the following basic functions. The  Home  tab shows a summary of your resources, deployments, and other inventory currently managed by  VCF Automation , as well as pending notifications and action items. This tab is available to administrators only. The  Consume  tab shows the current status of your provisioned, discovered, onboarded, and other resources. You can access resource details and day 2 actions that you use to manage your resources. The  Design  tab is your development home. You use the canvas and the YAML editor to develop and then deploy your machines and applications. The  Infrastructure  tab is where you add and organize your cloud vendor resources and users. This tab also provides information about deployed blueprints. The  Content and Policies  tab is where you import content to the catalog and create policies to manage deployments. The  Extensibility  tab is where you can extend and automate your application life cycles. You can subscribe to events that are used to trigger extensibility actions or  VCF Operations orchestrator  workflows. The  Orchestrator  tab is where you access your  VCF Operations orchestrator  integration. You use  VCF Operations orchestrator  to build and run workflows that extend automation capabilities. An  Alerts  tab provides notifications regarding capacity, performance, and availability for your infrastructure resources. You must have a configured integration with  VCF Operations  to see and use the alerts. The  Inbox  tab is where you approve catalog requests and respond to deployments that request user input. As an organization administrator VCF Automation for VM Apps, you must understand the user roles and set up connections with your cloud account vendor and integration applications. When you configure the cloud accounts and integrations, you are configuring the communication between VCF Automation and those target systems.You configure your cloud infrastructure to support template development and deployment. The infrastructure begins with cloud vendors, then you add VCF Automation users as project members and link them to the cloud account regions as projects. At this point, you can continue to develop templates, or you can turn over development to the project administrators and members.As a project member, use VCF Automation as you iteratively develop and deploy templates, until you have a production-worthy product. The deployment locations are configured by your cloud administrator as part of the infrastructure. The administrator has the best understanding of your organizations resources and budget.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Managing Projects in VCF Automation
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description: Projects in VCF Automation organizations provide a logical grouping of users and the infrastructure that they are assigned. Projects are used to represent real world teams which are in charge of development or operations. Each project has one or more namespaces assigned to it. Each namespace is an envelope of resources where applications can be deployed. Access controls for projects are governed by pre-defined roles.Project ConceptsNamespaces and Projects. Organization administrators can create and attach one or more namespaces to a project. Administrators can also delete a namespace at any time, which dissociates the namespace from the project. Every organization comes with a default project. The default project doesn’t have users or namespaces. The organization administrator can change the name, description of the default project, and add users and namespaces to the default project.Namespace Class. A namespace class is a template that is used to create namespaces. All components of a namespace, including limits on CPU, memory, and storage utilization, VM classes and storage classes, and content libraries can be defined as a reusable template. Namespace classes are created and maintained by organization administrators.Namespaces and Resource Limits. Infrastructure quota assigned to an organization can be subdivided and assigned to project teams in the form of namespaces. Namespaces are isolated resource pools in which resources like VMs, VKS clusters, and volumes can be provisioned. Organization administrators can override the resource limits specified in a namespace class during namespace creation.Namespaces and Zones. The resource limits of a namespace can be satisfied from capacity in one or more vSphere zones. When creating a namespace, organization administrators can select wich zones the namespace can use.Namespaces and Organization Quotas. Namespaces count towards the organization quota. The sum total of resource limits of all created namespaces cannot exceed the organization quota.Best Practices for ProjectsHow many projects and namespaces you create depends on your organization needs. Projects . Multiple projects are used when isolation boundaries between project teams are required. Only project members can access deployments and resources available to a project. Fewer projects are desired when isolation requirements can be traded off for a simpler operating model. Namespaces . Multiple namespaces are used when strict resource limits are needed for each application. Namespaces are logical constructs that can be used to define application boundaries. Each application can be deployed on a namespace with prescribed resource limits for CPU, memory, and storage. For instance, a group of VMs and VKS clusters that make up an application can be logically grouped together in a namespace.

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Organization Management
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
VCF Automation improves governance for users and resources by enabling Organization Administrators create and assign projects and vSphere Namespaces tailored for different application teams.
#todo make a list of roles and what capabilities each these roles do. For example, "what does an 'organization administrator' do; what are other kinds of admins?"
Organization administrators can set resource limits and policies while delegating network management through Virtual Private Clouds (VPCs) for application teams.
Additionally, Policy as Code enables organization administrators to enforce instance-centric policies for Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) resources from a central location for compliance and reducing the risk of human error.

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Organization Management in VCF Automation
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
Organization ManagementLast Updated December 16, 2025Use **VCF Automation** as a cloud administrator (or organization administrator) to set up projects for application teams, allocate resources, and apply governance.In VCF Automation, an organization is a top level entity that represents a line of business or a tenant. Each organization operates in a secure and isolated environment where users can access only allocated services and resources. Organizations consume resources and cloud services from a shared pool of resources. The resources allocated to organizations can be further allocated to application teams which are modeled in VCF Automation as projects. Organizations have users with varying levels of permissions depending on their role and duties.Organizations in VCF Automation are created by the provider administrator in the VCF Automation Provider Management Portal. The provider administrator can create two types of organizations: an All Apps organization and a VM Apps organization. VM Apps organizations can run VM-based applications, while All Apps organizations are enabled to run a comprehensive set of built-in cloud services. For more information about creating VCF Automation organizations in the provider portal, see Managing Organizations.Regardless of the type, each organization has its own organization portal where users log in to consume resources and services. Every organization has its own identity source that they connect to and can import users from.All Apps Organizations in VCF AutomationAll Apps оrganizations offer application teams a comprehensive set of built-in cloud services to provision VMs, Kubernetes, networking, volumes, Secret Store, databases, Harbor container registries, external DNS, certificates, and AI workloads. These cloud services can be consumed on a self-service basis through a curated catalog or self-service interfaces.Organizations enable line-of-business or tenant organization administrators to further organize and govern resources that are allocated to them among application teams through the following capabilities: Resource management for project teams. Centralized content management for the organization. Policy-based governance on usage of resources. Quota-based management of networking resources. Workflow orchestration and extensibility through event subscriptions. Integration with identity providers of their choice.
For information on working with All Apps organizations, see the Managing Organizations for All Apps in guide.Provider Consumption Organizations in VCF AutomationA Provider Consumption organization (PCO) is a special type of All Apps organization in VCF Automation that the provider administrator enables in the VCF Automation
 Provider Management Portal. The provider administrator can enable only one Provider Consumption organization. For more information about PCOs, see Create a Provider Consumption Organization.The PCO is intended for use when the provider wants to have their own consumption service for their users and/or they want to share catalog items with other organizations under their management.PCOs are administered in the same way as other All Apps organizations, but they offer some additional capabilities on top of what a standard All Apps organization provides. PCOs come with a preconfigured  VCF Operations orchestrator  instance that is embedded in the organization portal, which you access on the  Orchestrate  tab. As a PCO administrator, you can publish  VCF Operations orchestrator  objects as catalog items to other organizations that use the same embedded  VCF Operations orchestrator  instance. You can publish catalog items to other organizations that use VM images from a provider content library. For more information about managing your VCF Operations orchestrator
 integration, see Managing VMware Cloud Foundation Operations Orchestrator.VM Apps Organizations in VCF AutomationVM Apps organizations help existing VMware Aria Automation users transition to VCF Automation 9.0 without any impact to infrastructure, automation, or end-user experience.In VM Apps organizations, the allocation of resources, like cloud accounts, cloud zones, profiles, image mappings and so on, is contained in the organization itself. The organization administrator defines and works with the infrastructure; the provider administrator does not allocate resources to organization of this type.If you upgrade an existing VMware Aria Automation 8.x deployment to VCF Automation 9, your organizations are automatically mapped to VCF Automation for VM Apps organizations. You continue to use vIDB and VMware Aria Suite Lifecycle to manage vIDM to maintain legacy authentication.
For information on working with VM Apps organizations, see the Managing Organizations in for VM Apps guide.Best Practices for Organizations in VCF AutomationWhen to use All Apps vs VM Apps? All Apps organizations are used when organizations are ready to leverage the comprehensive set of built-in cloud services to provision VMs, Kubernetes, and so on. The underlying infrastructure requires vSphere Supervisor clusters and is managed in the  VCF Automation  Provider Management Portal. Talk to your provider administrator about how you can leverage these capabilities. VM Apps organizations are intended for current users of VMware Aria Automation who want to continue their journey with minimal disruptions. The VM Apps organization is fully self-contained with built-in infrastructure management and consumption capabilities. When to use blueprints vs the IaaS self-service console? Blueprints and the catalog offer a controlled manner to build and curate infrastructure. They are prescriptive in terms of the provisioned resources and so are suitable to deploy applications in production. They are also suitable for end users who do not want to concern themselves with details of the infrastructure. The IaaS self-service console offers more flexibility and is more suitable for development purposes.

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Configuring VCF Automation as an OIDC Proxy Server
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
You can use VCF Automation as a tenant-aware OpenId Connect (OIDC) identity provider proxy server. Verify that your role includes the  OIDC Server: Manage Settings  right. Verify that the roles of the users that will log in to the OIDC relying party (OIDC client) through  VCF Automation  include the  OIDC Server: Enable  right. After you configure VCF Automation as an OIDC proxy server, when a user attempts to log in to the OIDC relying party (OIDC client), they are redirected to VCF Automation and prompted to enter the name of their organization and their SSO or local credentials. After providing the necessary credentials, the user is directed to the OIDC relying party.VCF Automation delegates actual authentication to the authentication mechanism used by the provider or organization. This can result in additional redirects to any external Identity Providers that perform authentication for those users.Do not delete the automation-relying-party item in the Relying Parties list on the OIDC Services page. automation-relying-party is necessary for the organization portal services. Log in to the  VCF Automation Provider Management Portal . From the left navigation panel, select  OIDC Services . Click  Relying Parties  and click  New . Enter a relying party name for the client application registration, and make a note of it. Enter the URI to which to redirect users that are attempting to log in to the relying party, and click  Save . Copy the relying party ID and secret, and make note of them. Configure your OIDC relying party to use  VCF Automation  as an identity provider proxy server with the relying party ID and secret. You can retrieve the provider configuration values, including the JWKS endpoint and information about other endpoints and scopes necessary for the OIDC proxy configuration at the well-known configuration URL  hostname /oidc/.well-known/openid-configuration . See View and Edit the OIDC Proxy General Settings in Your VCF Automation. When a user attempts to log in to the OIDC relying party, they are redirected to VCF Automation, prompted to select a VCF Automation organization, and to provide their credentials. After a successful authorization, they are redirected back to the OIDC relying party.
You can use the vertical ellipsis () menu next to the name of the relying party ID to edit and delete the relying party, to regenerate a secret, and to copy the relying party ID.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Automation/Tenancy and Access Control/VCF Identity Broker/Configuring VCF Automation as an OIDC Proxy Server.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Enabling PKCE with vIDB in VCF Automation
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
VCF Automation supports Proof Key for Code Exchange (PKCE).Verify that you configured your system to use an OpenID Connect Identity Provider. See Configure Your System to Use an OpenID Connect Identity Provider Using Your VCF Automation Provider Management Portal.
PKCE is an extension to the OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code flow that is used to prevent CSRF and authorization code injection attacks. For more information, see Proof Key for Code Exchange in the OAuth 2.0 documentation. Run the request to retrieve your organization's settings. GET https://vcfa.example.com/api/admin/org/organization_id/settings/oauth The response contains the OAuth settings for your organization. Under  OrgOAuthSettings , make the following changes. Modify the  usePkce  element to  true . If your identity provider requires that client credentials be sent as an authorization header when making the API request to retrieve the access token, modify the  sendClientCredentialsAsAuthorizationHeader  element to  true . The default behavior is for the client credentials to be sent in the body of the API request. To update your OAuth settings with your modifications, run a PUT request. PUT https://vcfa.example.com/api/admin/org/organization_id/settings/oauth In the body of the request, include the modified elements of your OAuth settings.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Automation/Tenancy and Access Control/VCF Identity Broker/Enabling PKCE with vIDB in VCF Automation.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Generating API Access Tokens using vIDB
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description: You can generate and issue API access tokens. You are authenticated using your respective security best practices, including leveraging two-factor authorization, by using API access tokens, you can grant access for building automation against VCF Automation.Authenticating with an API token uses the "Refreshing an Access Token" standard as specified in the OAuth 2.0 RFC 6749 Section 6 to allow access to VCF Automation as an OAuth application. The returned access token is the same as a VCF Automation access token and client applications can use it to make subsequent API calls to VCF Automation. To make an OAuth 2.0 RFC-compliant request, familiarize yourself with Request for Comments (RFC) 6749 Section 6 information about refreshing an access token.Access tokens are artifacts that client applications use to make API requests on behalf of a user. Applications need access tokens for authentication. When an access token expires, to obtain access tokens, applications can use API tokens. By default, API tokens expire after 90 days.When using access tokens, applications cannot perform certain tasks. Change the user password Perform user management tasks Create more tokens View or revoke other tokens When accessing VCF Automation by using an API access token, applications have only view rights for the following resources. User Group Roles Global roles Rights bundles Applications accessing VCF Automation by using an API access token do not have the following rights. Token: Manage Token: Manage All Similar to generating a user API token, you can create a service account by using the VCF Automation API. The API request for creating a service account uses the same API endpoint as creating a user API token, but the presence of the software_id field indicates the intent to create a service account. In the upper right corner of the navigation bar, click your user name, and select  My Account . Under the  API Tokens  section, click  New . Enter a name for the token, and click  Create . The generated API token appears. You must copy the token because it appears only once. After you click  OK , you cannot retrieve this token again, you can only revoke it. Make an OAuth 2.0 RFC-compliant request to the  https:// site.cloud.example.com /oauth/provider/token  API endpoint. The request returns an access token that applications can use to perform tasks in  VCF Automation . The token is valid even after the user logs out. When an access token expires, the application can obtain more access tokens by using the API token. Request:POST https://host_name/oauth/provider/token Accept: application/json Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded Content-Length: 71 grant_type=refresh_token&refresh_token=Generated_API_Token Response:HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: application/json { "access_token":"Generated_Access_Token", "token_type":"Bearer", "expires_in":2592000, "refresh_token":null } Request using the generated access token:GET https://host_name/cloudapi/1.0.0/orgs Accept: application/json;version=40.0 Authorization: Bearer Generated_Access_Token Response:{"resultTotal":1,"pageCount":1,"page":1,"pageSize":25,"associations":[{"entityId":"urn:vcloud:org:a11a11a1-1111-1111-1a11","associationId":"a11a11a1-1111-1111-1a11@a11a1a11-1111-1111-1a11"}],"values":[{"id":"urn:vcloud:org:a11a1a11-1111-1111-1a11-a1a11aa11a1","name":"System","displayName":"System","description":"System Bucket","isEnabled":true,"managedBy":null,"canManageOrgs":true,"maskedEventTaskUsername":"system","directlyManagedOrgCount":0,"isClassicTenant":false,"isProviderConsumptionOrg":false,"creationStatus":"READY"}]}% If you want tenants to be able to generate tokens, you must grant tenant roles the  Manage user's own API token  right. By default, tenant users see only the tokens they create. To allow organization administrators to see and revoke the tokens of the other tenant users in the organization, you must grant them the  Manage all users' API tokens  right. Administrators with the  Manage all users' API tokens  right can see only the names of other users' the tokens, not the tokens themselves. To revoke any of your tokens, navigate to the  User preferences  page, and click the vertical ellipsis next to the token. To revoke the tokens of other users, in the top navigation bar, under  Administration , navigate to the access control settings for users. When selecting a specific user, you can also see their access tokens and revoke them. If you must identify events triggered by the use of an API access token, in the event log the following line appears in the  additionalProperties  section of an event. ```default "currentContext.refreshTokenId": "<UUID_of_the_token_that_performed_the_action>

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Managing Identity Providers with vIDB
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
You can integrate your VCF Automation with one or more external identity providers (IdPs), and import users and groups to your organizations. You can configure an LDAP server connection at the system or the organization level, a SAML integration at the organization level, and an OpenID Connect (OIDC) integration at the organization level.To determine the correct values and settings and to ensure proper and accurate configuration, see also the product documentation of those identity providers.You can also use the VCF Operations provider identity configuration, making VIDB the identity provider. See VCF Single Sign-On Models and Configuring VCF Single Sign-On. If you already have an OIDC connection for the provider organization, you cannot connect to VCF
VKS Single Sign-On (SSO). You must remove the OIDC configuration to configure VCF SSO. If you configure VCF SSO, a VCF SSO tab replaces the OIDC tab on the Identity Providers page.An organization can define an identity provider that it shares with other applications. Users authenticate to the identity provider to obtain a token that they can then use to log in to the organization. Such a strategy can enable an enterprise to provide access to multiple, unrelated services, including VCF Automation, with a single set of credentials, an arrangement often referred to as single sign-on.You can integrate your VCF Automation organizations with more than one identity provider. You must not have identical user names across IdPs. You can have only one integration per IdP technology. For example, you can have one LDAP, one SAML, and one OpenID Connect (OIDC) integration simultaneously. The login page displays all configured sign-in options and to make the login more user friendly, you can customize the button labels from the IdP edit pages.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Automation/Tenancy and Access Control/VCF Identity Broker/Managing Identity Providers with vIDB.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Managing IDPs
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description: As an organization administrator, you can use one or more external identity providers to import and manage users and groups in your organization. You can configure an LDAP server connection, a SAML integration, and an OpenID Connect (OIDC) integration.VCF Automation supports user login with an identity providers directly. Any third-party provider with OIDC, SAML, AD/LDAP protocols can be configured to use Single Sign-on to VCF Automation for identity and access management.

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Remapping VCF Automation Users Between Identity Providers
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description: You can remap VCF Automation users between identity providers.You can remap individual users from one identity provider (IDP) to another by using the VCF Automation API. You can use the VCF Automation UI for bulk remapping of users between identity providers.You can use the VCF Automation UI for bulk remapping of users between identity providers. Verify that your role includes the Group / User: Manage  right. Verify that the organization is configured with the identity provider types that you want to remap between. Log in to the  VCF Automation Provider Management Portal . From the primary left navigation panel, select  Access Control . Select  Users . Click  Bulk Update . Click  Export Users . The users are exported into a CSV file. In the CSV file with the users, change the value in the  providerType  field to identify the new IdP for each user. VCF Automation  supports the  SAML ,  LDAP , and  OAUTH  values. To remap a user to an OIDC identity provider, you must change the value in the  providerType  field to  OAUTH . To match the user name in the IdP that each user is remapping to, modify the user name. For  VCF Automation  to continue to associate the user's assets with the user when they log in through the new login flow, the ID of the user must remain unchanged. Changes to all other fields are ignored. Save your changes and close the CSV file. In the  Users Bulk Update  wizard, click  Next . Click  Select CSV File , browse for the file, and upload it. Click  Next . Click  Update . When you start the update process, users are remapped one by one. Users for which no changes are detected are skipped. If you close the  VCF Automation  UI tab while before the process is complete, the update stops. You can remap individual users from one identity provider (IdP) to another by using the VCF Automation API. Verify that your role includes the Group / User: Manage  right. Verify that the organization is configured with the identity provider types that you want to remap between. For information about bulk remapping of users between identity providers by using the VCF Automation UI, see Remap Users Between Identity Providers Using Your VCF Automation Provider Management Portal. Make a GET request to  /cloudapi/1.0.0/users . VCF Automation  returns a list of the users within the organization. Locate the user you want to remap, and retrieve the user information. GET /cloudapi/1.0.0/users/{user_id} Make a PUT request to  /cloudapi/1.0.0/users/ {user_id} . To remap a user, you must change the  providerType  field to identify the new IDP.  VCF Automation  supports the  SAML ,  LDAP , and  OAUTH  values. Additionally, to match the user name in the IDP that the user is remapping to, you can modify the user name. For  VCF Automation  to continue to associate the user's assets with the user when they log in through the new login flow, the ID of the user must remain unchanged. If you are remapping to provider type  LDAP ,  VCF Automation  validates the user name with the LDAP server before committing the operation. If  VCF Automation  does not complete this step for any reason, for example, loss of connectivity to the LDAP server, the remapping fails. If you are remapping a user to be a local user by specifying provider type  LOCAL , similar to the process of creating a user, you must provide a password. Verify that  VCF Automation  returns an  OK  response specifying the newly remapped provider type in the response body. To find the user that you want to remap, make the following request.Request:GET /cloudapi/1.0.0/users?pageSize=10 HTTP/1.1 Host: 127.0.0.1:8443 Accept: application/json;version=37.1 Sample response:{ "resultTotal": 2, "pageCount": 1, "page": 1, "pageSize": 10, "associations": null, "values": [ ..., { "username": "testuser", "fullName": "", "description": null, "id": "urn:vcloud:user:2b038199-0063-4c13-9bba-a3b58d775785", "roleEntityRefs": [ { "name": "vApp Author", "id": "urn:vcloud:role:85f69506-52a5-3e20-869a-ea18d667e19e" } ], "orgEntityRef": { "name": "testorg", "id": "urn:vcloud:org:806f0d87-c8b9-47f5-bfbe-3dc73a4c0d14" }, "password": "******", "email": "", "nameInSource": "testuser", "enabled": true, "isGroupRole": false, "providerType": "LOCAL" } ] } To remap testuser from LOCAL to LDAP, make a PUT request.Request:PUT /cloudapi/1.0.0/users/urn:vcloud:user:2b038199-0063-4c13-9bba-a3b58d775785 HTTP/1.1 Host: 127.0.0.1:8443 Accept: application/json;version=37.1 Content-Type: application/json;version=37.1 Body: { "username": "testuser", "fullName": "", "description": null, "id": "testorg", "id": "urn:vcloud:org:806f0d87-c8b9-47f5-bfbe-3dc73a4c0d14" }, "password": "******", "email": "", "nameInSource": "testuser", "enabled": true, "isGroupRole": false, "providerType": "LDAP" } vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Using VCF Automation as an Identity Provider Proxy Server
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
ou can take advantage of the OIDC Services to use VCF Automation as a tenant-aware identity provider proxy server.When VCF Automation is configured as an identity provider proxy server by using the OAuth 2.0 OpenID Connect standard, relying parties can use VCF Automation for tenant-aware authentication of users known to VCF Automation. For detailed information on the OpenID Connect standard, see OpenID Connect Core 1.0.As an identity provider proxy server, VCF Automation acts as intermediary between the client application (relying party) and the identity provider, and delegates actual authentication to the respective authentication mechanism used by the provider or tenants.A system administrator can configure relying parties that integrate with VCF Automation and then enable individual organizations to allow their users to use VCF Automation as an identity provider proxy.When making browser-based requests to the /oidc endpoints, the default behavior is for browser pages to be loaded from the VCF Automation host. To use OIDC, you can also configure a non-VCF Automation host into the CORS filtering list.Authentication FlowIntegration with VCF Automation
 is implemented through the OAuth 2.0 OIDC authorization code flow standard. For detailed information, see Authentication using the Authorization Code Flow.When a relying party redirects a user to VCF Automation, if there is no existing client session, the user is prompted to log in to VCF Automation by first identifying the organization or provider portal they wish to log into. The user authenticates through the configured authentication mechanism, which may involve further redirections to external identity providers. If the user's browser detects an existing VCF Automation user session, the authentication flow provides an SSO experience and no user interaction is required for reauthentication. Upon successful completion of the process, VCF Automation returns an access token and an ID token. The authorization code that is issued as part of the flow is valid for 5 minutes. The access token is valid for 5 minutes, and the ID token is valid for an hour.You cannot use the access token that VCF Automation returns upon successful authentication for accessing the UI portals or for making regular VCF Automation API calls.ID Token DetailsThe ID token that VCF Automation returns contains the following OpenID standard claims and VCF Automation specific claims.OpenID Request ScopesThe scope of the OpenID request is used to specify the privileges requested for an access token.Endpoints
You can use the access token returned by  VCF Automation  to retrieve claims about the authenticated user at the  hostname /oidc/UserInfo  endpoint. For details, see UserInfo Endpoint.
You can retrieve the provider configuration values, including the JWKS endpoint and information about other endpoints and scopes necessary for the OIDC proxy configuration at the well-known configuration URL  hostname /oidc/.well-known/openid-configuration . See View and Edit the OIDC Proxy General Settings in Your VCF Automation. Token Exchange Access to VCF Automation Identity Provider ProxyProgrammatic integration with the identity provider proxy functionality of VCF Automation is available through the token exchange flow that is detailed below. This flow does not involve the VCF Automation UI and is suitable for scripted access, such as CLI. Obtain a  VCF Automation  JWT by either directly logging in or by using an API token. Run a POST request. POST hostname/oidc/oauth2/token Select  x-www-form-urlencoded  for the body of the request. Include the following parameters in the body of the request. { "grant_type": "urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:jwt-bearer", "assertion": "VMware_Cloud_Director JWT", "client_id": "Relying_party_ID", "scope": "openid profile email phone groups vcd_idp", } The response returns both an ID token that includes the OIDC and  VCF Automation  claims, and an access token that you can use to retrieve claims about the authenticated user at the  hostname /oidc/UserInfo  endpoint. Encoded ID token example:eyJhbGciOiJSUzI1NiIsInR5NDg4SI6I................4dHnbU1RQ6Y9Yohgw Decoded ID token example:{ "at_hash": "1AA1aAA1AAAAAAaAA1A11a", "sub": "111111111-1111-1111-1111-11111111", "roles": [ "Organization Administrator" ], "iss": "https://hostname/oidc", "groups": [ "ALL USERS" ], "preferred_username": "testuser@vcd-ms1", "nonce": "ab123acab", "aud": "33333333-3333-3333-3333-33333333333", "azp": "22222222-2222-2222-2222-22222222", "org_id": "12345678-1234-1234-1234-123456789abc", "org_display_name": "oidcorg", "name": "test user", "phone_number": " ", "exp": 1111111111, "org_name": "oidcorg", "iat": 1111111111, "email": "user1@vmware.com" } User Info response example:{ "sub": "111111111-1111-1111-1111-11111111", "preferred_username": "administrator", "name": "administrator user", "email": "user1@site.com", "phone_number": "0 (111) 222-3333", "roles": [ "system administrator" ], "groups": [], "org_name": "system", "org_display_name": "System Organization", "org_id": "12345678-1234-1234-1234-123456789abc" }
