vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.title: VCF Operations HCX
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.description:
VCF Operations HCX is VMware’s integrated workload mobility and migration platform built into VMware Cloud Foundation. It combines the power of VMware Hybrid Cloud Extension (HCX) with VCF’s operational tooling to simplify application migration, workload rebalancing, and business continuity across data centers and clouds.You can perform secure and automated migrations without requiring changes to applications or network configurations.Thus, you can place workloads based on business requirements. The platform minimizes downtime during migrations, improves scalability, and supports compliance and security throughout workload transitions.
HCX stands for Hybrid Cloud eXtension—it’s not just another name for vMotion. It’s a comprehensive application mobility platform from VMware that enables workload migration, workload rebalancing, and business continuity across data centers and clouds.VCF Operations HCX has the following capabilities: Seamless workload migration. Migrate VMs and applications in waves live or in bulk with minimal or zero downtime. Network extension. Extend networks while preserving IP addresses and topologies to maintain application connectivity. Inter-and intra-VCF mobility. Enable workload mobility within and across multiple VCF instances, including site-to-site and region-to-region migrations. Application placement optimization. Enables high-performance application mobility across different environments, making it easier to optimize workload placement based on business requirements. At its heart, VCF Operations HCX is an application mobility platform that: **Connects environments—on-premises data centers, private clouds, and public clouds—with optimized, secure network interconnectivity. Enables workload migration—live or bulk migration of virtual machines (VMs) and applications between environments with minimal downtime. Supports hybrid cloud adoption—making it easier to modernize, consolidate, or balance workloads across sites. Essentially, it extends the capabilities of VCF so that moving workloads into, out of, or around your VCF estate is seamless and automated.VCF Operations HCX automates the process of moving VMs and applications from one environment to another. This includes: Live migrations (zero or near-zero downtime) Bulk migrations for large-scale moves Cross-platform migrations (including non-vSphere sources in some scenarios) Network extension so IPs/MACs remain consistent during migration This makes migrations faster, less error-prone, and less disruptive than traditional approaches.HCX builds a secure, encrypted interconnect between sites that: Extends Layer-2 networks across sites Preserves VM networking so that workloads keep their addresses Provides optimized tunnels tailored for high-speed bulk movement Cloud adoption isn’t a one-time event — usage patterns change. HCX enables: Moving workloads based on performance needs Rebalancing for cost or compliance reasons Continuous optimization of where workloads run This is key in hybrid environments where business needs or performance requirements evolve over time.VCF Operations HCX has deeper integration with VCF: Unified management & single sign-on with other VCF components Shared licensing managed through VCF Operations Integrated planning & execution workflows with VCF Operations for Networks Easier deployment with a single unified HCX Manager appliance That means less separate manual setup and a smoother experience from discovery to execution.Imagine you’re relocating a city’s services (libraries, police stations, hospitals) to a new smart city: Traditional migration = manually moving each building piece by piece. VCF Operations HCX = building a dedicated transit corridor where services can shift live without interruption, while preserving all their connections and addresses — all orchestrated by a central operations dashboard instead of manual labor.
vMotion is VMware’s native live-migration technology for moving a running VM between ESX hosts (including memory and CPU state), usually within the same VCF Domain or cluster.HCX doesn’t replace vMotion; it leverages it as one migration method (called “HCX vMotion”) when moving workloads between HCX-connected sites. It also supports: Cold Migration: Powered-off VMs Bulk Migration: Parallel, batched workloads Replication-Assisted vMotion: Parallel live migrations via replication + vMotion So, vMotion is a component inside HCX’s larger orchestration and connectivity framework. VCF Operations HCX is VMware’s integrated workload mobility solution within VMware Cloud Foundation. It simplifies application migration and workload rebalancing across on-prem, hybrid, and multi-cloud environments. Via optimized network extension and interconnects, it preserves application connectivity and minimizes disruption. Recent integrations with VCF improve deployment, management, and operational workflows.
VCF Day 0 Tasks, VCF Day 1 Tasks, or VCF Day 2 Tasks could be nice places to visit from here.

headers.heading: HCX uses vMotion as one of its tools

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Workload Mobility and Resilience/VCF Operations HCX.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.title: vMotion
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.description:
vMotion is vSphere’s live-migration mechanism that moves a running VM from one ESX host to another with no downtime.
In VCF, vMotion is foundational plumbing—it’s how higher-level services (DRS, maintenance workflows) actually move workloads.
VCF └── vSphere ├── DRS → decides *when/where* to move ├── HA → may trigger restarts (not vMotion) └── vMotion → performs the *move*
Implemented by: vSphere
Orchestrated via: vCenter Server
Consumed by: DRS, maintenance mode, admin actions DRS decides. vMotion moves. Pre-copy: VM memory is copied to the destination while the VM keeps running. Iterative sync: Dirty pages are recopied until the delta is tiny. Switchover: VM is briefly quiesced (milliseconds), CPU state flips. Resume: VM continues on the new host with the same IP/MAC. No reboot. No app restart. Shared storage access L2 network reachability Compatible CPU features (or EVC) vMotion-enabled VMkernel network with sufficient bandwidth
VCF designs these prerequisites in by default.
DRS load balancing (automatic) Host maintenance mode (drain before patching) Hardware refresh (zero-downtime) Policy remediation (after placement decisions)
You rarely “use vMotion” directly in VCF—it’s constantly in use under the hood. Not a scheduler (it doesn’t decide) Not a failover mechanism Not application-aware Not cross-site DR by itself It is transport, not policy. “VCF places workloads with vMotion” → No. DRS places; vMotion moves. “vMotion is free” → No. It consumes network and CPU headroom. “vMotion fixes capacity issues” → No. It redistributes load only. vMotion doesn’t choose destinations, and it doesn’t judge priorities—it just moves things safely when told. vMotion = zero-downtime VM movement Core building block for DRS and maintenance Always present and assumed in VCF designs Necessary—but never sufficient—by itself
VCF Day 0 Tasks, VCF Day 1 Tasks, or VCF Day 2 Tasks could be nice places to visit from here.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Workload Mobility and Resilience/vMotion.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.title: VMware Live Recovery
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.description:
VMware Live Recovery is VMware’s modern, unified disaster-recovery (DR) and cyber-recovery capability, designed to protect VCF-managed workloads against outages, site failures, and ransomware, with minimal downtime and minimal data loss. VMware Live Recovery = continuous protection + fast failover + clean recovery, natively aligned with VCF operations. VMware Live Recovery is not a hypervisor feature and not just storage replication.
It lives at the platform services / operations layer of VCF. Site failure Cluster outage Maintenance windows gone wrong Encrypted VMs Malicious data corruption Need for clean rollback instead of “latest replica” Near-zero RPO (seconds) Change-block tracking Continuous replication rather than periodic snapshots Automated failover / failback Application-aware recovery ordering Network remapping and IP preservation Roll back to a known-good state Avoid restoring infected replicas Immutable recovery points (depending on the backing storage) Protect workloads: on-prem → on-prem on-prem → cloud cloud → cloud Strong alignment with hybrid VCF deployments Primarily: VM workloads vSAN-backed storage
VCF-managed domains It is not: A Kubernetes-native backup system A replacement for application-level backups A secrets-or-identity-recovery tool ^ all these remain separate concerns.You can think of VCF as enforcing invariants: “Workloads must be recoverable within defined SLOs.” VMware Live Recovery is the enforcement mechanism for the resilience invariant: If a site fails → recover If data is corrupted → rewind safely If ransomware hits → recover clean, fast, and confidently VLR is
Not vMotion
Not VCF Operations HCX Not a backup product Not a Kubernetes-native DR Those solve mobility or data protection, not platform-level resilience orchestration. VMware Live Recovery is VCF’s unified DR + cyber-recovery platform Designed for low RPO, fast RTO, and clean recovery Successor mindset to SRM, built for ransomware-era threats Operates at the VCF Operations layer, not the hypervisor Focused on VM workloads, not containers or apps directly
VCF Day 0 Tasks, VCF Day 1 Tasks, or VCF Day 2 Tasks could be nice places to visit from here.

headers.heading: Where Does It Sit in the VCF Stack

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Workload Mobility and Resilience/VMware Live Recovery.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/vcf-op.title: VCF Operations
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/vcf-op.description:
#tenancy
VCF Operations helps your organization build, manage, operate and secure your private cloud infrastructure by deploying and maintaining its fleet-level components, providing visibility and enhanced performance across the workload and infrastructure stack, and helping your organization stay compliant with regulatory standards and organizational guidelines.VCF Operations has these functional areas:
Fleet Management Enables operational consistency and efficient resource management of the VCF infrastructure at scale.
Operations Management Provides monitoring and optimization of performance, cost and capacity, and faster troubleshooting.
Workload Operations  Ensures that critical applications are running as expected.
Performance Monitoring Ensures applications have continuous access to resources
FinOps and Capacity Helps you analyze your infrastructure expenses and optimize capacity usage.
VCF Operations HCX Provides support for migrating and interconnecting workloads within and across VCF private cloud.
Security Management Provides security management to ensure that your VCF private cloud is operationally secure. VCF Operations does not: Own tenancy boundaries Gate workload creation Enforce business approval flows Define org/project constructs Those remain in:
VCF Automation
Supervisor Upstream automation layers VCF Operations observes those constructs after the fact.Day 0 / Day 1 → VCF-A - Who can create? - What can be created? - Under what policies? Day 2 → VCF-O - Is it healthy? - Is it over/under-utilized? - Is it behaving strangely? Here is a very high-level look at VCF’s control plane:VCF (the platform) ├── VCF Automation (formerly Aria Automation) ├── VCF Operations (formerly Aria Operations) ├── Supervisor / vSphere └── Workloads Here is how things looks from each layer’s point of view:
Once a workload cluster is instantiated in a Supervisor Namespace, it has no awareness of VCF Automation constructs such as Organization or Project—Those concepts exist only at the governance layer (VCF Automation) and are not part of the runtime execution model (Supervisor).
You might want to check out Operations Management, Performance Monitoring, or Workload Operations.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/vcf-op.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/object-model/nsx-s.title: NSX Segment
vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/object-model/nsx-s.description: An NSX Segment is a logical Layer-2 network in VMware NSX. It is where workloads (VMs, containers) attach their NICs, just like plugging into a virtual switch—except it’s policy-driven, distributed, and decoupled from physical VLANs.VCF ├── vSphere (compute) │ └── VMs / Pods │ └── vNIC │ └── NSX Segment (L2) │ └── Tier-1 Gateway (L3, optional) │ └── Tier-0 Gateway → Physical network └── NSX Manager (policy & control) Defined in: NSX Manager Enforced on: ESXi hosts (distributed dataplane) Consumes: Overlay networking (GENEVE) Provides L2 connectivity between attached workloads Enables east–west traffic within the segment Acts as the policy anchor for: Distributed Firewall (DFW) DHCP (optional) MAC/IP learning & isolation Think of it as: “A virtual Ethernet network with cloud-native policy.” Segments remove VLAN sprawl and enable fine-grained security. Pure L2 broadcast domain No routing out Common for isolated tiers L3 routing enabled North–south possible via Tier-0 Most common in VCF DFW rules are applied to vNICs on segments Security is identity- and policy-based, not subnet-based Zero-trust patterns become practical The segment is not the security boundary — the workload is. In VCF: Segments are first-class networking objects Used by: VM workloads Kubernetes (via NSX CNI) Automation blueprints Lifecycle managed and validated by VCF You don’t hand-craft switch configs; you declare intent.If vSphere Port Group is: “A virtual switch tied to a VLAN” Then NSX Segment is: “A logical network with built-in policy, security, and mobility” ❌ Not a physical network ❌ Not a tenant boundary ❌ Not a router ❌ Not Kubernetes-specific (but integrates cleanly) NSX Segment = logical L2 network Attaches workloads and anchors security policy Decoupled from physical VLANs Foundational to zero-trust networking in VCF If you want, next we can go one level deeper into Segment → Tier-1 → Tier-0 traffic flow, or compare NSX Segment vs vSphere Port Group side-by-side with concrete packet paths.

headers.heading: Where an NSX Segment sits in the stack
What an NSX Segment actually does
2. Segment attached to a Tier-1 Gateway
NSX Segment vs related constructs (avoid confusion)

vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/object-model/nsx-s.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx.html.title: NSX
vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx.html.description:
#tenancyNSX enables network connectivity, operations, and scale. It uses a software-defined approach to networking that spans data centers, clouds and application frameworks.NSX abstracts network services from the underlying hardware, enabling programmable infrastructure through APIs. You can implement policies and workflows to automate tasks like network provisioning, security enforcement, load balancing, streamlining operations, and improving efficiency.NSX provides a complete set of logical networking capabilities and services, including logical switching, routing, distributed load balancing, virtual private network (VPN), quality of service (QoS), and monitoring.Enable logical Layer 2 overlay extensions across a routed (Layer 3) fabric within and across data center boundaries.Dynamic routing between virtual networks that is performed in a distributed manner in the hypervisor kernel, and scale-out routing with active-active failover with physical routers. Static routing and dynamic routing protocols are supported, including support for IPv6.Complete data plane isolation among tenants with a separate routing table, network address translation (NAT), and edge firewall support in each VRF on the Support for bridging between VLANs configured on the physical network and NSX overlay networks, for seamless connectivity between virtual and physical workloads.Site-to-site and unmanaged VPN for cloud gateway services.By using NSX, you can move workloads between racks and data centers by decoupling them from the underlying networks.Centralized policy configuration and enforcement across multiple locations from a single pane of glass, enabling network-wide consistent policy, operational simplicity, and simplified disaster recovery architecture.Enable consistent networking and security across data center sites, and across private cloud boundaries, irrespective of underlying physical topology or cloud platform.NSX can manage the provisioning, deployment, operations and retirement of networking infrastructure and applications from a central control pane.
You can automate infrastructure operations and offload manual tasks with workflows and agile templating using tools such as VCF Automation, Terraform, and Ansible. 
VPCs provide isolated network environments within a shared infrastructure. You can use Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) constructs to provision and manage network resources to business units or project teams independently, with granular control over networking policies and resource allocation.
You might want to check out NSX Segment for a more technical overview about NSX internal, or look at NSX Manager, or NSX Edge Cluster.
#tenancy

headers.heading: Layer 2–Layer 7 Network Stack and Overlay Services
Self-Service Networking with VPCs and Multi-Tenancy

vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx.html.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx-edge-cluster.h.title: NSX Edge Cluster
vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx-edge-cluster.h.description: An NSX Edge Cluster is a pool of dedicated NSX Edge Nodes that handle north–south traffic and advanced network services (routing, NAT, load balancing, VPN, firewall at the perimeter).It is part of VMware NSX, not vSphere. North–south routing Tier-0 Gateways (uplink to physical network) Tier-1 Gateways (tenant / app routing) Perimeter services NAT L4–L7 Load Balancing VPN (IPsec, L2VPN) Gateway firewalling High throughput datapath Optimized for packet forwarding Separate from ESXi host dataplane ❌ It does not run workloads ❌ It does not manage policy (that’s NSX Manager) ❌ It does not replace distributed firewall (DFW) VCF ├── vSphere Cluster (compute) │ └── Workload VMs │ └── East–West traffic (DFW on ESXi) │ ├── NSX Edge Cluster │ └── North–South traffic │ ├── Tier-0 Gateway │ └── Services (NAT, LB, VPN) │ └── NSX Manager └── Policy & control plane A clean rule of thumb: ESXi hosts = east–west NSX Edge nodes = north–south Edge nodes are deployed as VMs Grouped into Edge Clusters Services can be: Active/Active (ECMP) Active/Standby Protected by vSphere HA Scaled horizontally by adding Edge Nodes No — vSphere itself does not have an edge concept.But the confusion is understandable.Classic vSphere had: vSwitch / vDS Physical routers & firewalls outside vSphere No virtual routing tier. No virtual perimeter. No “edge” construct.Earlier NSX versions (NSX-V era) had a product literally called: NSX Edge Services Gateway People shortened this to “the edge”, and the name stuck.But it was always NSX, never vSphere.Today: NSX Edge Node NSX Edge Cluster Tier-0 / Tier-1 Gateways Still not vSphere-native.There is no vSphere Edge Node equivalent. vSphere: compute scheduling & virtualization NSX: software-defined networking NSX Edge: virtual perimeter routers & services VCF: opinionated lifecycle glue tying them together If you remove NSX: vSphere has no edge Networking reverts to physical devices NSX Edge Cluster = NSX’s north–south dataplane It handles routing, NAT, LB, VPN, perimeter firewalling vSphere never had an edge concept The term “edge” is historical NSX vocabulary, not vSphere In VCF, Edge Clusters are foundational for routed, multi-tenant designs If you want next, we can go one level deeper into: Tier-0 vs Tier-1 gateways Edge vs DFW responsibilities Why Edges must be isolated from compute clusters Those distinctions matter a lot in real VCF architecture discussions.

headers.heading: NSX Edge Cluster — and did vSphere ever have an “edge” concept?
NSX Edge Cluster in VMware Cloud Foundation
What an NSX Edge Cluster actually does
Where NSX Edge fits in the stack
What vSphere does have that people mislabel as “edge”

vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx-edge-cluster.h.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx-manager.html.title: NSX Manager
vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx-manager.html.description: NSX Manager is the central management and control plane for VMware NSX. It defines, stores, and enforces software-defined networking and security policy (switching, routing, firewalling) across the VCF environment.In VCF, NSX Manager is mandatory wherever NSX is used and is deployed and lifecycle-managed by VCF.VMware Cloud Foundation ├── Management Domain │ └── NSX Manager (3-node cluster) │ └── Workload Domains └── NSX Data Plane (transport nodes) Role: Management & policy authority Not a data-path component Consumes: vCenter inventory, clusters, hosts Policy management Segments (logical networks) Tier-0 / Tier-1 gateways (routing) Distributed Firewall (DFW) rules Control-plane orchestration Pushes intent to hosts and edges Inventory & topology Knows which workloads live where API & UI Single source of truth for NSX state Think of it as the “brain” of NSX.If NSX Manager goes down: Existing traffic continues No new changes can be made until it returns NSX Manager is typically deployed as: 3-node cluster Quorum-based Protected by vSphere HA Loss of one node → no impact Loss of quorum → management freeze, not traffic lossVCF: Deploys NSX Manager automatically Enforces supported topologies Handles upgrades, certificates, backups Assumes NSX Manager is always present You don’t “wing it” with NSX Manager in VCF. ❌ Not a router forwarding packets ❌ Not a firewall datapath ❌ Not optional in NSX-based VCF designs ❌ Not workload-aware beyond policy intent If vCenter is: “What compute exists and where?” Then NSX Manager is: “How workloads may talk to each other — and who is allowed.” NSX Manager is the control plane of NSX It defines networking and security intent Traffic keeps flowing without it, but change stops In VCF, it is foundational and non-optional when NSX is used If you want, next we can zoom in on NSX Edge vs DFW, or explain Tier-0 / Tier-1 gateways in the same concise mental-model style.

headers.heading: Where NSX Manager sits in the VCF stack
NSX Manager vs other NSX components (clean separation)

vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx-manager.html.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/cns.html.title: CNS
vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/cns.html.description:
CNS (Cloud Native Storage) is the vSphere capability that makes Kubernetes storage first-class and lifecycle-aware.
It bridges Kubernetes PersistentVolumes with vSphere storage (typically vSAN) so that Kubernetes, not admins, drives volume lifecycle, while vSphere retains visibility, Policy, and Governance.
VCF relies on CNS wherever Kubernetes (Supervisor or guest clusters) consumes vSphere storage.VCF ├── vSphere │ ├── vCenter Server │ │ └── CNS (storage awareness & lifecycle) │ ├── vSAN / VMFS / NFS │ └── ESXi │ └── Kubernetes ├── Supervisor Cluster └── Guest Clusters (TKG) └── PVC → PV → vSphere Volume Implemented by: VMware vSphere Integrated via: vSphere CSI Driver Observed/managed in: VMware vCenter Server Without CNS: Kubernetes creates volumes vSphere sees “random disks” No linkage, no lifecycle alignment With CNS: Kubernetes objects ↔ vSphere volumes are linked vSphere understands which PVC belongs to which pod Storage policy, health, and cleanup are automatic CNS makes Kubernetes storage visible, governable, and safe in vSphere. Lifecycle mapping PVC create/delete ↔ vSphere volume create/delete Topology awareness Knows which cluster, namespace, pod owns a volume Policy enforcement Applies vSphere Storage Policies (SPBM) Operational visibility Shows Kubernetes volumes in vCenter UI & APIs Kubernetes creates a PVC CSI driver requests a volume vSphere provisions storage (often vSAN) CNS records: Kubernetes metadata Volume ownership On PVC delete → CNS ensures correct cleanup Kubernetes stays declarative; vSphere stays authoritative. CNS is always on StorageClasses map directly to vSphere policies CNS operates via CSI Still centrally visible in vCenter Same mechanism, different consumption layers. ❌ Not a storage array ❌ Not a CSI driver itself ❌ Not Kubernetes-only ❌ Not a replacement for vSAN CNS is the glue, not the storage.If CSI is: “The driver that talks to storage” Then CNS is: “The brain that understands Kubernetes intent inside vSphere” Enables policy-driven storage for containers Prevents orphaned volumes Makes Kubernetes operationally sane for infra teams Required for supported VCF Kubernetes designs CNS = Cloud Native Storage awareness in vSphere Aligns Kubernetes volume lifecycle with vSphere Essential for Supervisor & TKG clusters in VCF Turns storage into a first-class Kubernetes citizen If you want next, we can connect this to StorageClasses → vSphere Storage Policies, or contrast CNS vs in-guest CSI on raw VMs—both are common points of confusion.

headers.heading: Where CNS sits in the VCF stack
CNS vs traditional VM storage (important contrast)

vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/cns.html.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/vds.html.title: VDS
vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/vds.html.description: A VDS (vSphere Distributed Switch) is a cluster-wide virtual switch that provides consistent networking configuration across all ESXi hosts. It centralizes network policy (port groups, uplinks, security, QoS) instead of configuring each host individually.VCF standardizes on VDS as the baseline virtual networking fabric.VMware Cloud Foundation └── vSphere └── vCenter Server └── vSphere Distributed Switch (VDS) ├── ESXi Host A ├── ESXi Host B └── ESXi Host C └── Port Groups → VM vNICs Implemented by: VMware vSphere Managed in: VMware vCenter Server Used by: ESXi hosts, VMs, NSX transport nodes Centralized L2 switching Consistent port group configuration NIC teaming & uplinks Traffic shaping, security, VLAN tagging Host lifecycle safety (no per-host drift) Think of it as: “One virtual switch, shared by the whole cluster.” VCF requires VDS because automation and upgrades depend on consistency.A Distributed Port Group defines: VLAN ID(s) Security policies (promiscuous mode, MAC changes) Traffic shaping Teaming / failover VM vNICs attach to port groups, not directly to the switch.This is where confusion often arises. VDS = underlay L2 switch NSX = overlay networking NSX creates overlay segments Overlay traffic is encapsulated (GENEVE) Encapsulated packets ride over VDS uplinks NSX does not replace VDS — it depends on it. In VCF: Management Domain has a predefined VDS Workload Domains get their own VDS NSX transport zones bind to VDS uplinks Lifecycle (patching, expansion) assumes VDS presence You rarely “design” VDS in VCF — it’s opinionated and enforced. ❌ Not a router (no L3) ❌ Not an NSX Segment ❌ Not a tenant boundary ❌ Not optional in VCF If VDS is: “A shared Ethernet switch for ESXi hosts” Then NSX Segment is: “A logical network built on top of that switch.” Different layers, different jobs. VDS is the foundational virtual switch in VCF Provides centralized, cluster-wide L2 networking Required for NSX and VCF lifecycle operations NSX overlays run on top of VDS, not instead of it If you want, next we can explicitly trace a packet: VM vNIC → NSX Segment → VDS → NSX Edge → Physical network That walkthrough usually locks the mental model in place.

headers.heading: VDS (vSphere Distributed Switch) in VMware Cloud Foundation
Where VDS sits in the VCF stack
VDS vs Standard vSwitch (why VDS exists)

vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/vds.html.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/vsan.html.title: vSAN
vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/vsan.html.description:
vSAN aggregates local or direct-attached capacity devices of all ESX hosts in a cluster and creates a single storage pool shared across all ESX hosts in the  vSAN cluster.Use **vSAN** as a VI administrator or storage administrator to enhance storage performance by aggregating local storage into a single shared pool across all hosts in a vSAN cluster.
You can use vSphere features that require shared storage, such as vSphere HA, vSphere vMotion, and vSphere DRS, without the need for external shared storage.vSAN provides operational consistency from edge to cloud, with complete visibility and lifecycle management of compute and storage from a single UI.You can perform consistent, VM-centric operations by using policy-based management. Within the vSAN ESA, per-VM policies increase flexibility of management, enabling compression policies, or customize data services on a per-VM basis.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/vsan.html.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/access-and-int.title: vSphere Client
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/access-and-int.description:
vSphere Client is: A web UI (HTML / JS) Running inside either ESX (embedded) or vCenter Consuming backend APIs It consumes REST and legacy SOAP / internal APIs Functionally: It is an API consumer It behaves differently depending on where it is placed: Same UI codebase: Connected to ESX → host-scoped Connected to vCenter Server → environment-scoped The UI is not “smart”: The backend defines reality.
There is exactly ONE UI name (“vSphere Client”), but it can connect to TWO different backends.
vCenter Server
ESX Hosts ## Mode 1 Browser ↓ ESX Host ↓ Embedded vSphere Client ## Mode 2 Browser ↓ vCenter Server ↓ vSphere Client ↓ Many ESX hosts
You might want to check out vCenter Server, one of the core components that makes vSphere, vSphere.

headers.heading: One UI to Rule Them All

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/access-and-int.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.title: vSphere, ESX, and vCenter
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.description:
Saying “vSphere is ‘‘ESX and vCenter’’” is colloquially common, but technically incomplete.Because vSphere is a platform, it is NOT a single product.Or, to put more simply: There is nothing you can curl called vSphere; similar to there is nothing that you can curl called AWS or Azure.vSphere is VMware’s virtualization platform built on ESX hosts managed by vCenter Server, together providing cluster-level services such as HA, DRS, and Kubernetes integration.But still, that term is mostly, contextually “good enough” because, in practice: You never run production vSphere without vCenter ESX alone is just a hypervisor, not a platform; and it is very limited vCenter alone does nothing
vSphere includes:
ESX is the bare-metal hypervisor.
vCenter Server provides centralized management. Platform features:
vMotion (live VM migration)
HA / DRS
Resource Pools
Distributed Virtual Switches Storage policies
Fault Tolerance
You cannot have vSphere without ESX.
You can have ESX without vCenter (but it will be very limited).
For more information about what vSphere controls and manages, you might want to see vSphere Constructs and vSphere Cluster. After that, your next step could be to check out vSphere Supervisor and see how it enables declarative management of these constructs.
Exploring vSphere Constructs might be the next logical area to navigate from here.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.sourcePath: VCF/Core Runtimes/vSphere/Core Components/Component Relationships/vSphere, ESX, and vCenter.md

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.title: Distributed Virtual Switch
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.description:
In VMware Cloud Foundation, a Distributed Virtual Switch (DVS) is the standard, centralized virtual networking fabric used across ESX hosts in a Workload Domain.

In VCF, a Distributed Virtual Switch is the mandatory, centrally managed L2 networking fabric that ensures every ESX host behaves identically so that VCF Automation, lifecycle management, and NSX can work reliably at scale.DVS provides consistent networking configuration, policy enforcement, and operational control at scale—something VCF depends on to behave predictably.DVS can be seen as:
One logical network switch that spans many ESX hosts, configured once, and applied everywhere.
Instead of configuring networking host-by-host, you configure it centrally, and every participating ESX host follows that definition.VCF is opinionated and automated. Networking must be: Deterministic Centrally managed
Compatible with lifecycle automation Consistent across hosts and clusters That’s why VCF mandates DVS (not standard vSwitches) for system and workload networking.
ESX hosts do not own the switch config — vCenter does. VCF automation (bring-up, scaling, patching, upgrades) assumes:A standard vSwitch breaks all of this because it is host-local and imperative.Typical VCF DVS port groups include: Management
vMotion
vSAN
NSX Host TEPs VM networks (VLAN-backed)
Supervisor / Kubernetes traffic (when applicable) VCF may create multiple DVS instances, for example: One for system domain One per workload domain
DVS ≠ NSX DVS provides L2 switching NSX builds overlay networking (Geneve tunnels, logical segments) on top of DVS You can have:
DVS without NSX (VLAN-backed networking)
However, NSX requires DVS underneath So DVS is the foundational substrate, not the SDN layer. DVS is a control-plane object
ESX caches its config locally, but authority lives in vCenter If vCenter is temporarily unavailable Traffic keeps flowing You just can’t change switch config VCF LCM expects DVS invariants Port groups, uplinks, MTU, and teaming must match what SDDC Manager expects DVS is not optional in VCF It is owned by vCenter, not hosts It enables automation, scale, and consistency
NSX depends on it, but it is not NSX itself Standard vSwitches are fundamentally incompatible with VCF’s design goals
Diving into ESX might be the next logical step from here.

headers.heading: 2. How DVS fits into the VCF stack
4. What Runs on a DVS in VCF

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.title: ESX
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.description:
ESX is the virtualization platform where you create and run Virtual Machines and Virtual Appliances, Kubernetes workloads, and AI/ML Workloads.  ESX is a Type-1 (bare-metal) hypervisor Runs directly on hardware Owns: CPU scheduling Memory management Device virtualization Does not coordinate clusters by itself You can run standalone ESX without vCenter, but: No clustering
No HA
No DRS
No vMotion orchestration ESX is a hypervisor, it is not a traditional Linux OS.In ESX, there is no general-purpose userland like you’d expect in Linux or Windows.ESX is a purpose-built, bare-metal hypervisor operating system whose kernel (VMKernel) directly manages hardware resources and runs virtual machines.
Exploring the relationship between vSphere, ESX, and vCenter may clarify some of of the dangling question marks, if you have any.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.title: vCenter Server
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.description:
vCenter is the service through which you manage multiple hosts connected in a network pool host resources.vCenter Server runs as a Virtual Appliance (VCSA) — a prebuilt VM — on ESX.Concretely: vCenter is not bare metal It is deployed as an OVA That OVA becomes one VM (sometimes functionally “a group of services”, but still a single VM) Internally, that VM runs: A hardened Linux-based OS vCenter services Database (embedded or external, depending on scale) Physical hardware └── ESX └── vCenter Server Appliance (VM) └── vCenter services vCenter Server is the centralized control plane Manages:
ESX hosts
vSphere Clusters
Resource Pools Policies Orchestrates:
vMotion
DRS
HA Lifecycle

vCenter Server does not run workloads: it tells ESX what to do instead.vCenter Server
Connects many ESX hosts. Maintains inventory and state
Enforces cluster-level logic. Orchestrates features that require coordination.
vMotion between hosts
DRS placement decisions
Cluster HA
Supervisor Cluster (for Kubernetes / VCF) vCenter Server is a set of backend services: Inventory (hosts, clusters, VMs) State and configuration database
Scheduling logic (DRS)
HA coordination
vMotion orchestration RBAC, roles, permissions APIs (REST, SOAP)

See vSphere Client for how a UI is served around the vCenter capabilities.You might want to check:
VCSA, which is directly-related to vCenter,
or ESX, which is the Type-1 Hypervisor that everything runs on
or Distributed Virtual Switch, if you are in a networking mood.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.title: VCSA
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.description:
see also: Virtual Appliance
VCSA, is an acronym for “vCenter Server Appliance”
It is a Virtual Appliance for vCenter Server

In VCF, VCSA is the central control plane for vSphere infrastructure—the brain that manages ESX hosts and clusters across domains. VCSA = vCenter, packaged as a Linux appliance VCF uses VCSA everywhere to manage compute No VCSA → no usable vSphere → no VCF Think of VCF as an orchestration stack, and VCSA as the authoritative source of truth for the compute state.Inside VCF, VCSA is responsible for:
Manages ESX hosts Forms and manages vSphere clusters Enforces cluster features:
HA
DRS
vMotion
Resource Pools Everything “higher” in the stack talks to VCSA:
VCF Operations
VCF Automation
NSX (for host/cluster attachment)
vSphere Supervisor (Kubernetes-on-vSphere) If something needs to know “what hosts exist?” or “where does this VM live?”, it asks VCSA. Integrates with SSO / identity providers Issues and validates service identities Acts as a trust anchor for many workflows VCF is domain-based, and each domain has its own VCSA. Always present Contains: VCSA
NSX Manager
SDDC Manager Manages itself and workload domains Each workload domain has: Its own VCSA
Its own NSX Isolated lifecycle and fault domains This separation is deliberate: Different upgrade cadences Different blast radii Different tenants / purposes When someone says “VCF manages vSphere” what they actually mean is “VCF automates VCSA, which in turn manages ESX” The Supervisor Cluster runs on vSphere But: VCSA creates it VCSA owns its lifecycle VCSA exposes it via vSphere APIs Kubernetes is embedded into vSphere, but VCSA remains the authority.Without VCSA: No cluster No HA/DRS No Supervisor No VM lifecycle No policy enforcement VCF is powerful because it standardizes and automates many VCSAs, not because it replaces them. VCSA = vCenter, packaged as an appliance It is the compute control plane inside VCF Every domain has its own VCSA All higher-level VCF services depend on it VCF orchestrates VCSA; it does not replace it

headers.heading: 2. API surface for everything above it

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/c.title: DRS
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/c.description: DRS (Distributed Resource Scheduler) is the vSphere cluster service that continuously balances CPU and memory load by automatically placing and live-migrating VMs (via vMotion) across hosts.In VCF, DRS is foundational, not optional.VMware Cloud Foundation └── vSphere └── Cluster ├── HA → “Can the VM run?” └── DRS → “Where should it run?” Implemented by: VMware vSphere Executed via: VMware vCenter Server Acts on: VMs inside a cluster VCF assumes DRS is enabled and automated for predictable behavior. Initial Placement – chooses the best host when a VM powers on Continuous Balancing – monitors CPU & memory pressure Live Migration – moves VMs using vMotion Rule Enforcement – respects affinity / anti-affinity constraints If HA answers “Can the VM run?”, DRS answers “Where should the VM run right now?” VCF designs assume Fully Automated DRS.DRS continuously evaluates: Host CPU utilization Host memory pressure VM demand & entitlements Resource Pool shares & limits Affinity / anti-affinity rules When imbalance exceeds a threshold: → vMotion is triggered → No VM restartDRS is performance & fairness, not failure recovery.DRS can enforce rules such as: “These VMs must stay together” “These VMs must never share a host” Typical use cases: App + cache locality HA for clustered apps Licensing constraints ⚠️ Over-constraining rules reduces DRS effectiveness.DRS respects: Resource Pool shares Resource Pool reservations Resource Pool limits Meaning: DRS balances within the rules you define — it does not override governance. In VCF, clusters are typically:Cluster ├── HA: Enabled ├── DRS: Fully Automated ├── Admission Control: On └── vMotion: Required If DRS is disabled: Initial placement degrades Load hotspots form HA restarts may fail due to poor placement ❌ Not a tenant boundary ❌ Not a scaling mechanism ❌ Not application-aware ❌ Not Kubernetes scheduling DRS operates strictly at the VM + host layer.❌ Disabling DRS for “predictability” → Creates hotspots and manual ops❌ Overusing VM-Host affinity rules → Breaks automatic balancing❌ Expecting DRS to fix under-provisioning → It redistributes; it does not create capacity DRS is the brain of a vSphere cluster It continuously optimizes where VMs run VCF assumes DRS is enabled and automated HA + DRS together provide resilience + efficiency If you want, next we can stack these side-by-side as a HA vs DRS vs vMotion vs Admission Control matrix — that’s often the “aha” moment in VCF mental models.

headers.heading: DRS (Distributed Resource Scheduler) in VMware Cloud Foundation (VCF)
Where DRS lives in the VCF stack

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/c.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/c.title: Fault Tolerance
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/c.description: Fault Tolerance (FT) is a vSphere feature that provides zero-downtime protection for a single VM by running a lockstep secondary copy of that VM on another host. If the primary host fails, the secondary immediately takes over with no reboot and no data loss.VCF inherits FT from vSphere; it does not redefine it.VMware Cloud Foundation └── vSphere └── Cluster └── Fault Tolerance (per-VM feature) ├── Primary VM └── Secondary VM (lockstep) Implemented by: VMware vSphere Configured in: VMware vCenter Server Applies to: Individual VMs (opt-in) Executes the same CPU instructions on two VMs simultaneously Streams execution state over a dedicated FT logging network On host failure → instant switchover, no restart HA restarts VMs. FT never restarts them. FT is about continuity, not balancing or recovery speed.FT is powerful but expensive. Limited VM sizes (CPU / memory caps) No snapshots No suspend No Storage vMotion Requires identical CPU features across hosts Heavy network & CPU overhead Because of this, FT is typically reserved for: Legacy apps that cannot tolerate any downtime Single-instance workloads with no clustering option VCF environments usually prefer: HA + DRS for infrastructure resilience Application-level HA (clusters, replicas, quorum) Kubernetes controllers for pod-level restart Site-level DR for disasters FT remains available, but it is not a default design assumption in VCF. HA: “If the server crashes, reboot it elsewhere” DRS: “Move servers around to keep things fair” FT: “Run two brains in sync at all times” FT is like live brain mirroring — effective, but costly.❌ Using FT as a substitute for application HA ❌ Enabling FT broadly “just in case” ❌ Forgetting FT network requirements ❌ Expecting FT to scale like Kubernetes replicas FT provides true zero-downtime VM failover It is a vSphere feature, inherited by VCF High overhead and strict limits make it niche In modern VCF designs, FT is the exception, not the rule If you want, next we can compare FT vs app-level clustering vs Kubernetes replicas — that’s usually where architectural trade-offs become obvious.

headers.heading: Where FT lives in the VCF stack
FT vs HA vs DRS (the clean separation)
Why FT is rarely used in VCF
FT in a VCF world (practical reality)

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/c.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/c.title: HA
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/c.description: HA (High Availability) in VCF is the vSphere-native mechanism that automatically restarts workloads when a physical host fails.It is not a single VCF feature; rather, VCF relies on and standardizes HA across its managed infrastructure.HA is not invented by VCF. It comes from vSphere and is enforced consistently by VCF.VMware Cloud Foundation └── vSphere └── Cluster └── HA (enabled at cluster level) └── VM restart on host failure Implemented by: VMware vSphere Configured in: VMware vCenter Server Consumed by: All VMs running in VCF-managed clusters VCF ensures HA is correctly configured, validated, and lifecycle-managed as part of its opinionated design. Detect host failure → restart affected VMs on surviving hosts ESXi hosts exchange heartbeats A host stops responding Remaining hosts declare it failed vCenter selects new hosts VMs are restarted from disk ⚠️ Important: VMs are restarted, not live-migrated Physical ESXi host failure Power loss to a host PSOD / host crash Host isolation scenarios Guest OS crashes Application-level failures Storage corruption Network partition inside the VM Data loss between last write and crash HA answers “Is the VM running?”, not “Is the app healthy?”In VCF, every workload domain cluster is typically: HA-enabled DRS-enabled Validated against design rules Example:Workload Domain └── Cluster ├── HA: Enabled ├── DRS: Fully Automated └── Admission Control: Enabled VCF expects HA to be on; disabling it usually breaks design assumptions.HA includes Admission Control, which prevents you from powering on too many VMs.Purpose: Ensure enough spare capacity exists to restart VMs after a failure. If Admission Control says “no”: Nothing is broken You are overcommitted beyond your failure tolerance This is HA doing its job, not being restrictive.VCF HA is infrastructure HA, not cloud-native app HA.❌ Turning off HA to “fit more VMs” → Silent loss of failure guarantees❌ Expecting HA to replace app clustering → Wrong layer❌ Confusing HA with zero downtime → There is always a restart HA in VCF = vSphere HA, standardized and enforced It restarts VMs after host failure It does not provide zero-downtime or app-level resilience It is a non-optional baseline for VCF design assumptions If you want, next we can connect this to DRS, Admission Control math, or how HA interacts with Supervisor / Kubernetes workloads—those nuances matter a lot in VCF discussions.

headers.heading: Where HA lives in the VCF stack
What HA protects against (and what it does not)
HA vs related VCF concepts (very common confusion)
HA inside a VCF Workload Domain
HA vs Kubernetes-style HA (important mental shift)

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/c.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/i.title: Resource Pool
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/i.description: A Resource Pool in VCF is a vSphere construct that carves up CPU and memory capacity inside a cluster and applies governance controls (limits, reservations, shares) over how workloads consume those resources.VCF inherits Resource Pools from VMware vSphere; it does not redefine them.Think of VCF as layered plumbing:VMware Cloud Foundation └── vSphere (via vCenter) └── Cluster └── Resource Pool └── VM / vApp Owned by: vSphere Managed through: VMware vCenter Server Consumed by: VMs (and vApps), including those provisioned via VCF Automation VCF Automation may target a resource pool, but does not create a new abstraction here.A Resource Pool lets you govern contention, not create capacity. Resource Pools do not add resources — they only slice and prioritize what already exists in the cluster. Think of a cluster as a water tank: The tank size = physical host capacity Resource Pools = valves Shares = which valve opens wider under pressure Reservations = minimum guaranteed flow Limits = maximum allowed flow No matter how many valves you add, the tank size never changes.VCF itself does not require Resource Pools, but they are often used: To separate platform workloads from tenant workloads To protect management components from noisy neighbors To enforce guardrails in shared clusters Example:Cluster ├── Mgmt-RP (high shares, reservations) │ ├── vCenter │ ├── NSX Managers │ └── Tenant-RP ├── App-VMs ├── DB-VMs ❌ Overusing limits → Causes artificial throttling and unpredictable latency❌ Deeply nested pools → Shares become multiplicative and hard to reason about❌ Using pools as security boundaries → They are not isolation mechanisms ❌ Not a tenant boundary ❌ Not a billing unit ❌ Not a Kubernetes namespace ❌ Not a quota system (that’s layered above, e.g., VCF Automation) A Resource Pool is a vSphere scheduling construct, fully inherited by VCF It controls CPU & memory contention, not ownership or tenancy VCF Automation may reference it, but does not redefine it Use sparingly, with clear intent and shallow hierarchies If you want, next we can contrast Resource Pools vs Supervisor Namespaces vs VCF Automation quotas side-by-side — that’s where most architectural confusion usually shows up.

headers.heading: Where Resource Pools sit in the VCF stack
What a Resource Pool actually does
Resource Pools vs VCF concepts (common confusion)

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/i.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/i.title: vSphere Cluster
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/i.description:
see also: vCenter Server, ESX, Supervisor Cluster A vSphere Cluster (or Supervisor Cluster) is a logical grouping of ESX hosts that vCenter treats as a single resource pool and failure domain. It exists only in vCenter ESX hosts do not know they are “in a cluster”. When you create a cluster in vCenter Server, you are telling: “*These ESX hosts agree to be scheduled, balanced, and failed over together.”This enables cluster-level logic, such as DRS (Distributed Resource Scheduler): vCenter decides which host should run which VM. When to rebalance the load.
Uses vMotion to move VMs between hosts. HA (High Availability) Hosts run a lightweight HA agent. If a host dies: Other hosts detect it vCenter (or preconfigured HA logic) restarts VMs elsewhere. Shared resource abstraction Instead of thinking: Host A: 64 cores Host B: 64 cores vCenter presents Cluster: 128 cores VM placement and limits are logical, not physical.A vSphere Cluster is not:Because from an operator’s perspective: Hosts act like a pool Failures are absorbed Workloads move transparently But architecturally: The cluster is an illusion created by vCenter.
A vSphere cluster is a vCenter-defined scheduling and failure domain over multiple ESX hosts,[ Physical Servers ] ↓ ESX (many hosts) ↓ vCenter Server ↓ vSphere features & automation

headers.heading: Why VMware still calls it a “cluster”

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/i.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/o.title: vSphere Constructs
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/o.description:
see also: vCenter Server, ESX A vSphere Construct is: *A first-class infrastructure object that is _natively defined, owned, and enforced by the vSphere control plane (ESX + vCenter), not by Kubernetes or higher-level automation layers.
Think of it as a primitive in vSphere’s own vocabulary. These are things that exist because vSphere exists; they are not abstractions layered on top. Virtual Machine
vCPU
vNUMA
vApp
Resource Pool Shares / Limits / Reservations
DRS rules
HA Admission Control Datastore
vSAN Object
VM disk (VMDK) Storage Policy Port Group
Distributed Virtual Switch
VM NIC
VLAN / overlay constructs Snapshot Clone
vMotion Storage vMotion
HA restart
Fault Tolerance
All of these are authoritative in vSphere and enforced by:
ESX
and vCenter Server If you want to get closer to the metal, all of these are relevant areas to explore:
VM NIC
VMDK
vApp
vCPU
vNUMA
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/o.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.title: vApp
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.description:
A vApp is a logical container in VMware that groups multiple VMs into a single, manageable application unit with shared lifecycle, networking, and (optionally) resource policies.It is best thought of as “an application-shaped wrapper around several VMs.”A vApp is a construct in VMware that lets you manage a set of related VMs as one application, with coordinated startup order, shared networking, and optional resource controls.vApps live and are managed in vCenter Server.vApps were created to solve a very specific problem: “How do I deploy and operate a multi-VM application as a single unit?” Before Kubernetes, before Helm, before Operators—this was VMware’s answer.vApp: OnlineStore ├── Web VM ├── API VM └── Database VM You can: Power on/off the whole application Clone or export it Track it as a single object Critical feature.You can define: DB starts first App tier next Web tier last Reverse order on shutdown This was huge in pre-container days.Inside a vApp you can: Define isolated networks Connect VMs to internal-only networks Attach uplinks at the vApp boundary It is like a “mini datacenter boundary for this application”.vApps support: OVF / OVA packaging Application-level metadata Deployment parameters (IP, hostname, etc.) This made vApps attractive for: ISVs Appliances Repeatable deployments vApp is an organizational and orchestration construct, not a runtime.vApps were ahead of their time, but eventually outpaced by containers.vApps are still relevant in:
VMware Virtual Appliances (OVA-based) Legacy multi-VM apps Demo environments Lab setups But, they are rare in modern Cloud Native stacks: Kubernetes replaced the need
VCF Automation layers supersede it GitOps models don’t map cleanly
You might want to check out Inventory Objects such as Resource Pools or vSphere Clusters.

headers.heading: How vApps compare to Modern Constructs
Where vApps are still used today

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.title: vCPU
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.description:
In the context of vCenter Server, a vCPU (virtual CPU) is a logical processor that vCenter assigns to a Virtual Machine, abstracting and time-sharing the physical CPUs (pCPUs) of the underlying ESX hosts.You can think of it as CPU time and execution context, not a physical core.
A vCPU is a scheduling unit presented to a Virtual Machine, which the ESX scheduler maps onto physical CPU cores or hardware threads on demand.A VM with 4 vCPUs does not get 4 dedicated cores: It gets permission to run up to 4 execution threads concurrently when physical CPU time is available.A vCPU is not: a physical core pinned hardware (unless you explicitly do CPU pinning) a guaranteed slice of CPU time A vCPU is: a schedulable execution context
backed by ESX’s CPU scheduler mapped dynamically to cores or hyperthreads exposed to the guest OS as a CPU socket or core
ESX uses time-slicing + SMT awareness Multiple vCPUs can run on the same physical core at different times There is no 1:1 relationship unless: CPU affinity is configured (rare, advanced, some Telco use cases demand it) Real-time workloads are used vCenter itself does not execute workloads. It: Defines VM configuration (number of vCPUs) Enforces resource policies: CPU limits CPU reservations Shares
Coordinates placement decisions (DRS) Observes performance (CPU Ready, Co-Stop, etc.)
The actual execution and scheduling happens on ESX hosts.When you assign vCPUs, you also define topology: Sockets Cores per socket Example: 4 vCPUs as 1 socket × 4 cores or 2 sockets × 2 cores This affects: Guest OS licensing
NUMA behavior Cache locality Some applications (databases, especially)
vCenter Server lets you control this explicitly.Oversubscription is normal, expected, and intentional.In real environments: Physical cores: 32 Total vCPUs across VMs: 200+ This is normal.This will work because: Most VMs are idle most of the time
ESX schedules based on demand Problems only appear when too many vCPUs want to run at once CPU Ready Time is one of the key metrics here: vCPU wants to run but can’t get scheduled. Start small (1–2 vCPUs) Scale up, not down Avoid wide VMs unless needed Watch: CPU Ready Co-Stop (for multi-vCPU VMs) Prefer fewer vCPUs with higher utilization over many idle vCPUs vCPU = schedulable execution context, not a core
vCenter Server defines and governs, ESX executes and schedules Oversubscription is by design More vCPUs ≠ more performance Correct sizing matters more than raw allocation
You might want to check out Inventory Objects such as Resource Pools or vSphere Clusters.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.title: VM NIC
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.description:
“vmnic-net-diagram 1.png” could not be found.A VM NIC (often written vNIC) is a virtualized network adapter presented to a virtual machine by the hypervisor. From the guest OS’s point of view, it behaves like a physical Ethernet card; from the host’s point of view, it’s a software object that plugs into VMware’s virtual networking stack.Effectively, it is a software Ethernet card that lives inside the VM. Appears as a standard network adapter (e.g., Intel or VMware-branded) Has: A MAC address Link state (up/down) One or more IP addresses assigned by the guest OS Drivers inside the VM talk to it just like real hardware The vNIC is backed by VMware virtual networking It connects to: A vSwitch (Standard or Distributed) A Port Group Traffic is then forwarded to: Other VMs The host The physical network via uplinks (pNICs) VMware supports multiple vNIC “models,” each with different tradeoffs:A typical path looks like this:[ VM ] | [vNIC] | [Port Group] | [vSwitch (VSS or VDS)] | [pNIC / Uplink] | [Physical Network] Port Group defines policies (VLAN, security, shaping) vSwitch is the virtual L2 switch pNICs are the host’s physical NICs Multiple vNICs per VM Separate traffic (management, data, backup)
SR-IOV VM bypasses vSwitch and talks almost directly to hardware Very high performance, less flexibility Traffic Shaping and Security Promiscuous mode MAC changes Forged transmits A VM NIC (vNIC) is a virtual Ethernet adapter attached to a VM It connects the VM to VMware’s virtual networking stack VMXNET3 is the modern, high-performance choice Networking is enforced through port groups and vSwitches Multiple vNICs, policies, and offloads make it far more flexible than physical NICs
You might want to check out Inventory Objects such as Resource Pools or vSphere Clusters.

headers.heading: VM NIC (Virtual Machine Network Interface Card) in VMware virtualization
Common VM NIC types in VMware
How a VM NIC connects to the Network

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.sourcePath: VCF/Core Runtimes/vSphere/Object Model/Virtual Machine Primitives/VM NIC.md

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.title: VMDK
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.description:
In VMware virtualization, VMDK stands for Virtual Machine Disk. It is the file format used by VMware to represent a virtual hard disk—the persistent storage attached to a virtual machine.A VMDK file behaves like a physical hard drive, but for a VM. From the guest OS point of view, it looks like /dev/sda, C:\, etc. From the ESX’s point of view, it’s one or more files on a datastore.VMDKs are stored on VMware datastores, which may be backed by: VMFS (block storage) NFS
vSAN Local disks Object storage (via vSAN ESA / integrations) A “VMDK” is usually not a single file: Ends in .vmdk Contains metadata: Disk size Geometry Provisioning type Backing extent file name Examples: disk-flat.vmdk disk-s001.vmdk, disk-s002.vmdk Holds the actual data blocks Snapshots and special configurations add more files.In the VMware ecosystem:
ESX handles block I/O VMDK is the disk abstraction
vCenter Server manages lifecycle Storage Policy Based Management (SPBM) governs behavior
All of this is orchestrated under VMware Cloud Foundation.
You might want to check out Inventory Objects such as Resource Pools or vSphere Clusters.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.title: vNUMA
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.description:
Let’s start with physical NUMA.NUMA stands for non-uniform memory accessNUMA is a physical server architecture used by modern multi-socket systems. Each CPU socket has: Its own local memory Faster access to that local memory Accessing memory attached to another socket is slower non-uniform here does not mean “processes access memory unevenly”; it is from a hardware perspective, and simply means “memory access latency is not the same for all memory locations”Hence: Memory access time is not uniformYou can think of it as: Two cities (CPU sockets) Each city has its own warehouse (memory) Shipping inside the city is fast Shipping between cities takes longer NUMA provides massive performance gain if locality is respected.Assume there is a workload that: Runs on CPU-0 But frequently accesses memory on CPU-1 Then, performance will drop due to latency and cache penalties. This is invisible at the OS level unless NUMA-aware.In a NUMA-aware system, CPU threads are scheduled to prefer running on CPUs that are near the memory they already use, not the other way around. All DRAM is: Equidistant (or close enough) Reached through a shared memory controller or fabric Differences exist, but: They are not tied to CPU identity They are mostly hidden from software Software does not (and cannot) reason about “which CPU core owns which memory” From the OS perspective: “Memory is one big pool” Latency variance exists, but not topologically anchored. In contrast, in NUMA, each CPU socket has its own local memory controller and DRAM; remote memory is reached via an interconnect and is slower.vNUMA is how a hypervisor exposes NUMA topology to a VM. The VM sees virtual NUMA nodes Each vNUMA node has: vCPUs Assigned memory Guest OS can schedule intelligently inside the VM vNUMA is NUMA-awareness for virtual machinesWithout vNUMA: Guest OS thinks memory is uniform Hypervisor silently shuffles memory Cache locality is lost With vNUMA: Guest OS: Allocates memory locally Schedules threads close to memory Databases, JVMs, etc., perform much better Tangential (but not directly-related-to) NUMA is SR-IOV.
SR-IOV allows one physical PCIe device (NIC, GPU, HBA) to present: One Physical Function (PF) Multiple Virtual Functions (VFs) The number of VFs an SR-IOV-enabled device can expose is fundamentally limited by the device’s hardware design, firmware, and onboard resources.SR-IOV devices expose a capability like:Total VFs supported: NThis value is: Burned into silicon Sometimes further capped by firmware Sometimes configurable downward (but not upward) Typical real-world numbers: 8 16 32 64 128 (High-end SmartNICs may go higher) You cannot exceed this, no matter what the OS or hypervisor wants.Each VF: Can be assigned directly to a VM Bypasses the hypervisor datapath When a VF is assigned: The VF is bound to the VM The VM sees it as a native PCIe device The guest driver talks directly to hardware Packets do not traverse: vSwitch vNIC vDS software datapaths
ESX does not schedule or inspect traffic This is why SR-IOV delivers: Near bare-metal latency Deterministic throughput Minimal jitter
vMotion flexibility (often) Snapshot support (often) Hypervisor mediation Some observability They solve different problems:An SR-IOV VF is physically attached to: A PCIe root complex Which belongs to one NUMA node If: VM vCPUs run on NUMA node 0 SR-IOV NIC VF is on NUMA node 1 You now have remote memory + remote I/O: Worst-case latency scenario.This is critical for performance workloads.When using SR-IOV: Align: VM vCPUs VM memory PCIe device To the same NUMA node This may require: NUMA-aware placement Host pinning Careful cluster design
You might want to check out Inventory Objects such as Resource Pools or vSphere Clusters.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: vSphere Trust Authority
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description: vSphere Trust Authority (vTA) is a hardware-rooted security feature that separates “who can decrypt and attest” from “who runs the workload.” It uses trusted execution and attestation so that even infrastructure administrators cannot access protected secrets or plaintext data.In VCF, vTA is an optional, high-assurance security capability, not a default baseline.VMware Cloud Foundation ├── Trust Authority Cluster (isolated) │ ├── Key Provider / Attestation Services │ └── Hardware-backed trust (TPM, TEE) │ └── Workload Domains └── Protected VMs / workloads Implemented by: VMware vSphere Integrated with: Key Management Interoperability Protocol providers Managed through: VMware vCenter Server Classic virtualization problem: Infrastructure admins can ultimately see everything. vTA introduces cryptographic separation of duties: Infra admins manage hosts and clusters They do NOT control keys Decryption happens only after hardware attestation This matters in: Regulated environments Confidential computing Insider-threat models Sovereign cloud designs Trust Authority Cluster boots with TPM-backed identity Hosts and workloads are attested Only if attestation passes: Encryption keys are released Protected workloads decrypt and run If trust breaks: Keys are withheld Workloads remain encrypted / suspended Access to infrastructure ≠ access to data Separate ESXi cluster Minimal admin surface Hosts key & attestation services Uses CPU security features (e.g., SEV, TDX) Prevents memory inspection Keys never live with workload admins Often backed by HSMs vTA is the strongest isolation boundary in vSphere.Typical usage: Confidential VMs Telco & financial workloads Government / sovereign clouds Typical non-usage: General enterprise clusters Cost-sensitive environments Dev/Test It is deliberately heavyweight.Think of vTA as: “Even if someone owns the data center, they still cannot read the data.” It is zero-trust applied to virtualization itself. ❌ Not a secrets manager ❌ Not an identity provider ❌ Not Kubernetes confidential computing (though complementary) ❌ Not required for VCF Strongest insider-threat protection Hardware-rooted trust Clear separation of duties Additional clusters & hardware Operational complexity Limited workload compatibility vSphere Trust Authority brings confidential computing to VCF It cryptographically separates infra admins from data access Optional, niche, but extremely powerful Used when “root access is not enough” must be enforced If you want, we can next connect this to confidential VMs, TPM attestation flows, or how vTA compares to cloud-provider confidential computing (AWS Nitro / Azure CVMs).

headers.heading: vSphere Trust Authority (vTA) in VMware Cloud Foundation
Where vTA lives in the VCF stack
vTA vs related VCF security features

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.sourcePath: VCF/Core Runtimes/vSphere/Platform Extensions/Security Services/vSphere Trust Authority.md

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Supervisor and Supervisor Cluster
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
A mode / capability of a vSphere cluster
Means: “This vSphere cluster has Kubernetes enabled and is running the Supervisor control plane” or less wordy: “*a vSphere cluster with Supervisor enabled”. Not a physical thing by itself
Think of it as a feature flag + control plane. A vSphere cluster with Supervisor enabled
A concrete, addressable object: ESXi hosts
vCenter-managed cluster
Supervisor control plane VMs This is what you actually connect to with kubectl
In practice, people often say:
“deploy this on Supervisor”
“connect to the Supervisor”
“namespace on Supervisor”
What they mean is: “the Kubernetes API exposed by the Supervisor-enabled vSphere cluster”
So colloquially: Supervisor ≈ Supervisor Cluster
But technically:
Supervisor = the Kubernetes capability
Supervisor Cluster = the vSphere cluster running it
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.sourcePath: VCF/Core Runtimes/vSphere/Platform Extensions/vSphere Supervisor/Architecture and Core Concepts/Supervisor and Supervisor Cluster.md

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: VM Workload and Pod Workload
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
In VCF, a workload is: A unit of compute that consumes CPU, memory, storage, and networking, and is subject to lifecycle, policy, and governance. VCF doesn’t care what the workload is at a philosophical level. It cares about: How it is instantiated How it is isolated How it is scheduled How it is governed Which control plane owns it one machine per workloadA VM workload is a traditional virtual machine: Runs on ESX Has its own guest OS Is managed by vCenter Uses vSphere Constructss directly
vCenter Server is the authoritative control plane VCF Automation wraps vCenter, but does not replace it CPU / memory allocated per VM Strong isolation via hypervisor boundaries Overcommitment controlled at ESX level Create VM Power on/off Snapshot Clone Patch guest OS Backup VM image VM policies Placement rules Affinity / anti-affinity HA / DRS Backup & DR policies many disposable units forming a service.A pod workload is a Kubernetes Pod running on the vSphere Supervisor Cluster.A pod on the vSphere Supervisor Cluster is not a traditional Kubernetes pod. It is a vSphere Pod — Kubernetes-shaped, but vSphere-implemented.Key point: A pod workload is not a VM pretending to be a container. Supervisor pods are VMs implementing container semantics, not containers implemented as VMs. A Supervisor pod is a Kubernetes Pod whose execution unit is a micro-VM, where the VM boundary replaces the Linux container boundary. The VM is the isolation primitive The Pod is the semantic primitive The container image is payload, not a process model So the VM is not “pretending to be a container” — it is implementing the Pod abstraction using a VM instead of a process. Pod (Kubernetes API object) └─ Backed by └─ Ultra-lightweight VM └─ ESX └─ Hardware It is: A Kubernetes-native unit Scheduled by Kubernetes Governed by Kubernetes APIs Backed by vSphere under the hood Kubernetes API (Supervisor cluster) is authoritative vCenter supplies infrastructure, not lifecycle semantics VCF Automation governs Kubernetes intent, not individual pods CPU / memory requested via Kubernetes requests & limits Scheduler decides placement Isolation via: Namespaces RBAC Pod security (Optionally) VM-backed pod runtimes Declarative (YAML) Reconciliation-based Pods are ephemeral Restart ≠ failure Replacement is normal Namespace-level quotas Admission control Image policies Network policies VM workloads → legacy, stateful, pet-like systems Pod workloads → cloud-native, stateless, cattle-like systems VCF’s value is: Running both on the same physical infrastructure, with unified policy and automation, without forcing one model onto the other. Trying to manage pods like VMs breaks Kubernetes. Trying to manage VMs like pods breaks operational reality.VCF keeps them separate but coordinated.
A pod workload in VCF is a Kubernetes-native execution unit scheduled and governed by the vSphere Supervisor Kubernetes control plane, consuming vSphere resources indirectly through Kubernetes abstractions—unlike a VM workload, which is a hypervisor-managed, OS-bearing unit directly governed by vCenter. “Pod workload” ≠ “small VM” Pod workloads are Kubernetes-first, not vSphere-first VMs are stateful machines Pods are replaceable execution instances VCF supports both because enterprises need both
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.sourcePath: VCF/Core Runtimes/vSphere/Platform Extensions/vSphere Supervisor/Architecture and Core Concepts/VM Workload and Pod Workload.md

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: vSphere Pod
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
A vSphere Pod is a Kubernetes Pod whose sandbox runs inside a lightweight VM (via ESX]), not inside a container runtime on a shared Linux node.
#todo TODO:// if this is a Pod Workload merge it, or the other one to this. So: API semantics → Kubernetes Runtime semantics → vSphere / VM Traditional Kubernetes Pods: Share a Linux kernel Rely on namespaces + cgroups Are fast and efficient But have weaker isolation (from a hypervisor POV) vSphere Pods were created to: Give VM-grade isolation While keeping Pod-level developer UX For multi-tenant / regulated environments This matters a lot for: Service providers Telco Regulated enterprise workloads “Pods from different customers must never share a kernel” Regular Kubernetes:Node (Linux) └── kubelet ├── Pod A ├── Pod B └── Pod C vSphere Pods:ESXi ├── Pod-VM A ├── Pod-VM B └── Pod-VM C No shared container runtime No shared kubelet per “node” Each pod is scheduled directly by vSphere Kubernetes still thinks it’s scheduling Pods — but vSphere translates that into VM placement.So in vSphereland, “One Pod ~= Tiny VM”


Kubernetes: Decides which pod should run vSphere: Decides where the pod-VM runs Enforces CPU, memory, NUMA, HA, DRS This is what “Kubernetes-native mode” really looks like under the hood. From the Pod’s perspective: It has an IP It mounts volumes It exposes ports Under the hood: Networking is NSX-backed Storage is datastore-policy-backe Attach/detach happens at VM granularity Again: Pod UX, VM machinery. Despite the VM runtime, vSphere Pods still use: Pod specs Containers Init containers ConfigMaps Volume mounts Pod lifecycle (create/delete/restart) Kubernetes Services (with some constraints) So developers mostly don’t care—and that is by design. Regular Pod → process in a shared OS vSphere Pod → process in its own micro-VM Or: Regular K8s → Linux container model vSphere Pods → “micro-VM container” model Essentially: vSphere Pods are not regular Kubernetes Pods They are Pod-shaped workloads backed by per-Pod VMs Kubernetes API semantics remain intact Runtime isolation is hypervisor-level This is intentional and central to Supervisor’s design

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: How Does vSphere Supervisor Change the vSphere Environment
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description: A Supervisor adds objects to the vCenter inventory, such as namespaces, vSphere Pods, and VKS clusters.Under each Supervisor, you can view: vSphere Namespaces  that represent logical applications running in the cluster. Resource pools for each  vSphere Namespace  on the  Supervisor . In a three-zone deployment, a resource pool for each  vSphere Namespace  is created on each cluster part of a zone. Within every namespace, you can view: vSphere Pods . vSphere Pods  of  Supervisor Services . VKS  clusters. Supervisor  control plane VMs and stand-alone VMs. Networking and storage resources. User permissions for that namespace.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Why Does Supervisor Exist
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description: Kubernetes didn’t replace VMs. It replaced application scheduling semantics.VMware’s bet was: "Instead of forcing Kubernetes to run on top of vSphere, we'll make Kubernetes a native execution mode of vSphere." Supervisor is that bet made concrete. vSphere = substrate Supervisor = Kubernetes-native personality of vSphere VCF Automation = enterprise automation layer on top vSphere Supervisor

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Adding Security Policies to a Supervisor Namespace
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
A Supervisor that uses NSX networking supports network security policies configured through a security policy CRD.Create a Security PolicyAs a DevOps, you can configure the security policy CRD to apply an NSX based security policy to a Supervisor namespace. The security policy protects traffic for vSphere Pods and VMs. VMs include VKS cluster nodes and other VMs deployed in the Supervisor.Use NSX version 3.2 or later. Create a security policy CRD. For the fields to use and CRD examples, see NSX Operator Security Policy CRD documentation on GitHub.
Access your namespace in the Kubernetes environment. See Connecting to Supervisor and VKS Clusters. Apply the security policy to the namespace. kubectl apply -f policy-name.yaml View your security policy. View details for the security policy. kubectl get securitypolicy policy-name View a description of your security policy. kubectl describe securitypolicy policy-name You can also use the NSX UI to view details of your policy. For information, see the VMware NSX Documentation page.
