vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Deploy a Confidential vSphere Pod
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description: ou can run confidential vSphere Pods on a Supervisor. A confidential vSphere Pod uses a hardware technology that keeps the guest OS memory encrypted, protecting it against access from the hypervisor.To enable SEV-ES on an ESX host, a vSphere administrator must follow these guidelines: Use the hosts that support the SEV-ES functionality. Use the  ESX  version of 7.0 Update 2 or later. Enable SEV-ES in an  ESX  system's BIOS configuration. See your system's documentation for more information about accessing the BIOS configuration. When enabling SEV-ES in the BIOS, enter a value for the  Minimum SEV non-ES ASID  setting equal the number of SEV-ES VMs and confidential  vSphere Pods  on the host plus one. For example, if you plan to run 100 SEV-ES VMs and 128  vSphere Pods , enter at least 229. You can enter a setting as high as 500. You can create confidential vSphere Pods by adding Secure Encrypted Virtualization-Encrypted State (SEV-ES) as an extra security enhancement. SEV-ES prevents CPU registers from leaking information in registers to components like the hypervisor. SEV-ES can also detect malicious modifications to a CPU register state. For more information about using SEV-ES technology in the vSphere environment, see Securing Virtual Machines with AMD Secure Encrypted Virtualization-Encrypted State in the vSphere Security documentation. Create a YAML file that contains the following parameters. In annotations, enable the confidential  vSphere Pods  feature. ... annotations: vmware/confidential-pod: enabled ... Specify memory resources for containers. Make sure to set memory requests and memory limits to the same value, as in this example. resources: requests: memory: "512Mi" limits: memory: "512Mi" Use the following YAML file as an example: apiVersion: v1 kind: Pod metadata: name: photon-pod namespace: my-podvm-ns annotations: vmware/confidential-pod: enabled spec: # specification of the pod's contents restartPolicy: Never containers: - name: photon image: wcp-docker-ci.artifactory.eng.vmware.com/vmware/photon:1.0 command: ["/bin/sh"] args: ["-c", "while true; do echo hello, world!; sleep 1; done"] resources: requests: memory: "512Mi" limits: memory: "512Mi" Access your namespace in the  Supervisor  environment. See Connecting to Supervisor and VKS Clusters. Deploy a confidential  vSphere Pod  from the YAML file. kubectl apply -f <yaml file name>.yaml When the  vSphere Pod  is deployed, DRS places it to the  ESX  node that supports SEV-ES. If no such node is available, the  vSphere Pod  is marked as failed. The confidential  vSphere Pod  that is launched provides hardware memory encryption support for all workloads that are running on that pod. Run the following command to verify that the confidential  vSphere Pod  has been created. ```default kubectl describe pod/ A vSphere administrator can view the confidential  vSphere Pod. In the vSphere Client, it appears with the Encryption Mode: Confidential Compute tag.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Deploy Workloads to vSphere Pods
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
What Is a vSphere Pod?A vSphere Pod is equivalent of a Kubernetes pod. It is a VM with a small footprint that runs one or more Linux containers. Each vSphere Pod is sized precisely for the workload that it accommodates and has explicit resource reservations for that workload. It allocates the exact amount of storage, memory, and CPU resources required for the workload to run.vSphere PodsvSphere Pods are objects enable the following capabilities for workloads: Strong isolation. A  vSphere Pod  is isolated in the same manner as a virtual machine. Each  vSphere Pod  has its own unique Linux kernel that is based on the kernel used in Photon OS. Rather than many containers sharing a kernel, as in a bare metal configuration, in a  vSphere Pod , each container has a unique Linux kernel Resource Management. vSphere DRS handles the placement of  vSphere Pods  on the  Supervisor . High performance.  vSphere Pods  get the same level of resource isolation as VMs, eliminating noisy neighbor problems while maintaining the fast start-up time and low overhead of containers. Diagnostics. As a vSphere administrator you can use all the monitoring and introspection tools that are available with vSphere on workloads. vSphere Pods are Open Container Initiative (OCI) compatible and can run containers from any operating system as long as these containers are also OCI compatible.Guidelines for Deploying vSphere PodsBefore deploying vSphere Pods, make sure that your environment meets the following requirements.Namespace
For information about creating a namespace, see Create and Configure a vSphere Namespace on the Supervisor.
For information about assigning permissions, see Identity and Access Management.NetworkingFor networking, vSphere Pods
 use the topology provided by NSX. For details, see Supervisor Networking.Spherelet is an additional process that is created on each host. It is a kubelet that is ported natively to ESX and allows the ESX host to become part of the Kubernetes cluster.StoragevSphere Pods use three types of storage depending on the objects that are stored, that are ephemeral VMDKs, persistent volume VMDKs, and containers image VMDKs.As a vSphere administrator, you configure storage policies for placement of container image cache and ephemeral VMDKs when you enable the Supervisor .On a vSphere Namespace
 level, you configure storage policies for placement of persistent volumes. See Persistent Storage for Workloads for details about the storage requirements and concepts.vSphere Pod Networking and Storage

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Kubectl in Supervisorlandia
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
Connected to Supervisor Cluster:kubectl config use-context <supervisor-context> kubectl get ns NAME STATUS AGE default Active kube-system Active kube-public Active kube-node-lease Active my-team-a Active my-team-b Active Here, there is no such thing as a “regular Kubernetes namespace” in the tenant sense. The namespace here: Cannot be created freely. Map to vSphere inventory objects. Quotas, storage, and networking are externally-enforced. Connected to a guest clusterkubectl get ns kubectl create ns foo kubectl delete ns foo All of these will work as expected. Supervisor namespaces → owns the cluster. Guest cluster namespace → normal Kubernetes semantics. # check Supervisor-specific APIs kubectl api-resources | grep -i vm virtualmachines vmoperator.vmware.com # look at the nodes kubectl get nodes -o wide # look for VM Operator kubectl get pods -A | grep vmoperator Supervisor cluster nodes typically show:
ESX-backed control-plane VMs. Special node labels VM Operator components Guest clusters look like: Standard linux nodes kubelet-managed lifecycle No VM Operator CRDs. In a Supervisor cluster, tenant namespaces are Kubernetes namespaces whose lifecycle, limits, and security are owned by vSphere. In a guest cluster, namespaces are owned entirely by Kubernetes.
#tenancy

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.sourcePath: VCF/Core Runtimes/vSphere/Platform Extensions/vSphere Supervisor/Supervisor Internals and Platform Integration/Control and Consumption/Kubectl in Supervisorlandia.md

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Supervisor Namespace
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
A vSphere Namespace sets the resource boundaries where vSphere Pods, VMs, and VKS clusters, and Supervisor Services can run. As a vSphere administrator, you create and configure vSphere Namespaces through the vSphere Client.When initially created, a vSphere Namespace has unlimited resources within the Supervisor. As a vSphere administrator, you can set limits for CPU, memory, storage, as well as the number of Kubernetes objects that can run within the vSphere Namespace. Storage limitations are represented as storage quotas in Kubernetes. A resource pool is created in vSphere per each vSphere Namespace on the SupervisorYou can map up to three vSphere Zones to a vSphere Namespace for running workloads on them. The vSphere Namespace spreads across all vSphere clusters that are part of the vSphere Zones. The resources utilized to a vSphere Namespace are taken from all the underlying vSphere clusters on equal parts. For example, if you dedicate 300 MHz of CPU, 100 MHz are taken from each vSphere cluster.To provide workload isolation, you should use vSphere Zones marked as management only for running the Supervisor conrol plane on these zones.Differences Between a vSphere Namespace and Kubernetes NamespaceAlthough in its core a vSphere Namespace serves the same function as a Kubernetes namespace, a vSphere Namespace is specific to the vSphere Supervisor. You should not confuse a vSphere Namespace with a Kubernetes namespace.A vSphere Namespace is implemented as an extension to a vSphere resource pool and its function is to provide resources to workloads running in the Supervisor. A vSphere Namespace has a direct mapping to a Kubernetes namespace through which object and storage quotas are enforced upon workloads.Another difference with a regular Kubernetes namespace is that the vSphere administrator manages the user access to vSphere Namespaces, as mentioned from above. The vSphere administrator can also associate VM classes and Content Libraries containing VM templates that DevOps engineers can use to self-service VMs.These are not Kubernetes namespaces in the usual sense. They are: Resource-governed containers Backed by:
vSphere Networking (NSX)
vSphere Storage (vSAN) vSphere RBAC A tenant can have more than one Supervisor Namespace; however, those namespaces are not individual tenants. Tenancy is a business/trust concept. Supervisor Namespaces are execution slices that implement tenancy. vCenter / API / UI ↓ Supervisor Namespace created ↓ Namespace appears in Kubernetes ↓ kubectl can now interact with it ^ This is the opposite of upstream Kubernetes.In a vSphere Supervisor cluster, tenant namespaces are created and owned by vSphere as Supervisor Namespaces. Kubernetes users cannot create namespaces directly; kubectl is used only to interact with namespaces after vSphere has provisioned them. Supervisor Namespaces are created by vSphere
kubectl create ns is not how tenancy is established. This will be explicitly denies on the Supervisor Cluster. There is no concept of a regular tenant namespace on Supervisor Kubernetes reflects what vSphere creates Namespace lifecycle is deliberately centralized for safety In a Supervisor cluster, Kubernetes cluster-admin privileges do not grant authority over physical resource allocation. Namespace creation and resource envelopes are owned by vSphere, and Kubernetes operates strictly within those bounds.Tenant: Coca-Cola ├── ns-coke-prod ├── ns-coke-stage └── ns-coke-dev Tenant: Coca-Cola ├── ns-coke-us ├── ns-coke-eu └── ns-coke-apac ## VCF Automation Representation Organization: Coca-Cola ├── Project: Coke-Prod → ns-coke-prod ├── Project: Coke-Stage → ns-coke-stage └── Project: Coke-Dev → ns-coke-dev ^ One organization, multiple projects, Each project maps to (ideally) one Supervisor Namespace. But this is also possible: Organization: Coca-Cola └── Project: Coke ├── ns-coke-dev ├── ns-coke-stage └── ns-coke-prod The only inverant is one supervisor namespace cannot belong to multiple projects. Namespaces are unique per supervisor cluster. Supervisor clusters are *isolation domains*, so global uniqueness enforcement would have been 1) artificial and 2) painful. Organization └── Project └── Supervisor Namespace(s) From vSphere's perspective, a Pod, VM, or VM-based Pod is just scheduled compute.Project is an automation construct. Defined by Automation Admin persona. Mapped to one or more Supervisor Namespaces. Invisible to vSphere / Kubernetes. Their purpose is to govern requests, not execution.
From the Guest Cluster’s perspective, Organizations and Projects do not exist; similarly there is no concept of an organization or project inside the Supervisor Cluster either.Supervisor namespaces intentionally mimic Kubernetes semantics:From the developer's laptop, they feel like ordinary Kubernetes namespaces.Here is where they differ though (mostly around ownership and LCM)in Supervisor namespaces, resource governance is outside Kubernetes.In Kubernetes: CPU/memory limits = ResourceQuota Storage = StorageClass + PVC Network = CNI rules In Supervisor: CPU/memory = vSphere resource pools Storage = datastore policies Network = NSX segments Limits are hard boundaries, not advisory So when you say: "This namespace gets 8 vCPU and 64 GB RAM" That's not a Kubernetes promise---that's vSphere enforcing physics.Security model is in vSphere, not in KubernetesKubernetes RBAC applies inside the box vSphere already drew.That’s why certain Kubernetes admin actions are silently blocked even when RBAC says “allowed”.From Kubernetes’ POV: It looks like a CNI plugin In reality: NSX owns: L2/L3 segments Firewall rules Load balancers Kubernetes asks politely. NSX decides.This matters for: NetworkPolicy Ingress behavior Multi-tenant isolation In vanilla K8s: PVC requests storage Cluster tries to satisfy it In Supervisor: PVC must map to pre-approved storage policies Datastore capabilities are enforced externally StorageClass ≈ view of vSphere policy, not a free-form construct.The goal of this abstraction is to: Let Kubernetes users feel at home Let infrastructure teams retain determinism Avoid “Kubernetes ate my datacenter” chaos So Supervisor namespaces are: Kubernetes-compatible interfaces to vSphere-owned sandboxes Supervisor namespaces intentionally impersonate Kubernetes namespaces Kubernetes sees them as native; operations are externally enforced vSphere owns: lifecycle resource limits security boundaries Kubernetes operates within those constraints Supervisor Namespace names are unique only within a Supervisor cluster, and every Supervisor Namespace is governed by exactly one Project; Organizations do not directly own namespaces.Supervisor Namespace names are not globally unique, nor organization-wide unique.
They are unique per Supervisor Cluster.
Supervisor Namespaces are always associated with a Project.Organization └── Project └── Supervisor Namespace(s) Namespace names are: ❌ not global ❌ not org-unique ❌ not project-unique ✅ unique per Supervisor cluster Namespace: belongs to exactly one Project indirectly belongs to one Organization never floats independently Here’s a concrete example:Org: Verizon Project: West-Coast - Supervisor Cluster: sjc-01 - Namespace: edge-prod - Supervisor Cluster: lax-01 - Namespace: edge-prod ← same name, totally fine Project: East-Coast - Supervisor Cluster: iad-01 - Namespace: edge-prod ← also fine
Namespace names are Supervisor Cluster-scoped Projects are mandatory governance owners Organizations are containers of projects, not namespaces Any apparent contradiction is UI simplification, not platform behavior

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Supervisor Namespace (to merge)
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
vSphere Supervisor workloads, including vSphere Pods, VMs, and VKS clusters, are deployed to a vSphere Namespace. A vSphere administrator defines the namespace on a Supervisor and configures it with resource quota and user permissions. Depending on the DevOps needs and workloads they plan to run, the vSphere administrator might also assign storage policies, VM classes, and content libraries for fetching VM images.When initially created, the namespace has unlimited resources within the Supervisor. As a vSphere administrator, you can set limits for CPU, memory, storage, and the number of Kubernetes objects that can run within the namespace. Storage limitations are represented as storage quotas in Kubernetes. A resource pool is created in vSphere per each namespace on the SupervisorIn a Supervisor activated on vSphere Zones, a namespace resource pool is created on each vSphere cluster that is mapped to a zone. The resources utilized by the namespace on a three-zone Supervisor are taken from all three underlying vSphere clusters in equal parts. For example, if you dedicate 300 MHz of CPU, 100 MHz are taken from each vSphere cluster.To provide access to namespaces to DevOps engineer, a vSphere administrator assigns permission to users or user groups available within an identity source that is associated with vCenter Single Sign-On or from an ODIC provider that is registered with the Supervisor
. For more information, see Understanding Authentication and Authorization in vSphere Supervisor.After a vSphere Namespace is created and configured with resource, object limits, permissions, and storage policies, as a DevOps engineer, you can access the namespace to run the following workloads:
For information about running  Supervisor Services , see Managing Supervisor Services.
For information about running  vSphere Pods , see Deploying Workloads to vSphere Pods.
For information about deploying VMs, see Deploying and Managing Virtual Machines in vSphere Supervisor.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.sourcePath: VCF/Core Runtimes/vSphere/Platform Extensions/vSphere Supervisor/Supervisor Internals and Platform Integration/Control and Consumption/Supervisor Namespace (to merge).md

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Resources that VKS Cluster Works With
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
VCF Automation and VKS cluster management provide a hierarchy of objects to help you manage your resources. The four core resources that VKS cluster management uses are the organization, project, cluster, and the VKS workload cluster namespace.Resource Hierarchy in VKS Cluster Management  VCF Automation OrganizationsAn organization is a top-level entity used to group and manage resources, users, policies, IaaS services, and catalog entities, while maintaining a secure boundary from other organizations. Organizations offer a centralized structure for billing, access control, and resource sharing, facilitating collaboration and governance across teams and departments. The organization typically correlates to a business or possibly a line of business within a large enterprise. Under the organization are grouping objects that allow you to separate the concerns of the people that use your resources.VCF Automation ProjectsProjects are logical representations of application teams and consist of users, groups, and resource pools they are entitled to. Projects enable you to organize your VKS clusters into logical groupings, for example, to align with business units.However, projects are also tied to the underlying infrastructure. The resource pools that projects use are called vSphere Namespaces. You can add or remove namespaces to a project at any time. Clusters within the same vSphere Namespace cannot be in different projects. Also, you cannot move a cluster between different vSphere Namespaces.By combining your resources into projects, you can simplify management. For example, you can apply policies or perform batch operations at the project level instead of working with separate clusters.Since you can change the name of a project at any time, VKS cluster management uses the project ID as the unique identifier for all project-scoped resources.You cannot delete a project if it contains a VKS cluster.VKS ClustersA VKS cluster is a vSphere-based Kubernetes cluster that runs your workloads.For more information about VKS and VKS clusters, see the Managing vSphere Kubernetes Service with vSphere Supervisor documentation.VKS Cluster NamespacesEach VKS cluster can have one or multiple Kubernetes namespaces that you can view with VKS cluster management. Your VKS clusters can also have unmanaged namespaces. Unmanaged namespaces are namespaces that are created externally and that you do not manage with VKS cluster management.VKS cluster namespaces are different from vSphere Namespaces. A vSphere Namespace is a resource pool that comprises CPU, memory, and storage resources that the provider administrator allocates to organizations and projects in VCF Automation. You do not manage vSphere Namespaces through VKS cluster management.Synchronization of Organizations and Projects From VCF Automation to VKS Cluster ManagementUpon deployment, VKS cluster management subscribes to the VCF Automation event broker service to synchronize organizations and projects. After subscribing to event broker, you get an event every time an organization or a project changes. This way VKS cluster management remains in sync with VCF Automation. For any events that might get missed, there is also a regular periodic re-synchronization.VKS cluster management is not available for VM Apps organizations in VCF Automation. Those organizations and the projects in them do not get sychronized with VKS cluster management. For more information about VM Apps organizations and All Apps organizations in VCF Automation
, see Organization Management.Yes — VCF Automation introduces a hierarchical resource model that organizes VKS clusters under: Organizations Projects VKS Clusters This hierarchy exists in the VCF control plane and is exposed via the VCF Automation APIs/UI to help platform teams: allocate quotas, enforce policy, view/manage clusters centrally
This is done as part of the VCF Automation resource model, not as native Kubernetes objects inside the VKS workload clusters themselves. Broadcom TechDocsWhat this implies: Organizational boundaries exist above the Kubernetes API level. They are part of the VCF Automation control plane, not part of kube-apiserver for the VKS clusters. This means these constructs are not visible via kubectl against a VKS cluster as CRs like PlatformMetaData or similar. Analogy: Think of Organization/Project as resource containers in a cloud control plane (like AWS Organizations + Accounts). Kubernetes doesn’t know or enforce them — but the cloud control plane does. Similarly here: VCF Automation knows about Organization and Projects, but the VKS clusters themselves do not expose that model in their own Kubernetes API surface.It’s important to separate three different namespace domains:These are the namespaces you see when you do:kubectl get ns
inside a VKS workload cluster — this is “real native Kubernetes” and works exactly like any other cluster namespace (pods, services, roles, etc.). WilliamLam.comThese do not represent Organization/Project boundaries from VCF Automation — they are just Kubernetes namespaces in the workload cluster.The vSphere Supervisor cluster also has namespaces — these are used to scope: System components (for VKS, VM Service, etc.) Resource allocation pools Workload provisioning contexts You can see Supervisor namespaces via:kubectl get namespaces
when connected to the Supervisor cluster’s control plane API endpoint. mpoore.ioThese Supervisor namespaces are used as a container for VKS cluster objects — but again, this is not the same as the VCF Automation Organization/Project construct. They exist inside the Supervisor’s Kubernetes API.This is a higher-level grouping used by VCF to track: VKS clusters quotas policies applied at Org/Project level
These are not Kubernetes namespaces — they are external catalog/metadata constructs and are only visible through VCF Automation APIs/UI and related governance surfaces. Broadcom TechDocsSo:VCF Automation coordinates: cluster creation cluster status changes policies and quota enforcement Between the Automation control plane and the Supervisor/VKS cluster APIs.
That’s why you see a mention of “synchronization / event brokerage” in the document: it’s the VCF Automation service syncing state between its own internal model (Organization → Project → Cluster) and the underlying Supervisor/VKS API objects. Broadcom TechDocsBut these sync events do not create new Kubernetes CRs inside a VKS cluster that represent Organization/Project names — they exist in the Automation control plane.No, at least not as directly exposed organizational CRs in the Supervisor’s Kubernetes API. What you do get in the Supervisor cluster: Namespaces scoped for system services Namespace/context for VKS clusters Standard K8s objects and CRDs used internally by VKS (Cluster API, controllers), but nothing labeled as “Org/Project” natively in kube-apiserver.
That is an out-of-band governance metadata layer, managed by VCF Automation, not in Supervisor’s Kubernetes API. Broadcom TechDocsTo reiterate:
Supervisor cluster = special embedded Kubernetes cluster for vSphere control plane and VKS services. Medium
VCF Automation Org/Proj = constructs in the VCF control plane to manage cluster fleets, quotas, policies. Broadcom TechDocs Neither of these is a native namespace in VKS workload clusters. There are three APIs involved: VCF Automation API/UI: Exposes Org/Project → VKS clusters Does not live in Kubernetes API You use the VCF automation UI or automation API to see and manage this. Supervisor Kubernetes API: Exposes Supervisor cluster resources Supervisor namespaces, system services, VKS cluster objects You can use kubectl here if you point at Supervisor API. VKS Workload Kubernetes API: The actual workload cluster that developers interact with Standard Kubernetes namespace API None of these expose an API object like:kind: PlatformMetaData
that carries the higher-level Organization/Project mapping — that mapping is external to the Kubernetes APIs, part of VCF Automation governance. Broadcom TechDocs
VCF Automation introduces a hierarchical model (Org → Project → VKS clusters) that is a control plane construct, not native Kubernetes. Broadcom TechDocs
Supervisor clusters have Kubernetes namespaces you can see via kubectl, but these are for system and resource scoping — not the high-level Org/Project model. mpoore.io
Workload clusters have their own native Kubernetes namespaces — standard kube namespaces separate from Supervisor. WilliamLam.com Organization/Project metadata is not visible in the Kubernetes API of workload or supervisor clusters; instead, it lives in VCF Automation service APIs/UI Short answer: a VKS Cluster does not directly “consume” or reason about that out-of-band metadata at runtime. That metadata is used upstream, by the control plane, to decide how, when, and whether a VKS cluster is created, configured, governed, or changed.Let’s unpack this precisely and mechanically.This is where Organization / Project / Cluster metadata lives. Org, Project, ownership Quotas Policies Approval flows RBAC mappings Lifecycle intent (“this cluster belongs to Project X in Org Y”) This layer is authoritative for that metadata.This is the service that provisions and manages Kubernetes clusters on the Supervisor.VKS: receives instructions does not reason about “organizations” as a first-class concept enforces what it is told via concrete config This is the execution substrate: namespaces resource pools networking storage controllers It enforces mechanics, not business structure.The Org / Project info is used to derive concrete, enforceable artifacts before or around the cluster — not inside it.Here’s how that plays out.When you say (implicitly or explicitly): “Create a VKS cluster in Project A of Organization B” VCF Automation uses that metadata to decide: Which Supervisor Namespace the cluster is created under Which resource pools (CPU/mem/storage) it may consume Which networks it may attach to Which policies apply by default By the time VKS sees the request, it looks more like: “Create a cluster with these limits, in this namespace, using these credentials” So VKS never sees “Organization = FooCorp” — it sees resolved, concrete constraints.Org / Project metadata drives policies such as: max node count allowed VM classes allowed storage policies network isolation rules upgrade windows These are compiled down into: admission constraints Supervisor namespace settings cluster spec defaults lifecycle rules enforced externally Once compiled, VKS enforces the result, not the intent.Org / Project membership is used to decide: who can create / delete clusters who can resize them who can see them in UI / API But inside the cluster: Kubernetes RBAC is still Kubernetes RBAC there is no native concept of “Org Admin” or “Project Owner” Those roles are translated at provisioning time into: kubeconfigs initial role bindings access paths Again: translation → enforcement → forget the original label.Because the Org / Project model is authoritative: deleting a Project can trigger cluster deletion quota exhaustion can block scale-out org-level policy changes can trigger reconciliation But: the decision happens in VCF Automation VKS just executes lifecycle operations it is told to execute This is why you see eventing / synchronization mentioned in the docs: it’s about state reconciliation, not metadata propagation.This is the part you were circling around — and your instinct was right.Inside a VKS workload cluster: ❌ No Organization CR ❌ No Project CR ❌ No PlatformMetadata object ❌ No way to kubectl get and discover: “Which Org do I belong to?” From a DevOps or in-cluster perspective: The cluster is sovereign. It has: nodes namespaces workloads policies But no awareness of who “owns” it at the platform governance layer.This is very intentional.If Org / Project metadata were injected into clusters: cluster portability would suffer backup / restore would leak tenancy info federation would get messy GitOps would become environment-coupled By keeping the metadata out-of-band: clusters remain generic Kubernetes governance stays centralized enforcement happens at the edges (creation, mutation, deletion) This mirrors how: AWS Organizations ≠ Kubernetes namespaces vCenter folders ≠ VM guest OS awareness Cloud billing ≠ workload runtime VCF Automation owns intent. VKS enforces outcome. Supervisor executes mechanics. Once the outcome is materialized, the intent is no longer visible downstream. Does the metadata exist? Yes — in VCF Automation. Is it synchronized into the cluster? No — only its effects are. Can DevOps see it via kubectl? No — by design. Does the Supervisor know about Orgs/Projects? No — only namespaces, pools, and policies. VKS does not “use” Org / Project metadata at runtime. It receives decisions derived from that metadata and enforces them. The metadata itself never enters the Kubernetes API surface.
#todo TODO: figure this out.
VKS Cluster Management is a component, I think.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: VKS Cluster Storage
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
VKS clusters, as some other components and workloads that run in vSphere Namespace require persistent storage.Storage Policies for VKS ClusterTo provide persistent storage resources to the VKS clusters, a vSphere administrator configures storage policies that describe different storage requirements. The administrator then adds the storage policies to the namespace where the VKS cluster is deployed. Storage policies visible to the namespace determine which datastores the namespace can access and use for persistent storage. They dictate how the cluster nodes and workloads are placed in the vSphere storage environment.Based on the storage policies assigned to the namespace, vSphere Supervisor creates matching Kubernetes storage classes that automatically appear in the namespace. They are also propagated to the VKS cluster on this namespace.In the VKS cluster, the storage classes appear in two editions, one with the Immediate and another with the WaitForFirstConsumer binding mode. The edition the DevOps team choose depends on their requirements.For more information about storage classes in VKS clusters, see Using Storage Classes for Persistent Volumes.How VKS Clusters Integrate with vSphere StorageTo integrate with the Supervisor and vSphere storage, VKS clusters use Paravirtual CSI (pvCSI).The pvCSI is the version of the vSphere CNS-CSI driver modified for VKS clusters. The pvCSI resides in the VKS cluster and is responsible for all storage related requests originating from the VKS cluster. The requests are delivered to the CNS-CSI, which then propagates them to CNS in vCenter. As a result, the pvCSI does not have direct communication with the CNS component, but instead relies on the CNS-CSI for any storage provisioning operations. Unlike the CNS-CSI, the pvCSI does not require infrastructure credentials. It is configured with a service account in the namespace.
How a Persistent Volume is CreatedThe following illustrates how different components interact when a DevOps engineer performs a storage related operation within the VKS cluster, for example creates a persistent volume claim (PVC).The DevOps engineer creates a PVC using the command line on the VKS cluster. This action generates a matching PVC on the Supervisor and triggers the CNS-CSI. The CNS-CSI invokes the CNS create volume API.
After successful creation of a volume, the operation propagates back through the Supervisor to the VKS cluster. As a result of this propagation, users can see the persistent volume and the persistent volume claim in the bound state in the Supervisor. And they also see the persistent volume and the persistent volume claim in the bound state in the VKS cluster.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Managing VKS Cluster with VKS Cluster Management
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
Use the VKS cluster management feature to manage the VKS clusters in your environment. With VKS cluster management, you get multi-cluster management features and capabilities integrated in your VCF Automation instance. So, you can now use VCF Automation to manage your Kubernetes fleets.VKS Cluster Management OverviewLast Updated December 16, 2025VKS cluster management is a feature in VCF Automation that enables you, as an organization or project administrator, to manage the VKS clusters in your environment and easily operate modern containerized applications across multiple clusters, teams, and environments. VKS cluster management ensures easier management of resources, apps, users, and security by enabling you to organize your clusters and namespaces into VCF Automation projects.VKS cluster management is not available for VM Apps organizations in VCF Automation. For more information, see Organization Management.VKS cluster management supports the following core capabilities: Policy management Rather than manually dealing with the many aspects of managing your Kubernetes resources and the apps that use them, you can create policies to consistently manage your clusters, namespaces, and workloads. For more information about policy-driven management of your VKS
 clusters, see Working With VKS Cluster Management Policies. Add-on management You can manage the add-on packages that are installed on your clusters. VKS
 cluster management uses Carvel, which is an open-source community standard for package management. For more information, see Managing Add-Ons on VKS Clusters with VKS Cluster Management.Managing add-ons is only available with VKS version 3.5 and later. Data protection
You can back up and restore your clusters and namespaces using Velero to protect the valuable data resources in your infrastructure. For more information, see Backing Up and Restoring VKS Clusters and VKS Cluster Namespaces with VKS Cluster Management.VKS Cluster Management ArchitectureVKS cluster management is deployed in three parts: A set of microservices is deployed inside  VCF Automation . The auto-attach service is deployed on the  Supervisor  that is registered with  VCF Automation . A set of extensions is deployed on each  VKS  cluster in the environment. If the management and workload layers are on separate networks, the communication between the different planes happens through a Supervisor
 management proxy. For more information, see Configuring the Supervisor Management Proxy.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.sourcePath: VCF/Core Runtimes/vSphere/Platform Extensions/vSphere Supervisor/Supervisor Internals and Platform Integration/Kubernetes Runtimes/VKS/VKS Cluster Management/Managing VKS Cluster with VKS Cluster Management.md

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Viewing Details About VKS Clusters with VKS Cluster Management
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description: you can use VKS cluster management enables you to monitor the health and utilization of your VKS clusters and resources. In the list of VKS clusters in VCF Automation, you can view general information about each cluster, for example cluster health, status, vSphere Kubernetes release version, and so on. You can view additional details about each cluster on the cluster subtabs that appear when you click the cluster. For easier navigation, you can use the filters on each cluster tab.VKS Cluster Information Available in VKS Cluster ManagementFrom the cluster top-level page, you can drill down to see health and utilization details for your nodes, namespaces, and resources.VKS Cluster Management Object LabelsLabels help you identify and organize your Kubernetes resources. VKS cluster management uses system-defined labels that are outlined in blue in the user interface. Labels can be applied to clusters, nodes, namespaces, and workloads. You cannot modify those system-defined labels, but you can use them to filter or sort your lists of clusters, nodes, namespaces, or workloads.Labels are displayed in object lists and in the detailed page for an object. For example, the Namespaces tab for a cluster displays a table with cluster nodes along with the labels that are applied to them. When you click on a node from the list, its labels are displayed in the summary panel at the top.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: VKS Cluster Management
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
VKS cluster management is a feature within VCF Automation. Starting with VCF 9.0.1, VKS cluster management is enabled automatically with the deployment of VCF Automation alongside the rest of the VCF Automation services.The only thing you must do to have VKS cluster management working properly, is install the Supervisor management proxy with the correct configuration that supports VKS cluster management. For more information about installing the Supervisor management proxy, see Configuring the Supervisor Management Proxy.DependenciesVKS cluster management has the following stateful dependencies: PostgreSQL SeaweedFS Kafka OCI repository VKS Cluster Management Image RegistryThe images that VKS cluster management uses for the deployment of agents and extensions on VKS
 clusters, are hosted on a public, unautheticated OCI repository. The default extension image registry is located at http://projects.packages.broadcom.com. In an air-gapped environment, you can use your own OCI-compliant registry and relocate the images that you need, see Enabling VKS Cluster Management in an Air-Gapped Environment.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: VKS Cluster Management Policies
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
ou manage the operation and security posture of your VKS clusters by creating and using policies of various types.VKS Cluster Management Policy TypesPolicies allow you to provide a set of rules that govern your organization and all the objects it contains.Five policy types exist inVKS cluster management. Security policy Security policies enable you to manage the security context in which deployed pods operate in your clusters by imposing constraints on your clusters that define what pods can do and which resources they have access to. For more information about security policies, see Managing Pod Security with VKS Cluster Management Security Policies.
Image registry policy Image registry policies enable you to specify the source registries from which an image can be pulled. For more information about image registry policies, see VKS Cluster Management Image Registry Policies.
Quota policy Quota policies enable you to constrain the resources used in your clusters, as aggregate quantities across specified namespaces, using preconfigured and custom templates. For more information about quota policies, see VKS Cluster Management Quota Policies
Mutation policy Mutation policies enable you to alter resources before they are admitted to the cluster. For more information about mutation policies, see VKS Cluster Management Mutation Policies.
Custom policy Custom policies enable you to implement additional business rules, using templates that you define, to enforce policies that are not already addressed using the other built-in policy types. For more information about custom policies, see VKS Cluster Management Custom Policies. Out of these five policies, only the quota policy type is implemented by using the Kubernetes-native ResourceQuota objects,. The rest of the policy types use the open-source OPA Gatekeeper as the policy engine.You can apply policies at any level of the hierarchy - the organization, the project, or cluster levels.Policy InheritanceIn the VKS cluster management resource hierarchy, there are three levels at which you can create policies: Organization Project VKS  cluster You can create direct policies at any level. But policies are also propagated down the hierarchy tree. Every object inherits the policies defined for its parent objects. For example, when you create a security policy at the project level, all clusters within that project inherit the applicable policy. Additionally, the project also inherits policy definitions from its parent organization, if there are policies created and applied to that organization.VKS Cluster Management Policies and GatekeeperSome of the policy types in VKS cluster management are implemented using OPA Gatekeeper. These policy types include security policy, image registry policy, and mutation policy. When you implement one of these policies, VKS cluster management installs Gatekeeper on the cluster and maintains that installation while you have VKS cluster management policies applied to that cluster.If there is an installation of Gatekeeper on the cluster that was not installed by VKS cluster management , then VKS cluster management does not alter or maintain that installation. In many cases, this situation does not impact the functionality of the policy. However, because Gatekeeper was not installed and configured by VKS cluster management , Gatekeeper-based policies implemented through VKS cluster management might not function as expected. This situation raises an Incompatibility insight that can be viewed on the Policy Insights page.For best results, if you are using VKS cluster management policies on a cluster, remove external installations of Gatekeeper and let VKS
 cluster management manage Gatekeeper for you. For more information, see the official Gatekeeper documentation at https://open-policy-agent.github.io/gatekeeper/website/docs/.

#todo TODO: TKG is outdated, provide info about VKS here.VKS is essentially the evolution of what was previously known as Tanzu Kubernetes Grid Service (TKGs). VMware has been moving away from the Tanzu branding for this component and aligning on the VKS name: “What was formerly known as Tanzu Kubernetes Grid Service (TKGs) is now unified under a single, intuitive name: vSphere Kubernetes Service (VKS).”
TKG (Tanzu Kubernetes Grid) is VMware’s CNCF-conformant Kubernetes distribution, integrated deeply with vSphere.TKG, in this context is: Upstream Kubernetes + VMware’s opinionated lifecycle, security, and infrastructure integration. Runs on vSphere Worker nodes are VMs
Created and managed via vSphere Supervisor Tightly integrated with:
vSphere networking (NSX / VDS)
vSphere storage (vSAN, CNS) vSphere IAM / RBAC boundaries Inside the guest cluster: Kubernetes sees: Namespaces RBAC CRDs Workloads It does not see: Organizations Projects Approval flows Business tenancy Those live outside the cluster, enforced by:
vSphere
vSphere Supervisor
Automation layers (i.e., VCF Automation) This is similar to saying “a Docker container does not know which Jira project paid for the VM it runs on”.vSphere / ESX └── Supervisor Cluster └── Supervisor Namespace └── TKG Workload Cluster (guest cluster) ├── Kubernetes API ├── Nodes = VMs └── Apps / Pods

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: VKS 1
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
The VKS provides self-service life cycle management of VKS clusters. You use the VKS to create and manage VKS clusters in a declarative manner that is familiar to Kubernetes operators and developers.VKS ComponentsThe VKS exposes three layers of controllers to manage the lifecycle of a VKS cluster. The  VKS  provisions clusters that include the components necessary to integrate with the underlying  vSphere Namespace  resources. These components include a Cloud Provider Plug-in that integrates with the  Supervisor . In addition, a  VKS  cluster passes requests for persistent volumes to the  Supervisor , which is integrated with VMware Cloud Native Storage (CNS). See Persistent Storage for Workloads. The Cluster API provides declarative, Kubernetes-style APIs for cluster creation, configuration, and management. The inputs to Cluster API include a resource describing the cluster, a set of resources describing the virtual machines that make up the cluster, and a set of resources describing cluster add-ons. The  Virtual Machine Service  provides a declarative, Kubernetes-style API for management of VMs and associated vSphere resources. The  Virtual Machine Service  introduces the concept of a virtual machine class that represents an abstract reusable hardware configuration. The functionality provided by the  Virtual Machine Service  is used to manage the lifecycle of the control plane and worker node VMs hosting a  VKS  cluster.
VKS Cluster ComponentsThe components that run in a VKS cluster span four areas: Authentication and authorization, storage integration, pod networking, and load balancing. Authentication webhook: A webhook running as a pod inside the cluster to validate user authentication tokens. Container Storage Interface Plugin: A Paravirtual CSI plug-in that integrates with CNS through the  Supervisor . Container Network Interface Plug-in: A CNI plugin that provides pod networking. Cloud Provider Implementation: Supports creating Kubernetes load balancer services. VKS APIYou use the VKS API to provision and manage VKS clusters. It is a declarative API that you invoke using kubectl and YAML. You can download the VMware expanded kubectl executable from the Supervisor API endpoint IP.With a declarative API, instead of making imperative commands to the system, you specify the desired state of the VKS cluster: how many nodes, available storage, VM sizes, Kubernetes software version. The VKS does the work to provision a cluster that matches the desired state.To call the VKS API, you invoke kubectl using a YAML file, which in turn invokes the API. After the cluster is created, you update the YAML to update the cluster.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: vSphere Supervisor Components
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
The Supervisor has the following components: Supervisor  control plane VM. You can select to deploy the  Supervisor  with either one or control plane VMs. For control plane HA, three VMs are recommended. The three  Supervisor  control plane VMs are load balanced as each one of them has its own IP address. Additionally, a floating IP address is assigned to one of the VMs and a 5th IP address is reserved for patching purposes. vSphere DRS determines the exact placement of the control plane VMs on the ESX hosts part of the  Supervisor  and migrates them when needed. VKS  and Cluster API. Modules running on the  Supervisor  and enable the provisioning and management of  VKS  clusters. Virtual Machine Service . A module that is responsible for deploying and running stand-alone VMs and VMs that make up  VKS  clusters. Spherelet. An additional process called Spherelet is created on each host. It is a kubelet that is ported natively to ESX and allows the ESX host to become part of the Kubernetes cluster. Container Runtime Executive (CRX) component. CRX is similar to a VM from the perspective of Hostd and  vCenter . CRX includes a paravirtualized Linux kernel that works together with the hypervisor. CRX uses the same hardware virtualization techniques as VMs and it has a VM boundary around it. A direct boot technique is used, which allows the Linux guest of CRX to initiate the main init process without passing through kernel initialization. This allows  vSphere Pods  to boot nearly as fast as containers.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: vSphere Supervisor Inventory
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description: The vSphere Supervisor inventory is a representation of the Supervisor folder and its associated resources.vSphere configures separate Supervisor folders for each Supervisor and all the associated resources. The namespaces and control plane VMs are mapped under the respective Supervisor folder isolating them from the resources of other Supervisors, even though names of namespaces must be unique within vCenter.The vSphere Pods within each namespace are segregated into a folder called vSphere Pods. This ensures their isolation from other VMs and VKS clusters that are in the same namespace and allows distinct and precise privilege allocation.Each Namespace folder includes all workload entities created under it, such as VMs deployed through VM Service and VKS clusters. Additionally, each Namespace folder contains a subfolder named vSpherePods which contains all the vSphere Pods associated with the Namespace. Since Pod VMs primarily serve infrastructure purposes, the vSpherePods folder is configured with restrictive permissions to prevent users from performing any direct operations on the pods.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: vSphere Supervisor Security
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
vSphere Supervisor leverages vSphere security features and provisions VKS clusters that are secure by default.vSphere Supervisor is an add-on module to vSphere that is able to leverage the security features that are built into vCenter and ESX. For more information, see the vSphere Security documentation.The Supervisor encrypts all secrets stored in the database (etcd). The secrets are encrypted via a local encryption key file, which is provided at boot by vCenter. The decryption key is stored in memory (tempfs) on the Supervisor nodes and on disk in encrypted form within vCenter database. The key is available in clear text to the root users of each system. Secrets held within the database of each workload cluster are stored in clear text. All etcd connections are authenticated with certificates that are generated at installation and rotated during upgrades. Manual rotation or updating of the certificates is currently not possible. The same encryption model applies to the data in the database (etcd) that is installed on the control plane for each VKS cluster.In Supervisor, you can run confidential vSphere Pods on compatible systems. You can create confidential vSphere Pods by adding Secure Encrypted Virtualization-Encrypted State (SEV-ES) as a security enhancement. For more information, see Deploy a Confidential vSphere Pod.A VKS cluster is secure by default. Restrictive Pod Security Admission (PSA) and PodSecurityPolicy (PSP) are available for VKS
 clusters. If developers need to run privileged pods or root containers, at a minimum a cluster administrator must create a RoleBinding that grants user access to the default privileged PSP. For more information, see Security for VKS Clusters.A VKS cluster does not have infrastructure credentials. The credentials that are stored within a VKS cluster are only sufficient to access the vSphere Namespace where the VKS cluster has tenancy. As a result, there is no privilege escalation avenue for cluster operators or users.The authentication token used to access a VKS cluster is scoped such that the token cannot be used to access the Supervisor or other VKS clusters. This prevents cluster operators, or individuals who might try to compromise a cluster, from using their root-level access to capture a vSphere administrator's token when they log in to a VKS cluster.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: vSphere Supervisor Storage
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
Supervisor components, applications, and workloads need to store and retrieve data. Some applications and objects might use transient fast storage, while others require storage that persists.Storage Topologies for vSphere ZonesA vSphere Zone is a fault domain that can fail independently from another zones. Supervisor supports different storage topologies for zones. These topologies define how datastores are attached to ESX hosts and how they behave during zone failures.Zonal datastoreA zonal datastore is local to a single vSphere Zone. It is attached to all the ESX hosts that are part of the underlying cluster. It can replicate data to provide higher availability within the zone. Its availability depends on the zone. If the zone goes down, the zonal datastore also goes down. Examples of a zonal datatore include: non-stretched vSAN, non-stretched vSAN storage cluster, non-stretched VMFS or NFS external storage. Cross-zonal datastoreA cross-zonal datastore spans multiple vSphere Zones. It is attached to ESX hosts from all the zones it covers. It can be stretched storage, for example, stretched vSAN, or non-stretched storage that pools hosts from multiple zones, for example, non-stretched vSAN storage cluster. It typically replicates data across zones. It stays available if one of the zones goes down. Examples of a cross-zonal datastore: stretched vSAN, stretched vSAN storage cluster, metro storage cluster, non-stretched vSAN or vSAN storage cluster deployed from hosts across multiple zones. When you work with zonal and cross-zonal datastores in Supervisor, avoid the following misconfigurations: A zonal datastore is attached to other zones. Example: A zonal vSAN datastore in Zone 1 is attached to Zone 2 and Zone 3 using vSAN remote datastore. A zonal datastore is only partially attached to  ESX  hosts in the zone. Example: A vSphere administrator accidentally unmounts a datastore from a host. Example: A new host is added to the zone, but the administrator forgets to attach all zonal datastores to it. A cross-zonal datastore is only partially attached to  ESX  hosts in multiple zones. Example: A datastore is accidentally unmounted from one of the hosts. Example: A new host is added to a zone, but the administrator forgets to attach all cross-zonal datastores to it. Editing storage policies to switch between zonal and cross-zonal compatibility. This action changes the storage class behavior and affects DevOps. Storage policies that match both zonal and cross-zonal datastores. DevOps cannot tell whether the volume they are getting is zonal or cross-zonal. About Storage PoliciesSupervisor uses storage policies to integrate with storage available in your vSphere environment. The policies represent datastores and manage storage placement of such components and objects as control plane VMs, vSphere Pod ephemeral disks, and container images. You might also need policies for storage placement of persistent volumes and VM content libraries. If you use VKS clusters, the storage policies also dictate how the VKS cluster nodes are deployed.Storage policies support any shared datastores in your environment, such as VMFS, NFS, vSAN, and vSAN ESA.Depending on your vSphere storage environment and the needs of DevOps, you can create several storage policies for different classes of storage. When you enable a Supervisor and set up vSphere Namespaces, you can assign different storage policies to be used by various objects, components, and workloads.For example, if a vSphere Pod mounts three types of virtual disks and your vSphere storage environment has three classes of datastores, Bronze, Silver, and Gold, you can create storage policies for all datastores. You can then use the Bronze datastore for ephemeral and container image virtual disks, and use the Silver and Gold datastores for persistent volume virtual disks.When you configure storage policies for datastores to be used with zones, follow these best practices: Make sure that a storage policy matchs either zonal datastores only or cross-zonal datastores only. Mixing both in a single policy leads to unpredictable behavior. Use a policy with zonal constraints to target zonal datastores. The system guarantees compatibility with zonal datastores and catches any misconfigurations during placement. If you create a policy without zonal constraints to use with zonal datastores, ensure it remains compatible with zonal datastores only. You must verify that no cross-zonal datastores match this policy. If you create a policy that matches cross-zonal datastores only, ensure it remains compatible with cross-zonal datastores at all times. Prevent any zonal datastore from matching this policy. SupervisorAt the Supervisor level, you configure a storage policy for Supervisor control plane VMs. In addition, if your deployment supports vSphere Pods, you assign storage polices and specify the datastore locations for ephemeral disks and container images. For information about setting storage when enabling Supervisor, see the Installing and Configuring vSphere Supervisor
 documentation. To change storage settings, see Change Storage Settings on the Supervisor.Control Plane Storage PolicyThis policy ensures that the control plane VMs are placed on the datastores that the policies represent.Ephemeral Virtual DisksA vSphere Pod requires ephemeral storage to store such Kubernetes objects as logs, emptyDir volumes, and ConfigMaps during its operations. This ephemeral, or transient, storage lasts as long as the pod continues to exist. Ephemeral data persists across container restarts, but once the pod reaches the end of its life, the ephemeral virtual disk disappears.Each pod has one ephemeral virtual disk. As a vSphere administrator you use a storage policy to define the datastore location for all ephemeral virtual disks when configuring storage for the Supervisor.Container Image Virtual DisksContainers inside the vSphere Pod use images that contain the software to be run. The pod mounts images used by its containers as image virtual disks. When the pod completes its life cycle, the image virtual disks are detached from the pod.Image Service, an ESX component, is responsible for pulling container images from the image registry and transforming them into virtual disks to run inside the pod.
Persistent Storage for WorkloadsCertain Kubernetes workloads that DevOps run on a namespace require persistent storage to store data permanently.Persistent storage can be used by vSphere Pods, VKS clusters, VMs, and other workloads you run on the namespace. To make persistent storage available to the DevOps team, the vSphere administrator creates storage policies that describe different storage requirements and classes of services. The administrator then assigns storage policies and configures storage limits at a namespace level.To understand how vSphere Supervisor
 works with persistent storage, be familiar with the such essential Kubernetes concepts as storage classes, persistent volumes, and persistent volume claims. For more information, see the Kubernetes documentation at https://kubernetes.io/docs/home/.To learn about persistent storage for VKS
 clusters, see Storage for VKS Clusters.
For information about using persistent storage, see Using Persistent Storage with Workloads.If your DevOps team plans to deploy third-party services that use vSAN Direct
 for their persistent storage needs, see Enable Stateful Services.Supervisor uses several components to integrate with vSphere storage. 
Cloud Native Storage (CNS) on vCenterThe CNS component resides in vCenter. It is an extension of vCenter management that implements provisioning and lifecycle operations for persistent volumes.When provisioning persistent volumes, the component interacts with the vSphere First Class Disk functionality to create virtual disks that back the volumes. In addition, the CNS server component communicates with the Storage Policy Based Management to guarantee a required level of service to the disks.The CNS also performs query operations that allow vSphere administrators to manage and monitor persistent volumes and their backing storage objects through vCenter.First Class Disk (FCD)Also called Improved Virtual Disk. These disks reside on datastores and back ReadWriteOnce persistent volumes.When you use FCDs, keep in mind the following: FCDs do not support NFS 4.x protocols. Instead, use NFS 3. vCenter  does not serialize operations on the same FCD. As a result, applications cannot simultaneously perform operations on the same FCD. Performing such operations as clone, relocate, delete, retrieve, and so on simultaneously from different threads causes unpredictable results. To avoid problems, applications must perform operations on the same FCD in a sequential order. FCD is not a managed object and does not support a global lock protecting multiple writes to a single FCD. As a result, FCD doesn't support multiple  vCenter  instances managing the same FCD. If you need to use multiple  vCenter  instances with FCDs, you have the following options: Multiple  vCenter  instances can manage different datastores. Multiple  vCenter  instances do not operate on the same FCD. Storage Policy Based ManagementStorage Policy Based Management is a vCenter service that supports provisioning of persistent volumes and their backing virtual disks according to storage requirements described in a storage policy. After provisioning, the service monitors compliance of the volume with the storage policy characteristics. For more information about Storage Policy Based Management, see the About Storage Policy Based Management chapter in the vSphere Storage documentation.vSphere CNS-CSIThe vSphere CNS-CSI component conforms to Container Storage Interface (CSI) specification, an industry standard designed to provide an interface that container orchestrators like Kubernetes use to provision persistent storage. The CNS-CSI driver runs in the Supervisor and connects vSphere storage to Kubernetes environment on a namespace. The vSphere CNS-CSI communicates directly with the CNS component for all storage provisioning requests that originate from the namespace.

headers.heading: How Supervisor Integrates with vSphere Storage

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: vSphere Supervisor
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
vSphere Supervisor is a control plane built in vSphere that integrates desired state and a single consistent API directly in the hypervisor. vSphere Supervisor enables native deployment and management of Kubernetes clusters, declarative virtual machines, and vSphere Pods alongside traditional workloads. It transforms vSphere to an extendable platform by providing a declarative API for self-service provisioning of modern infrastructure services in a resource boundaries enabled by vSphere Namespaces.Supervisor Namespace
The vSphere Supervisor lives as a set of Kubernetes control-plane VMs running on ESX hosts, instantiated, wired, and governed by vCenter Server.

Runs on: ESX Created and managed by: VMware vCenter Server Implemented as: Kubernetes control-plane VMs
Distributed across ESX hosts
Backed by vSAN / datastores
Networked via NSX (or VDS in simpler setups) When you “enable Supervisor” in vCenter: vCenter: Creates a special-purpose Kubernetes cluster Instantiates its control plane as VMs Pins it tightly to: Cluster membership Networking Storage Treats it as part of the infrastructure, not a tenant workload So the Supervisor is: Not a workload cluster Not user-managed Kubernetes Not a vSphere product you install It is an infrastructure service owned by vCenter.Physical Hosts └─ ESX └─ vCenter Server (control plane) └─ Supervisor Cluster (Kubernetes control plane VMs) ├─ Supervisor Namespaces ├─ vSphere Pods └─ Guest / Workload Clusters The vSphere Supervisor is a Kubernetes control plane deployed as system-managed VMs on ESX, whose lifecycle is owned entirely by vCenter Server and whose purpose is to expose Kubernetes semantics directly on vSphere infrastructure. The vSphere Supervisor physically lives as vCenter-managed Kubernetes control-plane VMs running on ESX hosts inside a vSphere cluster.
vSphere Supervisor is the foundation of VCF consumption and can be enabled during workload domain creation or directly in vCenter.
#todo "consumption" is discussed in several meetings. It seems like standard nomenclature. Learn what it is.
#todo Is vSphere Supervisor a type of vSphere deployment. Follow-up: what really is vSphere? Is it part of VCF-A or VCF-O? It transforms vSphere clusters into modern application platforms by embedding a platform-level Kubernetes control plane directly into ESX hosts, exposing a unified declarative API surface.
This integration allows end users to provision and manage workloads, including VMs, containers via vSphere Pods, full Kubernetes clusters through VCF/Core Runtimes/vSphere/Platform Extensions/vSphere Supervisor/Supervisor Internals and Platform Integration/Kubernetes Runtimes/VKS/VKS, OCI image registries, and data services through a consistent API interface.
#todo what kinds or registries, "bring your own", harbor, cloud? all?
#todo why embedding the control plane into ESX hosts is such a big thing? wasn't that possible before. Isn't an ESX a "Linux Machine" at a high level anyway? What makes this so unique and innovative?
#todo is the "unified declarative API surface" k8s API, and custom resources? What kind(s) of Custom Resources?
#todo what "really" is a vSphere Pod? Enough with all the marketing language!
vSphere Supervisor maintains enterprise-grade governance, security, and operational consistency through vCenter, VCF Operations, and VCF Automation.
#todo is vSphere Supervisor a higher-level abstraction around the above; or is it a separate entity that communicates (i.e. supervises) those sub-entities?
vSphere Supervisor's vSphere Namespaces provide the foundation for multi-tenancy, enabling GitOps-based workflows, and delivering cloud-like self-service in private data centers.
#todo so tenancy is namespace-bound?
#tenancy
Use NSX Virtual Private Clouds (VPC) workload networks. This configuration is a requirement for using VCF Automation
Determine if a Single-Zone Supervisor or Multi-Zone Supervisor deployment is required: In VCF 9.0, a Supervisor deployed in a single-zone configuration cannot be converted to a multi-zone deployment after enablement. You must determine the target deployment model before initiating the Supervisor enablement process.
#todo what is single-zone versus multi-zone? Single-Zone Deployment: A Single-Zone Supervisor deployment uses a single vSphere cluster to host both workloads and Supervisor management components.
Additional vSphere Zones can be added after initial enablement. However, these zones are used exclusively for workload placement and do not host Supervisor control plane components.
#todo what are Supervisor control plane components?
Multi-Zone Deployment: A Multi-Zone Supervisor deployment uses three vSphere Clusters, placing each cluster into a vSphere Zone. vSphere Zones are used by workloads and Supervisor management components to deliver high availability and expose each cluster as an independent, consumable availability zone. This configuration provides a resilient, HA-capable platform. Additional vSphere Zones can be added after initial enablement. However, these additional zones are available for workload consumption only, not for Supervisor control plane components. Single Host: Also a Single-Zone Supervisor with a single Control Plane VM deployed to a single ESX host, with vSphere HA disabled. While it shares the same characteristics as other single-zone deployments, in this configuration, any host failure results in downtime for the Supervisor Control Plane and potentially for associated workloads.
Easy Supervisor: This is a Single-Zone simplified deployment that uses workload networking on top of vSphere Distributed Switch, designed as a fast and simple starting point for proof-of-concept environments and production deployments leveraging vSphere Distributed Switch. An Easy Supervisor deployment consists of: One Supervisor Control Plane VM A shared network for both workload and management traffic No load balancer
#todo does that imply that normally workload and management traffic is spilt?
It is vSphere running in special Kubernetes-enabled mode.
VCF Automation consumes what Supervisor exposes.
You can think of Supervisor as vSphere with Kubernetes fused into its control plane.


When you enable Supervisor on a vSphere Cluster, you are activating a capability inside vSphere.
Supervisor runs inside ESX.
Uses vCenter as the control plane.
Creates Supervisor Namespaces. Exposes Kubernetes APIs, backed by native vSphere primitives. So conceptually, Supervisor is vSphere operating in "Kubernetes-native mode".
Supervisor Namespaces are not Kubernetes namespaces.If classic vSphere is "run VMs", Supervisor vSphere is "Run anything (VMs, Pods, services)" with the same primitives.
Supervisor runs on ESX. It enables Kubernetes semantics backed by vSphere primitives.
VCF Automation is optional and sits above Supervisor.
Supervisor Namespaces look like Kubernetes namespace on purpose.vSphere (authoritative substrate) └── Supervisor ├── Kubernetes API (authoritative for some things) └── vSphere API/UI (authoritative for others) There is no promise that: every UI action has a YAML equivalent or that YAML is the “source of truth” for all infra Instead: some things are Kubernetes-first some things remain vSphere-first Kubernetes manifest → vSphere policy enforcement. Create VMs via VirtualMachine CRDs (VM Operator) Create Pods / Deployments Attach storage Attach networks (within guardrails) PVCs backed by vSphere storage policies Datastore selection via StorageClasses Policy-based placement Declare “I need this secret” Injector materializes it VCF Secret Service enforces access
Pods/VMs attach to NSX-backed segments Load balancers exposed via K8s Service abstractions You don’t manage NSX topology in YAML, but you consume it declaratively. Infrastructure topology Tenancy and Governance constructs (Organization, Projects, Quoatas at Provider level, Approval, Chargeback) Those live in VCF Automation / vSphere UI, not Kubernetes. So: vSphere Supervisor exposes a Kubernetes-native API surface for workload consumption (pods, VMs, storage, networking), while infrastructure topology, tenancy, and governance remain vSphere- and Automation-controlled.

headers.heading: Things Can Be Declaratively Done via k8s
What You Cannot Do in K8s Declaratively
