vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/vsphere.html.title: vSphere
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/vsphere.html.description:
At its core, vSphere is a compute, storage, and network abstraction layer: A distributed operating system for data centers.It manages large collections of infrastructure, such as CPUs, storage, networking, GPUs, and DPUs as a seamless and dynamic operating environment, and also manages the complexity of a data center.  It virtualizes physical infrastructure into managed CPU, storage, and networking resources.vSphere ├── ESX (data plane) ├── vCenter Server (control plane) └── Integrated services (HA, DRS, vMotion, etc.) vSphere is a distributed system that provides the following:The two core components of VMware vSphere are ESX and vCenter.
Whereas vSphere Client is the Web UI that interacts with the APIs of vSphere components.vSphere is a product contract, not a system.
ESX and vCenter are the systems that implement that contract.Here is how vSphere facilitates LCM:
Lifecycle management via pre-staging ESX images.
Near-zero-downtime live patching for ESX.
vSphere as a platform, manages workload performance in several dimensions: With its GPU support, vSphere improves workload performance for modern AI workloads
DRS enables automatic load balancing of resources allocated to workloads in a vSphere Cluster. Storage DRS optimizes VM data placement as the VM is created and used over time. Moving workloads seamlessly across the fabric, and ensuring things are always ship-shape, is what vSphere excels at:
High Availability with vSphere automatically restarts your VMs following physical machine failure.
Fault Tolerance provides continuous availability of any application in the event of a hardware failure with no data loss or downtime.
vMotion enables live migration of virtual machines with no disruption to users or loss of service, eliminating the need to schedule application downtime for planned server maintenance. Storage vMotion avoids downtime for planned storage maintenance. At vSphere security is by default, not an afterthought:
Identity Federation with Microsoft Entra ID, ADFS and Okta. Virtual Machine Encryption: Data-at-rest encryption for virtual machine data and disks.
vSphere Trust Authority: Remote attestation for sensitive workloads. Yesn’t.Saying “vSphere is ‘ESX and vCenter’.” is colloquially common, but technically incomplete.
See vSphere, ESX, and vCenter for a more nuanced analysis.
You might also want to check vSphere Constructs for an idea of what vSphere directly controls, and what capabilities it has.
You might want to check out vCenter Server, one of the core components that makes vSphere, vSphere.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/vsphere.html.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/vcf-enablers/vcf-installer/vcf-fleet.title: VCF Fleet Deployment
vcf/vcf-enablers/vcf-installer/vcf-fleet.description:
There are several different way you can deploy a VCF Fleet, each with its own benefits and liabilities.


This model is ideal for organizations seeking a streamlined and scalable approach to deploying within a single availability zone or region. The design provides centralized management, enabling a unified framework for managing instances and vCenters through a single VCF Operations instance.
This is typically the first (and robust) starting point for deploying the first VCF Instance, with the flexibility to expand to multiple instances while maintaining centralized operations and automation.
This is an ideal choice for organizations that require robust protection against site-wide failures and the ability to recover critical workloads in the event of a disaster.By building upon the former deployment design, this approach integrates disaster recovery capabilities to ensure business continuity.
It leverages VMware's advanced tools and technologies, such as VMware Live Recovery, to enable seamless failover and failback between sites or regions. This design ensures that critical workloads are replicated and protected, minimizing downtime and data loss during unexpected events.Additionally, it supports flexible deployment models, including Single-Rack and Multi-Rack configurations, to meet diverse infrastructure needs.
VMware Cloud Foundation Operations utilizes replication or backup and restore mechanisms to protect components at a secondary site, while VMware Cloud Foundation Automation relies on backup and restore processes for recovery at the secondary site.VMware Cloud Foundation Operations utilizes replication or backup and restore mechanisms to protect components at a secondary site, while VMware Cloud Foundation Automation relies on backup and restore processes for recovery at the secondary site.

This is another Fleet Deployment topology with Fault Domains and Disaster Recovery, combining Disaster Recovery and High Availability capabilities.
You might want to switch gears and check out VCF SDKs, APIs, and CLIs.
vcf/vcf-enablers/vcf-installer/vcf-fleet.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/vcf-enablers/vcf-installer/vcf-insta.title: VCF Installer
vcf/vcf-enablers/vcf-installer/vcf-insta.description:
VCF Installer is the one-time (or rare-use) bootstrap and bring-up tool for VMware Cloud Foundation.
VCF Installer’s sole purpose is to stand up the very first VCF environment and hand control over to SDDC Manager.
If SDDC Manager is the factory control system, VCF Installer is the factory construction crew that builds the factory in the first place.
VCF Installer exists to answer a very specific question: “Given raw hardware, how do I get to a fully functional VCF Management Domain with SDDC Manager running?” Once that answer is executed successfully, VCF Installer is done.VCF Installer is responsible for: Validating hardware readiness Validating network configuration Validating DNS / NTP / IPAM Validating credentials and certificates Orchestrating the initial deployment of:
ESX on hosts
vCenter Server
NSX
SDDC Manager itself
Management Domain components
This is Day-0 only work.Before anything is deployed, VCF Installer runs extensive prechecks, including: Hardware compatibility (HCL alignment) Network reachability MTU consistency IP pool correctness Time synchronization DNS forward/reverse lookup Credential access Think of it as a fail-fast safety gate: Better to stop early than build a broken cloud.VCF Installer typically operates with: Structured input (JSON / guided wizard) Explicit topology definitions Explicit IP assignments You declare what you want, and the installer executes a deterministic build.There is no concept of “incremental evolution” here: That belongs to SDDC Manager.It is not: A lifecycle manager A long-running control plane A tenant or consumption interface A policy engine An operations tool After bring-up: It is not used daily It does not manage upgrades It does not manage workload domains
Those responsibilities move entirely to the SDDC Manager.Once installation completes:
SDDC Manager becomes the authoritative owner VCF Installer steps out of the picture You can think of it as: VCF Installer creates SDDC Manager; SDDC Manager creates and manages everything else. A natural question is: “Why not just use SDDC Manager from the start?”Because: SDDC Manager itself must be deployed That deployment requires validated sequencing That sequencing must run before SDDC Manager exists VCF Installer solves this bootstrapping paradox. VCF Installer → kubeadm init
SDDC Manager → Kubernetes control plane (after init)
VCF Automation → Higher-level UX / APIs for consumers You don’t run kubeadm init every day, and you don’t run VCF Installer every day either. VCF Installer is a Day-0 tool It bootstraps the Management Domain
It deploys the SDDC Manager itself It performs strict prechecks and validation After success, it is effectively retired
Why not look into VCF Fleet Deployment?

headers.heading: Relationship to SDDC Manager

vcf/vcf-enablers/vcf-installer/vcf-insta.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/vcf-enablers/gated-sdk.html.title: Gated SDK
vcf/vcf-enablers/gated-sdk.html.description:
VCF Gated SDK is a RESTful SDK around everything VCF.The VCF Gated SDK refers to the VMware Cloud Foundation Software Development Kit that is not publicly downloadable without authentication: You need to be an authorized VMware/Broadcom customer or partner to access it.So, “Gated” here means governed access, not technical limitation.In practice, “gated” means: You must log in to the Broadcom Developer Portal with valid credentials. Access is typically tied to an active support contract or partner agreement. The SDK download link is hidden until your account is verified for entitlement. VCF Gated SDK provides Java and Python libraries, API bindings, utilities, and sample code to automate and integrate with VMware Cloud Foundation. Contains proprietary VMware/Broadcom code. Ensures only licensed customers/partners can use it. Helps control distribution of sensitive API bindings and internal tooling. VCF is not a generic API platform; it is a validated system. Some APIs: Control core lifecycle Mutate global topology Bypass normal UI guardrails Can easily create unsupported states Exposing these APIs broadly would: Fragment platform behavior Break upgrade guarantees Explode support matrices So VMware/Broadcom chooses controlled exposure instead of full openness.Gated SDKs often include APIs that: Drive SDDC Manager internal workflows Orchestrate LCM sequencing Mutate domain-level state machines Access pre-GA or evolving models Bypass tenant-safe abstractions These are platform-builder APIs, not tenant or end-user APIs.A Gated SDK usually implies one or more of the following: Explicit enablement flag Contractual agreement Limited documentation access No backward-compatibility guarantees Direct escalation path to engineering Strong expectations of platform literacy You are expected to know what you are doing.A Gated SDK is official, but not democratized.It is not: Unsupported A hack A private backdoor A “use at your own risk” API It is supported; but with conditions.If you see something described as a Gated SDK, it usually signals: “This is powerful” “This can break invariants” “This is for platform-level integration” “You need approval and discipline” In other words: This is not a convenience API — it is a responsibility API. A Gated SDK is an official but restricted VCF SDK It protects lifecycle safety and supportability It is intended for platform builders, not tenants Access implies higher expectations and accountability It exists to balance power vs stability
You might want to explore other core VCF concepts from here.

headers.heading: Why Gated SDKs Exist in VCF

vcf/vcf-enablers/gated-sdk.html.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/vcf-enablers/vcf-sdks,-apis,-and-cli.title: VCF SDKs, APIs, and CLIs
vcf/vcf-enablers/vcf-sdks,-apis,-and-cli.description:
In VMware Cloud Foundation, “VCF SDK APIs and CLIs” are programmable control surfaces that expose VCF capabilities for automation, integration, and at-scale operations. They sit above the infrastructure components (vCenter, NSX, vSAN) and below higher-level portals, giving you deterministic, supportable ways to drive the platform.┌──────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ Portals / UIs │ │ - VCF Automation UI │ │ - SDDC Manager UI │ ├──────────────────────────────────────────────┤ │ SDK APIs & CLIs ← YOU ARE HERE │ │ - REST APIs │ │ - Official CLIs │ │ - Language SDKs (where provided) │ ├──────────────────────────────────────────────┤ │ Platform Control Planes │ │ - SDDC Manager │ │ - VCF Automation │ ├──────────────────────────────────────────────┤ │ Product APIs │ │ - vCenter / NSX / vSAN │ └──────────────────────────────────────────────┘
VCF APIs abstract platform intent (*domains, lifecycle, tenancy**), not raw hypervisor knobs.SDDC Manager REST APIs expose everything SDDC Manager knows and controls: Bring-up and expansion
Workload Domain lifecycle Host add/remove
Cluster creation End-to-end upgrades (LCM) Inventory, versions, and health These APIs are the authoritative way to automate VCF without breaking supportability. If it changes VCF topology or lifecycle, it goes through SDDC Manager APIs. CI/CD pipelines Infrastructure-as-Code tools
Day-2 automation frameworks Internal platforms and runbooks
These are about consumption and Governance.APIs for tenant-facing operations such as:
Organizations and Projects Policies and approvals
Blueprints / templates Workload provisioning (VMs, Kubernetes-backed services) These APIs sit closer to business intent than infrastructure detail. SDDC Manager APIs → Build and maintain the cloud VCF Automation APIs → Consume the cloud These are both human and also script friendly.Used for: Diagnostics Operational workflows Automation-friendly scripting Break-glass scenarios It is a thin wrapper over SDDC Manager APIs, with guardrails.This is: A faster iteration than REST during ops An easier integration into shell scripts Provides consistent auth and context handling CLIs are not separate systems — they are API clients.These are language bindings.Where available, VMware/Broadcom provides SDKs that wrap REST APIs in native language constructs: Object models Typed requests/responses Auth helpers Pagination, retries, error handling These SDKs are ideal when: You are building a platform or product You need maintainable, testable code Shell scripts are no longer enough They do not:
Replace vCenter or NSX APIs Provide low-level tuning knobs Allow unsupported lifecycle paths Let you bypass validation logic
This is by design. VCF optimizes for predictability and supportability over raw flexibility. Git declares desired domains / versions Pipeline calls SDDC Manager APIs Platform converges safely Internal UI talks to VCF Automation APIs End users never see infrastructure details Health checks Controlled upgrades Capacity expansion All API-driven, no UI clicks. VCF SDK APIs are the supported automation surface SDDC Manager APIs control lifecycle and topology VCF Automation APIs control consumption and governance CLIs are just API clients Using these APIs preserves VCF invariants and supportability
Since it’s related to APIs, you might want to check out what a Gated SDK is.

headers.heading: What VCF APIs Intentionally Do Not Do

vcf/vcf-enablers/vcf-sdks,-apis,-and-cli.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/vcf-enablers/vcf-sdks,-apis,-and-cli.sourcePath: VCF/VCF Enablers/VCF SDKs, APIs, and CLIs.md

vcf/about-vcf.html.title: About VCF
vcf/about-vcf.html.description:
VCF is a full-stack Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) platform that delivers software-defined compute, storage, networking, security, and management.
Integrated automation enables a self-service platform to deploy VMs and containers for developer agility. Hardened platform offering built-in resilience, scaling, and clustering for non-stop operations.
It provides automation and orchestration to simplify Day 0, Day 1, and Day 2 tasks. It simplifies full stack deployment.
The purpose of VCF is to design, plan, deploy, and manage your SDDC by using automation capabilities.VMware Cloud Foundation is a unified private-cloud platform that combines the scale and agility of public cloud with security and performance of private cloud. delivering increased productivity and lower Total Cost of Ownership ([TCO](Total Cost of Ownership)).VCF consists of the following parts:These are the heavy-lifters of VCF.
vSphere (compute and VM runtime)
vSAN (storage)
NSX (networking and security) Management Plane is about platform control and lifecycle management.
VCF Operations (visibility, health, and optimization)
VCF Automation (provisioning, policy, and workflows) These are meta components. They neither run workloads, nor operate them directly. They enable installation, integration, and extensibility.
VCF Installer
VCF SDKs, APIs, and CLIs
VMware Live Recovery
VMware Data Services Manager
VCF Business Services Console
VCF Usage Meter
VMware Cloud
VMware Skyline
Cloud Services Console
Gated SDK
Governance
STIG
VCF Roles and Permissions
VCF Single Sign-On
VCF Identity Broker
VCF builds, manages, operates, secures, monitors, and govern an entire Private Cloud. Deploy a new VCF platform Converge existing virtual infrastructure to a new VCF platform.
Deploy a Workload Domain
Import an existing vCenter instance to a Workload Domain.
Add a vSphere Cluster or an ESX host to a Workload Domain.
Configure vSAN Stretched Cluster
Manage network connectivity using NSX Edge Clusters and Transit Gateways in vCenter Manage virtual infrastructure in vCenter Licensing Configure IAM and SSO Link vCenter instances for centralized inventory management
Manage certificates across the VCF Fleet Manage password across the VCF Fleet Manage tags across the VCF Fleet Manage the configuration settings of vCenter instances and vSphere Clusters. Backup and restore the VCF Fleet and its managed VCF Instances Migrate workloads across Workload Domains and vCenter instances
Deploy and configure vSphere Supervisor for running Kubernetes Workloads and VM Workloads Licensing Configure alerts Perform log analysis and troubleshooting Monitor network operations Monitor storage operations Perform infrastructure diagnostics and VCF health monitoring Configure and use monitoring dashboard and monitoring reports Workload monitoring and observability Manage cost and capacity Mitigate security risks Enforce security compliance Manage infrastructure, identity, and access across consumer organizations
Manage vSAN storage
Manage networking in NSX
Link vCenter instances for centralized inventory management
Manage certificates across the VCF Fleet
Manage passwords across the VCF Fleet
Manage tags across the VCF Fleet
Manage the configuration settings of vCenter instances and vSphere Clusters.
Prepare the collection of VM-base workload Blueprints and infrastructure services for the organization and end users Provision VMs Provision Kubernetes clusters
Provision vSphere Pods Provision persistent volumes Provision secret stores Install container registries
After this summary, checking out vSphere—one of the core abstraction layers of VCF—could provide further clarity.

vcf/vmware-cloud-foundation.html.title: VMware Cloud Foundation
vcf/vmware-cloud-foundation.html.description:
VMware Cloud Foundation (VCF) is a unified platform to design, plan, deploy, and manage your SDDC by using automation capabilities.That is one of the core tenents of VCF, and thus, it requires clarification before anything else.In VCF-speak, the phrase “a workload is a workload” is not a tautology—it’s a deliberate abstraction boundary.It means that VCF intentionally collapses many very different execution models into a single management concept, and refuses to care about their internal form unless it must.Below is the precise meaning, layered from philosophy, to architecture, to consequences.From VCF’s point of view, a workload is simply “something that consumes resources and is governed by policy.”It is not:
a VM a Container
a Pod VM
a Kubernetes pod
a Guest Cluster a Helm release Those are implementation details.VCF asks only: Where does it run? Who owns it? What resources does it consume? What policies apply? What lifecycle rules govern it? If those questions can be answered, VCF is satisfied.VCF exists above:
ESX
vSphere Clusters
vSphere Supervisor Kubernetes
VKS
VMs Containers If VCF tried to manage each kind of workload differently, it would: explode in complexity duplicate logic couple business policy to runtime mechanics So instead, VCF defines: Workload = Policy + Placement + Lifecycle + Resources Everything else is delegated downward.All of the following are equally valid workloads in VCF:VCF deliberately does not rank or privilege any of these.In VCF, a workload is anything that consumes platform resources and is subject to platform policy—its internal shape is intentionally irrelevant. VCF intentionally erases runtime distinctions Governance > implementation
Supervisor is the abstraction bridge If two things consume resources and obey policy, VCF treats them identically
vSphere Supervisor makes it possible.
vSphere Supervisor converts:
Pods to lightweight VMs
Kubernetes objects to vSphere-managed entities
Namespaces to policy and tenancy units From below, everything is Kubernetes.
From above, everything is vSphere resources. VCF sits above Supervisor, so it sees:
Resource Pools
Namespaces Quotas
Policies The kind or form of the workload becomes irrelevant.VCF does not care: whether the workload uses containerd or not
whether it’s a PodVM or classic VM whether it runs Go, Java, or Bash whether it was deployed via Helm, kubectl, or Terraform whether it is “cloud-native” or “legacy” Those are runtime-layer concerns, not platform-layer concerns. A power grid doesn’t care if you plug in a toaster or a server rack—only how much power you draw and what safety rules apply. This is why statements like these are true: “Pod workloads are not special.” “VM workloads are not special.” “Guest clusters are just workloads.” “Infrastructure doesn’t care about your app model.” So, you don’t fight against the platform to fit the workload in; you design the workload to fit the platform’s (opinionated) invariants.To internalize VCF, don’t think in: Pods vs VMs Containers vs Processes Control Planes vs Data Planes
Instead, think in Governance: Who owns this? What are its limits? How is it created and destroyed? How does it fail? How is it audited? Don’t anchor your designs to what runs. Anchor them to how they are governed.If this does not make sense initially, give it some time and revisit this page once you navigate this website further. I assure you it will eventually click.
For now, let’s keep a mental note of this, and dive deeper into the VCF rabbit hole.

headers.heading: A Workload is a Workload is a Workload
But, Why Does VCF Need This Abstraction

index.html.title: index
index.html.description:
Disclaimer This site contains my personal notes and understanding of VMware Cloud Foundation. It reflects my own learning journey and mental models. Although I conducted an extensive research to keep things consistent and factually accurate, due to the fast-evolving nature of VCF, the content on this site may be incomplete, outdated, or incorrect. THIS IS NOT OFFICIAL DOCUMENTATION. For authoritative and up-to-date information, please refer to the official VMware Cloud Foundation Documentation. This site is not affiliated with, endorsed by, or sponsored by Broadcom, Inc. VMware, VMware Cloud Foundation, and related marks are trademarks of Broadcom, Inc., or its subsidiaries. ^ That part taken care of, let’s get this rolling, shall we?Although its features degrade gracefully, this website is best experienced on a desktop browser (instead of a mobile browser), where you can navigate the graph view, and pin articles.It is specifically designed to give a more IDE-like experience.
This knowledge base is organized around mental models, not product marketing or step-by-step tutorials.If you are new, I recommend starting with one of the paths below, depending on what you are trying to understand.
If you are a visual learner, The Big Picture should possibly be the first thing to look at before diving any deeper: It nicely outlines how various VCF components and concepts link together.
Also, the concept of tenancy is a fundamental part of VCF, and it touches everything: I have tagged anything that directly or indirectly ties to tenancy with the #tenancy tag. Just tap on the #tenancy tag, and you will see list of relevant pages filtered on the navigation section.If you want to understand what VCF is and how its major pieces fit together:
→ VMware Cloud Foundation
→ VCF Concepts
→ Tenancy in VCFThis path focuses on structure, roles, and boundaries rather than implementation details.If you are interested in what actually runs and where workloads live:
→ vSphere
→ vSphere Supervisor
→ VKS
This path explains the execution model, including VMs, Pods, Supervisor Namespaces, and Guest Clusters.If you are trying to understand who controls what and how lifecycle and operations are handled:
→ VCF Automation
→ VCF OperationsThis path is useful for architects, platform engineers, and operators.If your focus is on guardrails rather than features:
→ Governance
→ STIG
→ VMware Validated Solutions
→ VMware CloudThis path covers cross-cutting concepts that influence design and operations.This content of this site is intentionally organized semantically, rather than taxonomically. So you will likely find the “graph view” (on the right) more useful than the folder navigation (on the left).Hope you enjoy the ride,
Volkan.
Unless explicitly stated otherwise, the content on this website is distributed under a  licenseCC-BY-NC-SA 4.0.
Images on this site are used for informational and illustrative purposes. Some originate from publicly available sources and may not carry explicit attribution. If you are a rights holder and require attribution, modification, or removal, please contact me and the request will be addressed promptly.

secrets-federation-notes.html.title: Secrets Federation Notes
secrets-federation-notes.html.description:
#todo TODO: remove this from the docs once I have a good enough template for the solution. Many tenants (Pepsi, Coca Cola, Sprite, Pizza Hut) Each tenant has an external Vault (or Vault instance) with paths that can overlap: credentials/db/finance is a common example Sync into an internal OpenBao (or internal Vault) via ESO Inject into workloads via Vault Sidecar Injector You want no path collisions and no possibility of cross-tenant access There are two separate problems: Storage namespace collision in internal OpenBao Runtime authorization when workloads fetch secrets (injection)
Note: Only Organization Administrator is able to create secrets in the current system; not sure if the same applies for the VCF Secret Service. That’s something to keep in mind. See VCF Roles and Permissions this is the first half of the problem.Based on the official VCF Secret Service docs, a lot of the “last-mile consumption” is already solved (create secret → store it → inject it into pods/VMs as files), but tenancy isolation is explicitly coarse and largely stops at the Supervisor Namespace boundary. It’s there, but it’s not the fine-grained. That is any OpenBao secret bound to a namespace is visible to any workload in that namespace.That should be fine since tenants are effectively namespace-bound.The “Managing Secrets…” doc spells out delivery formats: vSphere Pods → file mount under /vault/secrets/<user-provided-name> VM Service VMs → disk-based transfer + read-only mount VKS (guest) cluster pods → file mount similar to vSphere Pods This solves consistent delivery semantics per workload type. All service accounts have read access to all secrets of that namespace. ^ that is the granularity we get. Which may or may not be fine based on the customers’ requirements.Also it’s worth noting that any notion of Organization/Project tenancy in the Secret Store model does not exist by architecture (which is also fine because secrets are namespace-bound, and tenants are also namespace-bound).None of the flows refer to Organization/Project at all. They are consistently “pick a Supervisor namespace; secrets live there”.That’s consistent with what we discussed earlier: governance constructs don’t appear at runtime.The docs show a pattern like secret/data/<namespace>/<secretName> for retrieval. Secrets are stored in a “corresponding namespace” (meaning: per Supervisor namespace). VKS isolation is only at Supervisor namespace level (explicit). Within a namespace, all service accounts can read all secrets (explicit). So the tenancy story is not missing — it’s just coarse: Tenant isolation = Supervisor Namespace isolation (and nothing finer is guaranteed). A safe mapping consistent with the doc’s retrieval convention would look like: External: credentials/db/finance Internal: secret/data/<supervisor-namespace>/credentials/db/finance (or secret/data/<supervisor-namespace>/<some-secret-name> that contains those K/Vs) That avoids cross-tenant collisions because the Supervisor namespace becomes the first path segment.According to the docs, all tenants share the same unified internal secrets store (OpenBao).In the doc’s annotation model, you specify a secret “path” in the injector annotation. They show: vault.hashicorp.com/agent-inject-secret-...: "secret/data/demo/db-cred" Inject Secrets in to a vSphere … So for Pepsi, if you used the flattened name approach, you’d inject like: secret/data/pepsi/auth__finance__db__creds …and because the auth role is tied to the namespace (example role demo), Pepsi workloads would authenticate with role pepsi and read from the pepsi/* prefix. ✅ In this doc model, within a tenant’s Supervisor namespace, any Pepsi workload can access any Pepsi secret. ❌ Restricting secrets to only pods in a specific Kubernetes namespace inside the tenant is not supported here (especially for VKS guest clusters). ✅ OpenBao paths look like secret/data/<supervisor-namespace>/<secretName> (KV v2 style). ✅ In shared OpenBao, prevent collisions by ensuring the first path segment is the tenant namespace (pepsi, cocacola, …). VCF Secret Store Service does have guardrails that prevent a Coca-Cola workload from mounting Pepsi secrets, as long as you stay within the supported model.But those guardrails are namespace-scoped, not “tenant-aware in the abstract”, and they rely on how identities and roles are provisioned, not on OpenBao magically inferring tenancy.The guardrails are not: “OpenBao automatically understands tenants” “Vault paths are globally protected by magic” They are: The Vault/OpenBao token that a workload receives is issued in the context of a specific Supervisor Namespace. That token is not shared across namespaces. So: A Coca-Cola workload never gets the same token as a Pepsi workload Tokens are not reusable across namespaces This is enforced by Supervisor, not by Kubernetes RBAC alone.The injector examples in the docs consistently show: a role name tied to the namespace (e.g. demo) secrets read from secret/data/<namespace>/... That implies (and matches how VMware typically wires these systems): Each Supervisor Namespace has a corresponding OpenBao role and policy. You don’t see the policy YAML in the docs, but the model only works if: role pepsi → policy allows secret/data/pepsi/* role cocacola → policy allows secret/data/cocacola/* Otherwise the examples would be unsafe. A pod can’t just arbitrarily say: vault.hashicorp.com/agent-inject-secret-foo: secret/data/pepsi/db from another namespace, because: the injector runs with Supervisor context the auth role used is bound to the namespace the token issued is constrained by that role So even if a Coca-Cola pod requests a Pepsi path, the read fails. That’s the critical point: request ≠ authorization. ref: “All service accounts have read access to all secrets of that namespace.” That sentence is not saying: “All namespaces can read all secrets.” It’s saying: “Within one Supervisor Namespace, we don’t give you finer-grained scoping.” If we ensure that: Pepsi secrets are materialized under secret/data/pepsi/... Coca-Cola secrets under secret/data/cocacola/... Then VCF Secret Store Service guardrails already align with that: Pepsi workloads authenticate as “Pepsi namespace” Pepsi role can only read secret/data/pepsi/* Coca-Cola role cannot read Pepsi paths So yes: If we respect the namespace-prefix contract, the rest of the consumption plumbing is already handled safely by VCF Secret Store Service. We are not punching a hole in the security model by doing the sync.The model breaks only if you bypass the intended trust boundaries, for example: A single ESO instance with a token that can write/read all tenant prefixes Manually creating secrets in the wrong namespace Reusing roles or tokens across namespaces Exposing OpenBao externally and letting workloads authenticate out-of-band Those are operator errors, not product gaps — but they’re exactly what auditors look for.VCF Secret Store Service enforces tenant isolation at the Supervisor Namespace boundary by issuing namespace-scoped identities and policies for secret access. As long as tenant secrets are materialized under their corresponding namespace paths, cross-tenant secret access is prevented by design. Fine-grained intra-namespace isolation is intentionally not provided.

There is a Single OpenBao Instance

the-big-picture.html.title: The Big Picture
the-big-picture.html.description:
VMware Cloud Foundation (VCF) is a unified platform to design, plan, deploy, and manage your SDDC by using automation capabilities.That is one of the core tenents of VCF, and thus, it requires clarification before anything else.In VCF-speak, the phrase “a workload is a workload” is not a tautology—it’s a deliberate abstraction boundary.It means that VCF intentionally collapses many very different execution models into a single management concept, and refuses to care about their internal form unless it must.Below is the precise meaning, layered from philosophy, to architecture, to consequences.From VCF’s point of view, a workload is simply “something that consumes resources and is governed by policy.”It is not:
a VM a Container
a Pod VM
a Kubernetes pod
a Guest Cluster a Helm release Those are implementation details.VCF asks only: Where does it run? Who owns it? What resources does it consume? What policies apply? What lifecycle rules govern it? If those questions can be answered, VCF is satisfied.VCF exists above:
ESX
vSphere Clusters
vSphere Supervisor Kubernetes
VKS
VMs Containers If VCF tried to manage each kind of workload differently, it would: explode in complexity duplicate logic couple business policy to runtime mechanics So instead, VCF defines: Workload = Policy + Placement + Lifecycle + Resources Everything else is delegated downward.All of the following are equally valid workloads in VCF:VCF deliberately does not rank or privilege any of these.In VCF, a workload is anything that consumes platform resources and is subject to platform policy—its internal shape is intentionally irrelevant. VCF intentionally erases runtime distinctions Governance > implementation
Supervisor is the abstraction bridge If two things consume resources and obey policy, VCF treats them identically
vSphere Supervisor makes it possible.
vSphere Supervisor converts:
Pods to lightweight VMs
Kubernetes objects to vSphere-managed entities
Namespaces to policy and tenancy units From below, everything is Kubernetes.
From above, everything is vSphere resources. VCF sits above Supervisor, so it sees:
Resource Pools
Namespaces Quotas
Policies The kind or form of the workload becomes irrelevant.VCF does not care: whether the workload uses containerd or not
whether it’s a PodVM or classic VM whether it runs Go, Java, or Bash whether it was deployed via Helm, kubectl, or Terraform whether it is “cloud-native” or “legacy” Those are runtime-layer concerns, not platform-layer concerns. A power grid doesn’t care if you plug in a toaster or a server rack—only how much power you draw and what safety rules apply. This is why statements like these are true: “Pod workloads are not special.” “VM workloads are not special.” “Guest clusters are just workloads.” “Infrastructure doesn’t care about your app model.” So, you don’t fight against the platform to fit the workload in; you design the workload to fit the platform’s (opinionated) invariants.To internalize VCF, don’t think in: Pods vs VMs Containers vs Processes Control Planes vs Data Planes
Instead, think in Governance: Who owns this? What are its limits? How is it created and destroyed? How does it fail? How is it audited? Don’t anchor your designs to what runs. Anchor them to how they are governed.If this does not make sense initially, give it some time and revisit this page once you navigate this website further. I assure you it will eventually click.
For now, let’s keep a mental note of this, and dive deeper into the VCF rabbit hole.VMware Cloud FoundationAt its core, vSphere is a compute, storage, and network abstraction layer: A distributed operating system for data centers.It manages large collections of infrastructure, such as CPUs, storage, networking, GPUs, and DPUs as a seamless and dynamic operating environment, and also manages the complexity of a data center.  It virtualizes physical infrastructure into managed CPU, storage, and networking resources.vSphere ├── ESX (data plane) ├── vCenter Server (control plane) └── Integrated services (HA, DRS, vMotion, etc.) vSphere is a distributed system that provides the following:
The two core components of VMware vSphere are ESX and vCenter.
Whereas vSphere Client is the Web UI that interacts with the APIs of vSphere components.vSphere is a product contract, not a system.
ESX and vCenter are the systems that implement that contract.Here is how vSphere facilitates LCM:
Lifecycle management via pre-staging ESX images.
Near-zero-downtime live patching for ESX.
vSphere as a platform, manages workload performance in several dimensions: With its GPU support, vSphere improves workload performance for modern AI workloads
DRS enables automatic load balancing of resources allocated to workloads in a vSphere Cluster. Storage DRS optimizes VM data placement as the VM is created and used over time. Moving workloads seamlessly across the fabric, and ensuring things are always ship-shape, is what vSphere excels at:
High Availability with vSphere automatically restarts your VMs following physical machine failure.
Fault Tolerance provides continuous availability of any application in the event of a hardware failure with no data loss or downtime.
vMotion enables live migration of virtual machines with no disruption to users or loss of service, eliminating the need to schedule application downtime for planned server maintenance. Storage vMotion avoids downtime for planned storage maintenance. At vSphere security is by default, not an afterthought:
Identity Federation with Microsoft Entra ID, ADFS and Okta. Virtual Machine Encryption: Data-at-rest encryption for virtual machine data and disks.
vSphere Trust Authority: Remote attestation for sensitive workloads. Yesn’t.Saying “vSphere is ‘ESX and vCenter’.” is colloquially common, but technically incomplete.
See vSphere, ESX, and vCenter for a more nuanced analysis.
You might also want to check vSphere Constructs for an idea of what vSphere directly controls, and what capabilities it has.
You might want to check out vCenter Server, one of the core components that makes vSphere, vSphere.vSphereUse **NSX** as a network administrator for networking and automation for virtual machines, containers, or bare metal applications.NSX enables network connectivity, operations, and scale. It uses a software-defined approach to networking that spans data centers, clouds and application frameworks.NSX brings networking services closer to the application, whether running on virtual machines (VMs), containers or physical servers. This allows for a cloud operating model where networks can be provisioned and managed independently of the underlying hardware.NSX abstracts network services from the underlying hardware, enabling programmable infrastructure through APIs. You can implement policies and workflows to automate tasks like network provisioning, security enforcement, load balancing, streamlining operations, and improving efficiency.NSX provides a complete set of logical networking capabilities and services, including logical switching, routing, distributed load balancing, virtual private network (VPN), quality of service (QoS), and monitoring.Enable logical Layer 2 overlay extensions across a routed (Layer 3) fabric within and across data center boundaries.Dynamic routing between virtual networks that is performed in a distributed manner in the hypervisor kernel, and scale-out routing with active-active failover with physical routers. Static routing and dynamic routing protocols are supported, including support for IPv6.Complete data plane isolation among tenants with a separate routing table, network address translation (NAT), and edge firewall support in each VRF on the Support for bridging between VLANs configured on the physical network and NSX overlay networks, for seamless connectivity between virtual and physical workloads.Site-to-site and unmanaged VPN for cloud gateway services.By using NSX, you can move workloads between racks and data centers by decoupling them from the underlying networks.Centralized policy configuration and enforcement across multiple locations from a single pane of glass, enabling network-wide consistent policy, operational simplicity, and simplified disaster recovery architecture.Enable consistent networking and security across data center sites, and across private cloud boundaries, irrespective of underlying physical topology or cloud platform.
NSX can manage the provisioning, deployment, operations and retirement of networking infrastructure and applications from a central control pane. You can automate infrastructure operations and offload manual tasks with workflows and agile templating using tools such as VCF Automation, Terraform, and Ansible. 
VPCs provide isolated network environments within a shared infrastructure. You can use Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) constructs to provision and manage network resources to business units or project teams independently, with granular control over networking policies and resource allocation.
By creating projects, you can isolate security and networking objects across tenants in a single NSX deployment. You enable multi-tenant deployment and consumption of NSX services for the provider administrator and the tenants or organizations.
The provider administrator can create projects, assign users and groups, and allocate quotas to restrict the configurations available to the tenants.
#tenancyNSX
vSAN aggregates local or direct-attached capacity devices of all ESX hosts in a cluster and creates a single storage pool shared across all ESX hosts in the  vSAN cluster.Use **vSAN** as a VI administrator or storage administrator to enhance storage performance by aggregating local storage into a single shared pool across all hosts in a vSAN cluster.
You can use vSphere features that require shared storage, such as vSphere HA, vSphere vMotion, and vSphere DRS, without the need for external shared storage.vSAN provides operational consistency from edge to cloud, with complete visibility and lifecycle management of compute and storage from a single UI.You can perform consistent, VM-centric operations by using policy-based management. Within the vSAN ESA, per-VM policies increase flexibility of management, enabling compression policies, or customize data services on a per-VM basis.vSAN
VCF Automation enables IT teams and cloud service providers (CSPs) to deliver a self-service private cloud for AI, Kubernetes, and VM-based applications.
The solution simplifies the process of provisioning and scaling a multi-tenant private cloud with out-of-the-box Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) offerings, accelerating the time to market for applications while maintaining control using policy-based governance.VCF Automation provides governance at the request and lifecycle level—controlling who can deploy which patterns, under what constraints and approvals—while runtime security, drift detection, and continuous enforcement are handled by downstream platforms.
Governance
#tenancyVCF Automation has the following capabilities:
Cloud Services: Provides a set of cloud services to meet the needs of application teams
Provider Management: Supports IT teams and cloud service providers to effectively manage, deliver, and scale cloud services across multiple vCenter and VCF instances.
Organization Management: Provides capabilities that enable the organization administrator of a Line of Business or a tenant to further organize and govern resources allocated to them among application teams.
vSphere Supervisor: Provides the capability to run Kubernetes workloads directly on ESX hosts and to create upstream Kubernetes clusters within dedicated namespaces.( #todo: Further explanation needed ) VCF Automation
#tenancy
VCF Operations helps your organization build, manage, operate and secure your private cloud infrastructure by deploying and maintaining its fleet-level components, providing visibility and enhanced performance across the workload and infrastructure stack, and helping your organization stay compliant with regulatory standards and organizational guidelines.VCF Operations has these functional areas:
Fleet Management Enables operational consistency and efficient resource management of the VCF infrastructure at scale.
Operations Management Provides monitoring and optimization of performance, cost and capacity, and faster troubleshooting.
Workload Operations  Ensures that critical applications are running as expected.
Performance Monitoring Ensures applications have continuous access to resources
FinOps and Capacity Helps you analyze your infrastructure expenses and optimize capacity usage.
VCF Operations HCX Provides support for migrating and interconnecting workloads within and across VCF private cloud.
Security Management Provides security management to ensure that your VCF private cloud is operationally secure. VCF Operations does not: Own tenancy boundaries Gate workload creation Enforce business approval flows Define org/project constructs Those remain in:
VCF Automation
Supervisor Upstream automation layers VCF Operations observes those constructs after the fact.Day 0 / Day 1 → VCF-A - Who can create? - What can be created? - Under what policies? Day 2 → VCF-O - Is it healthy? - Is it over/under-utilized? - Is it behaving strangely? Here is a very high-level look at VCF’s control plane:VCF (the platform) ├── VCF Automation (formerly Aria Automation) ├── VCF Operations (formerly Aria Operations) ├── Supervisor / vSphere └── Workloads Here is how things looks from each layer’s point of view:
Once a workload cluster is instantiated in a Supervisor Namespace, it has no awareness of VCF Automation constructs such as Organization or Project—Those concepts exist only at the governance layer (VCF Automation) and are not part of the runtime execution model (Supervisor).
You might want to check out Operations Management, Performance Monitoring, or Workload Operations.VCF Operations



SDDC Manager is the foundational lifecycle-management and orchestration engine of VMware Cloud Foundation. It is responsible for deploying, configuring, upgrading, and maintaining the entire VCF stack as a single, validated system rather than as independent products.If you think of VCF as a factory-built private cloud, SDDC Manager is the factory control system that ensures every component is installed correctly, stays in a supported state, and evolves safely over time.
Also: in VCF 9.0, Broadcom’s docs state that SDDC Manager UI is being deprecated and that SDDC Manager workflows can now be found in VCF Operations and vSphere Client—so many “platform lifecycle” workflows show up there now. (TechDocs)SDDC Manager performs end-to-end lifecycle operations across the VCF stack: ESXi (hypervisor) vCenter Server NSX vSAN Optional components (Aria / Operations, Automation, etc.) Key characteristics: Uses validated upgrade bundles Enforces component compatibility Executes sequenced, automated upgrades Provides rollback and precheck logic This is not just patching — it’s system-level lifecycle orchestration.SDDC Manager is responsible for: Initial VCF bring-up Creating: Management Domain VI (Workload) Domains Adding: Hosts Clusters Workload domains Ensuring: Correct networking Correct certificate trust Correct inventory alignment Without SDDC Manager, you do not have VCF — only loosely assembled VMware products.SDDC Manager acts as the system-of-record for: What components exist Their versions Their relationships Their lifecycle state vCenter manages virtualization. SDDC Manager manages the cloud system itself.SDDC Manager enforces: Supported topologies Supported versions Supported upgrade paths If you try to: Upgrade NSX independently Modify components outside supported flows You risk breaking VCF supportability.This is intentional — VCF favors predictability over freedom.It is not: A tenant portal A developer platform A policy engine A workload orchestrator A replacement for vCenter, NSX Manager, or Kubernetes APIs Those functions live elsewhere (VCF Automation, Supervisor, vCenter, NSX, etc.).A useful mental model: SDDC Manager manages the cloud itself; everything else manages what runs inside that cloud. Without SDDC Manager: Enterprises would manually assemble components Version skew would be common Upgrades would be risky and expensive Supportability would collapse With SDDC Manager: VCF becomes repeatable Lifecycle becomes deterministic VMware/Broadcom can guarantee outcomes This is why SDDC Manager is non-optional in VCF. SDDC Manager → Kubernetes control plane for the cloud platform itself vCenter / NSX / vSAN → Kubernetes nodes & CNI & CSI VCF Automation → Higher-level API / UX for consumers Different layers, different responsibilities. SDDC Manager is the backbone of VCF It owns lifecycle, topology, and compatibility It enforces validated, supported states It is infrastructure-centric, not tenant-centric Without it, VCF does not exist as a product If you want, next we can: Contrast SDDC Manager vs VCF Automation Walk through a Day-0 / Day-1 / Day-2 flow with SDDC Manager Map SDDC Manager concepts to Kubernetes mental models SDDC Manager
VMware vCloud Director (VCD) is a cloud-management and multi-tenancy layer built on top of vSphere. It was designed primarily for service providers (ISPs, telcos, MSPs) to offer VMware-based clouds to multiple customers in a clean, isolated, self-service way. vSphere → virtualization engine (hypervisors, clusters, VMs) VCD → cloud abstraction + multi-tenant control plane VCF → opinionated full stack (compute + storage + networking + ops) vSphere does not have native multitenancy, VCD enables multitenancy. VCD → sell VMware-based cloud to others VCF Automation → run your own internal cloud Cloud Layer ──────────── vCloud Director ← multi-tenant cloud manager Automation Layer ──────────── VCF Automation / Aria Automation Infrastructure ──────────── vSphere + vSAN + NSX Hardware ──────────── Bare metal



No. vSphere = hypervisor + cluster management VCD = separate product that consumes vSphere
VMware’s product web pages for Cloud Director explicitly state that VCD operates within the VMware Cloud Foundation platform as an integrated cloud-management layer: VCD is described as helping to “[efficiently […] operate and manage your managed private and public cloud services using VMware Cloud Director within the VMware Cloud Foundation platform](VMware Cloud Director | Leading Cloud Service Delivery Platform.However, in the baseline VCF component lists and core architectural docs, the docs list things like vSphere, vSAN, NSX, SDDC Manager, VCF Automation but not VCD as a base building block. *Historically: no. Today: “it depends on the SKU and use case.”** VMware Cloud Foundation (VCF) is aimed at: Enterprises Private cloud Platform teams
Automation (VCF Automation) VMware vCloud Director (VCD) is aimed at: Service providers Telcos Hosted private cloud Customer-facing tenancy VCF does not require VCD, and most enterprise VCF deployments do not use it.vCloud Director
VCF is a full-stack Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) platform that delivers software-defined compute, storage, networking, security, and management.
Integrated automation enables a self-service platform to deploy VMs and containers for developer agility. Hardened platform offering built-in resilience, scaling, and clustering for non-stop operations.
It provides automation and orchestration to simplify Day 0, Day 1, and Day 2 tasks. It simplifies full stack deployment.
The purpose of VCF is to design, plan, deploy, and manage your SDDC by using automation capabilities.VMware Cloud Foundation is a unified private-cloud platform that combines the scale and agility of public cloud with security and performance of private cloud. delivering increased productivity and lower Total Cost of Ownership ([TCO](Total Cost of Ownership)).VCF consists of the following parts:These are the heavy-lifters of VCF.
vSphere (compute and VM runtime)
vSAN (storage)
NSX (networking and security) Management Plane is about platform control and lifecycle management.
VCF Operations (visibility, health, and optimization)
VCF Automation (provisioning, policy, and workflows) These are meta components. They neither run workloads, nor operate them directly. They enable installation, integration, and extensibility.
VCF Installer
VCF SDKs, APIs, and CLIs
VMware Live Recovery
VMware Data Services Manager
VCF Business Services Console
VCF Usage Meter
VMware Cloud
VMware Skyline
Cloud Services Console

#tenancyGovernance in VCF is the set of mechanisms that decide who is allowed to request which platform capabilities, under what constraints, with what approvals, and for how long — before anything is created.
VCF Automation governs entitlement and lifecycle decisions, including lease expiry and grace periods, but vSphere Supervisor remains the execution authority and only acts when Automation explicitly requests a change. VCF-A governance is front-door, human-aware, policy-driven It’s about entitlement, approval, and lifecycle It is not a security monitoring system It is not a Terraform-style reconciler It is exactly what service providers and large enterprises need to avoid chaos What Governance is NOT:Governance does not watch workloads. It decides whether they are allowed to exist in the first place.Governance (VCF Automation) ├── Organizations ├── Projects ├── Blueprints ├── Entitlements ├── Approvals ├── Quotas └── Leases Execution (vSphere / Supervisor) ├── Namespaces ├── Resource pools ├── Networks └── Workloads Nothing in the execution layer knowns governance exists. Governance defines who may open the door. Execution decides what happens after they are inside the house. In other words, governance is “pre-creation” control, not runtime policing.
From here, Policy, Policy as Code, and STIG are all good candidates to check out.Governance
VMware Cloud Foundation Day 0 tasks are everything required to prepare and bootstrap the platform before any tenant, workload, or higher-level automation exists.
Think of Day 0 as laying the concrete and pouring the foundation—after this, you can build floors (VCF Day 1 Tasks) and move people in (VCF Day 2 Tasks). Day 0: Make the platform exist Day 1: Configure and extend the platform Day 2: Operate workloads on the platform VCF is very opinionated: nothing meaningful can happen until Day 0 is clean and correct.These are outside VCF but mandatory. Rack & cable hosts Power, cooling, BIOS/firmware NTP, DNS, IPAM VLANs / MTU (often jumbo frames) Out-of-band management (iDRAC / iLO) If this is wrong, everything later becomes “mysteriously flaky.”
Before VCF can orchestrate anything, ESX must exist.
Install ESX on all hosts Apply compatible firmware and drivers Validate hardware against VCF BOM Configure basic networking (vmnics, MTU) These hosts are raw compute, not yet part of any SDDC.This is the true start of VCF.
Deploy SDDC Manager Appliance Connect it to: DNS NTP Identity source Verify reachability to all ESX hosts From this point on, VCF owns lifecycle.This creates the core control plane SDDC.Includes automated deployment of:
vCenter Server
NSX Manager
vSAN
ESX Management Cluster This is where VCF becomes a self-hosting platform.After this, you no longer treat components individually.Baseline platform networking is established.
NSX fabric initialization Transport zones Edge nodes (management edges) Tier-0 / Tier-1 gateways Initial firewall policies This defines how everything can talk later.Foundational access control.
Integrate vCenter / SDDC Manager with: LDAP / AD / Identity Provider Define platform admin roles Secure service accounts Without this, automation has no authority.Often underestimated, always painful if skipped. CA strategy (internal vs external) TLS certificates for:
vCenter
NSX
SDDC Manager Trust alignment across components This is where future mTLS, OIDC, and zero-trust efforts live or die.This is about future safety. Validate VCF BOM Enable lifecycle management workflows Confirm patching & upgrade paths Confirm supportability state
If skipped, VCF Day 2 Tasks turns into firefighting. No tenants No projects No Supervisor Namespaces No Kubernetes workloads No automation pipelines No business logic Day 0 is pure platform plumbing. VCF Day 0 = platform existence It is non-negotiable and opinionated Focuses on infrastructure, identity, network, and lifecycle No tenants, no workloads, no business logic
Done right → VCF Day 1 Tasks and VCF Day 2 Tasks feel boring (the best outcome) VCF Day 0 Tasks
VMware Cloud Foundation Day 1 tasks start after the platform exists and focus on making it usable, consumable, and policy-driven—without yet running real business workloads.If Day 0 pours concrete, Day 1 frames the building and installs utilities. Day 0 → Platform exists Day 1 → Platform is configurable & consumable Day 2 → Platform is used & operated Day 1 is where intent, policy, and abstraction appear.This is where business structure enters the system.
Define Organizations
Define Projects Map projects to: Supervisor Namespaces Resource boundaries Define quotas and limits This is not Kubernetes yet—it’s VCF’s business abstraction layer.From “admins only” to multi-role access.
Define MERGE ME AND REPLACE INCOMING LINKS Tenant Admin roles Map identity groups to roles Separate:
Organization Administrators (colloquially known as Platform Admins)
Project Administrators (colloquially known as Tenant Admins) Developers Enable delegated self-service
This is where “secure Multi-Tenancy” becomes real.Networking shifts from fabric to consumption. Project-level networking Tenant Tier-1 gateways NAT, routing, firewall policies Load balancer enablement Network isolation per project Infrastructure networking (Day 0) becomes tenant networking.Turn raw storage into governed capacity. Define storage policies (performance, availability)
Assign policies to Projects
Enable vSAN / NFS / VMFS consumption Set quotas and constraints This prevents noisy neighbors and capacity abuse.Expose compute without exposing chaos. Define resource pools Assign clusters to projects Enable placement policies
Configure HA / DRS behavior Compute becomes schedulable capacity, not hardware.This is where container platforms appear.
Enable vSphere Supervisor Configure:
Supervisor Namespaces Kubernetes versions CNI / CSI integration
VKS clusters
Kubernetes exists because Day 1 enabled it, not because ESX magically does containers.Where humans stop clicking.
Enable VCF Automation
Define Blueprints Approval flows Day-1 actions exposed as APIs
Service Catalog creation This is the front door for tenants.This is preventative control, not enforcement after damage. Quotas Naming standards Placement constraints Lifecycle constraints Compliance policies Day 1 policies determine how painful Day 2 is.Before workloads, you need visibility. Enable logging pipelines Metrics collection Alert baselines Capacity visibility You can’t operate what you can’t see. No real business workloads No app-specific tuning No scaling incidents No break/fix operations Day 1 is still design-heavy, not ops-heavy. VCF Day 1 = platform enablement
Introduces tenancy, policy, automation No real workloads yet Sets the rules for everything that follows Good Day 1 → boring, predictable Day 2
Check out VCF Day 2 Tasks to see what comes after day one, where theory and preparation meets the challenges of real-world production workloads.VCF Day 1 Tasks
VMware Cloud Foundation Day 2 tasks begin once real workloads exist. This is where theory meets entropy: failures happen, usage grows, humans make mistakes, and the platform must keep working anyway.If: Day 0 pours the concrete Day 1 frames the building Day 2 is living in it for years Or: Day 0 → Existence Day 1 → Enablement Day 2 → Sustainment Day 2 is continuous, not a phase you “finish”.This is the obvious part—but it’s only the surface. Deploy workloads (VMs, Pods, clusters) Scale up/down Start / stop / suspend Migrate workloads Retire workloads Day 2 starts the feedback loop. Platform health monitoring Workload health monitoring Capacity tracking Performance baselines Alert tuning (noise reduction) Bad alerts = ignored alerts = outages.The real test of architecture. Host failures Network partitions Storage degradation Control plane issues Application outages Includes: [HA] / [DRS] behavior Failover validation Backup & restore DR testing
If this fails, Day 0 and Day 1 didn’t matter.Security shifts from design to enforcement. Certificate rotation Secret rotation Credential revocation Firewall rule changes Vulnerability remediation Audit and compliance reporting One of VCF’s core promises. [] patching
vCenter upgrades
NSX upgrades Kubernetes version upgrades Firmware alignment (BOM compliance) All while: Workloads are running SLAs are enforced This is why VCF is opinionated.Reality: resources are finite. Capacity planning Quota adjustments Overcommit tuning Chargeback / showback Cluster expansion This is where finance meets engineering.Day 1 defines policies. Day 2 fights drift. Detect misconfigurations Enforce standards Handle exceptions Reconcile “special cases” Without this, entropy wins.Day 2 success is measured socially, not technically. Self-service reliability Automation success rates Time-to-resource Support ticket volume Developer trust A stable platform feels boring. That’s success.Day 2 never freezes architecture. Introduce new workload types Add regions / clusters Enable new services Deprecate old patterns VCF must evolve without reset. VCF Day 2 = continuous operations Includes incidents, upgrades, security, scale
Validates Day 0 and Day 1 decisions Workload type becomes irrelevant Boring Day 2 is the highest compliment
Why not explore vCloud Director for a change, or VCF Fleet Deployment or VCF Installer as platform enablers.VCF Day 2 Tasks
#tenancy
In a VCF-based platform, tenant isolation is realized through vSphere Supervisor Namespaces, which serve as the enforced execution boundary for workloads.
A single tenant may be associated with one or more Supervisor Namespaces, typically aligned to Projects within an Organization.
Supervisor Namespaces provide hard isolation for compute, networking, storage, and identity, while VCF Automation operates above this layer to deliver governance, policy enforcement, and self-service without weakening those isolation guarantees.
In VMware Cloud Foundation, multi-tenancy does not mean soft separation within a shared runtime. Instead, it is defined by: Explicit tenant boundaries Platform-enforced isolation No cross-tenant visibility or control Lifecycle independence between tenants This design prioritizes predictability, security, and supportability over maximal flexibility.VCF intentionally separates administrative constructs from enforcement points.
Organizations and Projects define who can do what
Supervisor Namespaces define what can actually run and where
While Organizations and Projects are essential for governance and delegation, isolation becomes real only at the Supervisor Namespace layer.At this boundary, VCF enforces: Resource allocation and limits Network segmentation Storage policy enforcement Identity and access scoping A common tenant layout in VCF looks like this:
One Organization represents a tenant (i.e. Coca Cola)
One or more Project exists within that Organization (i.e. Dev / Staging / Prod)
Each Project (typically) maps to one Supervisor Namespace (but can map to more than one) A tenant may therefore own multiple namespaces, often separated by: Environment (dev / stage / prod) Application domain Regulatory or compliance boundary This model allows tenants to scale horizontally without eroding isolation.
VCF Automation provides the control plane for consumption, not the enforcement layer.It is responsible for: Self-service access to platform capabilities
Policy-driven approvals and quotas
Governance and auditability Abstraction of underlying platform complexity
VCF Automation:
Does not bypass Supervisor Namespace isolation Does not weaken platform guardrails Does not act as the isolation mechanism itself It governs access to platform-enforced boundaries—it does not replace them.If we think in layers:
Infrastructure layer: Hosts, clusters, networking, storage (operated outside VCF Automation)
Isolation layer: Supervisor Namespaces (hard tenant boundary)
Governance layer: Organizations and Projects (who can consume what)
Workload layer: VMs, Kubernetes clusters, and services Multi-tenancy in VCF emerges from the composition of these layers, not from any single construct. Supervisor Namespaces are the hard isolation boundary in VCF Organizations and Projects provide governance, not isolation Tenants may span multiple namespaces VCF Automation governs consumption without compromising isolation This layered design is foundational to VCF’s security and supportability Multi-Tenancy
#tenancy

A Policy in VCF is a Governance Rule that defines what is allowed, constrained, or enforced across infrastructure and workloads.
It exists across multiple layers of VCF, but it becomes a first-class, user-visible construct in VCF Automation.
If you think of VMware Cloud Foundation as a city: Infrastructure → roads, power, zoning Policies → zoning laws, speed limits, building codes
VCF Automation → city planning office that enforces them before you build
VCF Operations → inspectors that check compliance after things exist
These are foundational, implicit, and exist below VCF Automation, often enforced automatically.Examples: Storage policies (SPBM): RAID, availability, performance tiers
Network policies: NSX security groups, microsegmentation rules
Host policies: DRS, HA, admission control These are:
Defined in vSphere / NSX Consumed transparently by higher layers Not tenant-facing by default This is usually what people mean when they say “policy”.This is where Policy becomes a named, explicit, governable object.
In VCF Automation, policies define constraints and guardrails for consumers.Examples: Who can deploy what Where workloads can land What sizes, images, or networks are allowed Lease durations and approval requirements Typical policy categories: Placement policies: Which clusters, regions, zones Sizing policies: CPU, memory, storage limits Image policies: Approved OS images only Network policies: allowed networks / isolation Approval policies: manual gates for certain actions Lease policies: TTL and reclamation rules These policies are evaluated before provisioning.
In VCF Automation, policies are usually scoped to:
- Organizations
- or ProjectsThey act as guardrails, not implementation detailsExample: “In Project Prod, only Gold storage, max 16 vCPU, and approval required.” This is where policy intersects with consumption abstraction.
In **VCF Operations, policy ≠ enforcement.VCF Operations uses policy indirectly.
In VCF Operations: Policies become: Alerts Compliance checks Drift detection Optimization rules
VCF Operations answers: “Is reality still compliant with the policy?”
VCF Automation answers: “Should this action be allowed at all, in the first place?”
A Policy in VMware Cloud Foundation is a governance rule, not a single product feature
VCF Automation is where policies are: Explicit Named Scoped Evaluated before action
VCF Operations observes and reports compliance Infrastructure layers actually enforce the low-level mechanics
STIG can be an interesting topic that can complement policies.
You might also want to check out VCF Roles and Permissions.Policy
