Check out what governance means in the context of VCF.VCF Roles and PermissionsA Blueprint is a declarative deployment template that defines what can be requested, how it is configured, where it may land, and under which policies and approvals.
A VMware Cloud Foundation Design Blueprint is a prescriptive end-to-end design for a VCF Fleet in a commonly requested architecture topology, created to help accelerate time to value when building a new VMware Cloud Foundation platform.A Blueprint has a prescriptive selection of deployment models chosen from the design library to conform to the design profile of the Blueprint.A Blueprint an be deployed as is, with no alterations, or can be used as template where any of the deployment models can be substituted for alternatives from the same category within the design library. 
A Blueprint reflects the initial deployment of a VCF Fleet and supports expansion in a variety of ways to support the needs of your organization.A Blueprint provides a set of planning, implementation and design elements (requirements and recommendations) based on the chosen deployment models.
Blueprints in VCF Automation are governed deployment templates that define allowed workload patterns, configuration inputs, placement constraints, and approval policies. They orchestrate resource creation but are not part of the runtime execution layer.Once a deployment is created, the Blueprint can be deleted and the workload keeps running: It’s not part of the runtime layer.User ↓ Blueprint ← governance + intent ↓ Project ← who / where / policy ↓ Supervisor Namespace ↓ vSphere / Kubernetes runtime Kubernetes YAML answers: “How do I create this thing?” Blueprints answer: “Who is allowed to create which thing, under what rules, and with whose approval?”
Organization: business boundary (e.g. Verizon)
Project: governance scope (e.g. US-East)
Blueprint: allowed patterns inside that scope Organization: Verizon └── Project: US-East ├── Blueprint: Standard App VM ├── Blueprint: GPU Pod └── Blueprint: 3-Node K8s Cluster Each Blueprint: targets specific Supervisor Namespace(s) enforces constraints hides complexity from requesters Typically it defines:Examples: A VM A vSphere Pod A Guest Kubernetes cluster A multi-tier app (VM + LB + storage) CPU / memory sizes Environment variables Image versions Feature toggles Secret references (not secret values)
Which Supervisor Namespace(s) are allowed Which storage policies are allowed Which networks are allowed Size limits Placement rules Who can request it Who must approve it Lease duration Cost visibility / chargeback tags
In VMware Cloud Foundation, the terms template and blueprint are related but not interchangeable. They operate at different abstraction layers and serve different purposes in the lifecycle of infrastructure and workloads. A template defines what a single resource looks like A blueprint defines how multiple resources come together. A template is a reusable, preconfigured artifact that represents one resource, typically: VM Template A golden VM image (OS + patches + base software) Used to rapidly deploy identical VMs OVF/OVA Templates Portable packaged virtual appliances Content Library Templates
Shared across vCenter instances and VCF Domains Infrastructure-level Static Low abstraction No logic, no dependencies Consumed by automation tools (not orchestrating anything themselves) A Template says: “This is what a machine looks like when it’s born.” In contrast, a single Blueprint can define these following components: 2 application VMs 1 database VM A load balancer A network segment Placement rules Lifecycle actions That entire topology is deployed as one logical unit. Blueprints consume templates. Here is possible flow: Template: Ubuntu 22.04 VM with hardened baseline Blueprint: Uses that template Defines how many instances Attaches networks Applies policies Adds lifecycle logic So: Templates = building blocks Blueprints = architectural plans In Kubernetes terms (for intuition): Template ≈ Container Image Blueprint ≈ Helm Chart / Application Manifest Understanding this distinction prevents common mistakes: ❌ Treating templates as reusable environments ❌ Expecting templates to handle lifecycle logic ❌ Trying to encode business logic inside VM images Correct mental model: Templates are static Blueprints are dynamic and declarative As a quick comparison: Template → A reusable VM or image → Low-level, static, infrastructure-focused Blueprint → A declarative application/environment definition → High-level, orchestrated, lifecycle-aware
You might want to check concepts like Organizations, or Projects, which are related to Blueprints.Blueprint
Workflows consist of a schema, workflow variables, and input and output parameters.The workflow schema is the main component of a workflow as it defines all the workflow elements and the logical connections between them. The workflow variables and parameters are the properties that workflows use to transfer data.

In VMware Cloud Foundation, there isn’t a single “workflow engine” owned by only one product. Different parts of VCF create/execute different kinds of workflows:
VCF Automation is the place where you typically design and run “day-1” style workflows tied to requests (catalog items, provisioning, configuration, approvals, extensibility, etc.). Its value prop explicitly includes orchestration and extensibility.
Under the hood, these workflows commonly leverage an Orchestrator (formerly vRealize Orchestrator) integrated/embedded with the automation stack. It is executed by VCF Operations Orchestrator which is a part of the VCF Operations stack.
VCF Operations is primarily the ops brain: monitoring, alerting, capacity, compliance, etc.. It can run actions (and sometimes chain remediation) in response to alerts.
Actual workflow automation is done through VCF Operations Orchestrator, which is explicitly described as a “workflow automation solution” and can create and run workflows.
VCF Operations Orchestrator saves a workflow token every time a workflow runs, recording the details of that specific workflow run.Workflows receive input parameters and generate output parameters when they run.Most workflows require a certain set of input parameters to run. An input parameter is an argument that the workflow processes when it runs. The user, an application, another workflow, or an action passes input parameters to a workflow for the workflow to process when it runs.For example, if a workflow resets a virtual machine, the workflow requires the name of the virtual machine as an input parameter.A workflow's output parameters represent the result from the workflow run. Output parameters can change when a workflow or a workflow element runs. During a workflow run, the workflow can receive the output parameters of other workflows as input parameters.For example, if a workflow creates a snapshot of a virtual machine, the output parameter for the workflow is the resulting snapshot.Workflow elements process data that they receive as input parameters, and set the resulting data as workflow variables or output parameters.Read-only workflow variables act as global constants for a workflow. Writable variables act as a workflow’s global variables.You can use variables to transfer data between the elements of a workflow.You can obtain variables in the following ways: Define variables when you create a workflow. Set the output parameter of a workflow element as a workflow variable. Inherit variables from a configuration element. A workflow schema is a graphical representation that shows the workflow as a flow diagram of interconnected workflow elements. The workflow schema is the most important element of a workflow as it determines its logic.When users run a workflow, they provide the values for the input parameters of the workflow in the workflow presentation.A workflow token represents a workflow that is running or has finished running.A workflow is an abstract description of a process that defines a generic sequence of steps and a generic set of required input parameters. When you run a workflow with a set of input parameters, you receive an instance of this abstract workflow that behaves according to the specific input parameters you give it. This specific instance of a finished or a running workflow is called a workflow token.Workflow Token Attributes are the specific parameters with which a workflow token runs.The workflow token attributes are an aggregation of the workflow's global variables and the specific input and output parameters with which you run the workflow token.
Next, you might want to look into Running VCF Operations Orchestrator Workflows, or you can check out VCF Operations Orchestrator.Workflow

Within VMware Cloud Foundation, an SDDC is the foundational architectural model that virtualizes all core data-center resources (compute, storage, networking, and management) and delivers them as software services.
Think of SDDC as the “what”, while VCF is the “productized implementation” of that model.In an SDDC:
No hardware-specific configuration is required by tenants. Everything is expressed as policies, APIs, and declarative intent.If you think of SDDC as an interface, VCF is an implementation of that interface.Or in mor simpler terms, You cannot “install an SDDC”. You deploy VCF, and the result is an SDDC.As a very simplistic analogy: SDDC → “Cloud computing” VCF → “AWS (but for private cloud)” Inside VCF, SDDC enables: Uniform resource abstraction
A VM workload and a Kubernetes workload are both “workloads” Policy-driven behavior
Placement, HA, security, backups are rules, not scripts Lifecycle coherence
Upgrade ESX, NSX, vSAN together, safely and repeatably Multi-tenancy
Organizations, Projects, namespaces, quotas, RBAC Cloud-like operations on-prem
Self-service, APIs, Governance, chargeback SDDC is not: A single product Just virtualization Just Kubernetes A UI A vCenter feature It is the system-level design philosophy that VCF enforces.VCF’s value proposition is: “You don’t assemble an SDDC yourself anymore: We ship one.” That’s why: VCF has strict BOMs VCF enforces lifecycle orchestration VCF tightly integrates ops + automation + infra This is intentional: freedom at the top, rigidity at the bottom. SDDC = architecture VCF = implementation of that architecture In VCF, everything (compute, storage, network, ops) is software-defined SDDC enables cloud-like behavior on private infrastructure You deploy VCF, and you get an SDDC: That simple.
VCF Private Cloud could be a topic of interest to look at right after SDDC.SDDCVCF Identity Broker
Project Administrators leverage the infrastructure that is created by the Organization Administrator to ensure that their project members have the resources they need for their development work.Project Administrators can:
View all content for their Project, including namespaces, deployments, and so on
Perform all Day 2 actions on resources
Manage users in the Project and assign roles
Manage Project-level settings and administrator content
Create resources using the IaaS services console in namespaces they created or have access to Manage Catalog Approval Requests
← Back to User RolesProject Administrator
An Organization Administrator can access the Organization portal and add users and groups to the Organization.Organization Administrators can:
Manage Projects and Project Users Configure integrations, such as Git
Manage Blueprints and Catalog Items
Manage namespaces and associated resources
Fully access namespaces that they did not create
Manage new VPCs and associated resources
See all Projects and all Deployments Create and manage Content Libraries
Create and manage policies on resources and deployments Create and manage event subscriptions
← Back to User RolesOrganization Administrator
#tenancy
In VMware Cloud Foundation, a Project is a logical, tenant-scoped construct used for workload organization, Governance, and self-service consumption.It exists at the automation and policy layer, not the virtualization layer.Projects group workloads, users, quotas, policies, and lifecycle controls under a common administrative boundary. It is “a governed slice of cloud capacity” exposed to consumers.
Projects live primarily in VCF Automation (formerly vRealize Automation / Aria Automation).It is not: A vSphere cluster A Kubernetes cluster A resource pool
A Supervisor Namespace (though it may map to one) Instead, it is a control-plane abstraction that binds together multiple lower-level constructs.VCF Instance └── Organization └── Project ├── Users & Roles ├── Policies & Quotas ├── Cloud Zones ├── Workload Deployments └── Supervisor Namespaces / VKS Clusters
A project represents a tenant or sub-tenant: Different teams Different applications Different environments (prod, staging, dev) Each project is isolated from others by policy.Projects define who can do what:
Project Administrator
Project User
Project Advanced User
Project Auditor These roles govern: Who can deploy workloads
Who can modify Blueprints Who can see usage or costs Projects define where workloads can land: Which Cloud Zones they can use Resource quotas (CPU, memory, storage) Network constraints Storage policies This prevents a single tenant from exhausting shared infrastructure.Projects are the context in which users deploy:
Virtual Machines Kubernetes clusters (e.g., Supervisor-backed) Application blueprints
Day-2 operations (scale, update, destroy) Everything a user deploys is always within a project.A Project maps to:
A Supervisor Namespace One or more Kubernetes clusters A set of Kubernetes namespaces inside those clusters But the Project itself is not Kubernetes-native. It’s a management abstraction above Kubernetes.Think of it as: “A governance wrapper around Kubernetes and VM resources.”
VCF Automation supports both one-to-one and one-to-many mappings between Projects and Supervisor Namespaces; the choice is an architectural pattern, not a platform constraint.Very common, very clean:Organization: Coca-Cola ├── Project: Coke-Prod → ns-coke-prod ├── Project: Coke-Stage → ns-coke-stage └── Project: Coke-Dev → ns-coke-dev This provides: Clean blast-radius isolation Clear RBAC and quotas per environment Easy mental model Common in regulated / prod-heavy setups This is a design choice, not a platform requirement.(Equally valid, also common in larger deployments)Organization: Coca-Cola └── Project: Coke ├── ns-coke-dev ├── ns-coke-stage └── ns-coke-prod This provides: Shared governance (same people, same blueprints) Environment separation handled at namespace level Easier cross-env promotion workflows Fewer projects to manage
In VMware Cloud Foundation: A Project is a logical tenant boundary It governs who can deploy what, where, and how It sits above infrastructure and below the organization It is the unit of consumption for developers and teams
It enables Multi-Tenancy, Governance, and self-service
You might want to check out Blueprints.Project
#tenancy
See also: Project

In VCF Automation, an Organization is not a technical runtime boundary—It is a business-facing logical entity that defines who is allowed to consume cloud capabilities, under which rules, and with which visibility.It is the outermost “contract boundary” for consumption, not execution.An Organization is a logical tenant boundary that groups identity, policy, quotas, visibility, and approval flows for consuming infrastructure and platform services.It answers: Who is consuming? What are they allowed to consume? Under which business rules? —not how workloads actually run.
Because Supervisor Namespaces are the actual enforcement boundary, a single Organization can define multiple tenants.But those “tenants” are operational tenants, not consumption tenants.There are two different kinds of tenancy in VCF:They are deliberately decoupled.
A Supervisor Namespace enforces: RBAC Resource quotas Network isolation Storage policies Pod security boundaries Runtime blast radius This is where: Kubernetes says “no” vSphere enforces limits Workloads are actually prevented from crossing boundaries Namespace = hard enforcement boundary
Organizations define intent and Governance. An Organization: Defines who is allowed to create tenants Defines how many tenants Defines under which rules Defines approval and lifecycle policies It’s closer to: “Who is allowed to mint isolation boundaries?” not: “Where isolation happens.” A single Organization can own: Multiple Projects Each Project can map to:
One Supervisor Namespace Or several namespaces (depending on policy / model) Organization: Acme Corp ├── Project: Acme-Prod → ns-acme-prod ├── Project: Acme-Stage → ns-acme-stage ├── Project: Acme-Dev → ns-acme-dev └── Project: Acme-Analytics → ns-acme-analytics
Each namespace is a real tenant boundary.But from a business standpoint: Acme Corp is still one customer: One billing entity One governance envelope One policy domain This construct enables the following scenarios (which would have been impossible otherwise).Classic need: Dev / Stage / Prod Regulated vs non-regulated Different trust zones All under: One contract One identity plane One catalog Example: Organization = “Platform Team” Projects = internal product teams Namespaces = per-team isolation This would break if Organization == Namespace.Example: Organization = External customer Projects = customer environments Namespaces = actual enforcement boundaries Same model works for: Internal IT SaaS providers Telco multi-tenant platforms If something must be isolated, it must be isolated at the namespace level.Anything above that:
Is governance Is visibility Is policy Is economy Organizations define who may create tenants; namespaces are the tenants.Similar to: AWS Account Azure Subscription (with Management Groups layered above) GCP Project (with Org/Folder hierarchy) But in VCF, it’s explicitly framed as consumption-first, not infrastructure-first. Separates consumers (e.g., companies, business units, external customers) Enforces isolation in: Identity and Access Visibility Quotas and Limits Chargeback / showback Organizations are where policies attach, such as: Who can request what Approval workflows Budget limits Lease durations Allowed regions / environments Allowed workload types (VM, Kubernetes, services) These policies then flow downward.Everything inside an Organization is: Visible only to that Organization (unless shared) Governed consistently This includes: Projects Blueprints / templates Catalog items Requests Cost views Organization ├── Projects │ ├── Policies │ ├── Quotas │ ├── Users / Groups │ └── Workload requests │ └── (maps indirectly to) └── Cloud Zones └── Infrastructure (vSphere, Supervisor, VKS, etc.) Infrastructure never belongs to an Organization Consumption always does Organization deliberately hides infrastructure topology.From the Organization’s point of view:
There is no ESX No cluster No datastore
No vSphere Supervisor There is only: “What can I request?” “What am I allowed to use?” “Who approves this?” “How much does it cost?” This abstraction enables: Multi-tenant platforms Internal private clouds Managed services SaaS-like experience on top of VCF If Organization is “who is the customer”, then Project is “what they are working on”.Typical mapping:Organization: Acme Corp ├── Project: Acme-Prod ├── Project: Acme-Stage └── Project: Acme-Dev Projects: Scope quotas Bind to cloud zones
Eventually map to Supervisor Namespaces or runtime constructs Organizations never do.
Organization = Governance + visibility It exists to model consumption, not execution It owns policy, identity, and economics It deliberately abstracts away infrastructure
Everything technical happens below it, via Projects and Cloud Zones
Check IaaS as a concept, or jump back to VMware Cloud Foundation.Organization
Roles assigned to users and groups are an essential part to identity and access management in VCF Automation.
You can leverage identity providers with Organizations to enable single sign-on to provision users and groups. Once the users and groups are added to the Organization, they must be assigned roles to enable specific permissions and access to different features within  VCF Automation.
VCF Automation has several levels of user roles. These different levels control access to the Organization, the Projects that produce or consume the Blueprints, Catalog Items, access to IaaS Services, and the ability for users to use or see individual parts of the user interface. These different levels give Organization Administrators different tools to apply any level of granularity that is required by their operational needs.
Here are the predefined user roles in **VCF Automation. You can visit each link to see more details about them. Organization Roles
Organization Administrator
Organization User
Organization Auditor Project Roles
Project Administrator
Project Auditor
Project Advanced User
Project User
Defer to Identity Provider User permissions can also be determined based on information received from the identity provider for the Organization.
Organization Management could be a good area to explore after getting acquainted with the user roles here. Additionally, you can find a more detailed listing of what permissions these roles have in VCF Roles and Permissions.User Roles
#tenancy
In VMware Cloud Foundation, Platform Admin and Tenant Admin are useful conceptual terms, but not official role names in VCF.VCF defines explicit, documented roles such as:
Organization Administrator
Project Administrator (and related Auditor / User roles) This page uses Platform Admin as a conceptual responsibility boundary, and Organization / Project Administrator as the official tenant-facing roles defined by VCF.The distinction is intentional and fundamental.
VCF separates infrastructure ownership from consumption governance: platform infrastructure is operated outside VCF Automation, while Organization Administrators and Project Administrators govern what runs within tenant boundaries.
Organization Administrator has Tenant-level authority.
An Organization Administrator represents the tenant boundary in VCF Automation.They manage: Organization-level configuration Tenant users and role assignments Organization-wide quotas and policies Governance within the organization They cannot: Modify platform topology Upgrade core infrastructure Affect other organizations Bypass platform guardrails
The Project Administrator is a Project-scoped operational authority.
A Project Administrator manages consumption and operations within a single Project, which maps to one (typical, but can be more than one) Supervisor Namespace.
The Project Administrator can create Projects, assign users and groups, and allocate quotas to restrict the configurations available to the tenants. |
By creating Projects, you can isolate security and networking objects across tenants in a single NSX deployment. Project Administrators manage: Project users and access Workload provisioning (VMs, Kubernetes clusters, services) Project-scoped quotas and approvals Day-to-day operational policies Their authority is strictly bounded by:
The Organization Platform-defined constraints Without this separation: Tenants could break upgrade paths Platform consistency would erode Supportability would collapse One tenant could impact others VCF deliberately trades tenant flexibility for platform predictability, safety, and lifecycle integrity. Organization Administrator is the true tenant administrator in VCF 9 Project Administrator governs consumption within a tenant The separation protects multi-tenancy, lifecycle management, and supportability This boundary is foundational to VCF’s architecture
VCF Roles and Permissions is the logical follow-up to this section, which dives into more details of predefined roles and privileges in **VMware Cloud Foundation.Administrative Roles in VCF


In VMware Cloud Foundation, the Management Cluster is the foundational cluster that runs the platform itself. It hosts the management plane—the services that build, operate, upgrade, and secure the rest of the cloud.Put simply: If the Management Cluster is down, you can’t manage the cloud—only the workloads keep running. The Management Cluster is part of the Management Domain (a special Workload Domain). It is created first during Day-0 bring-up and is non-optional.Typical components include: SDDC Manager vCenter Server (management vCenter) NSX Managers vSAN management services Optional: Operations / Automation services (depending on deployment) These components do not belong to tenants. They belong to the platform.It runs the services that: Define topology Enforce lifecycle sequencing Validate upgrades Maintain inventory and state All VCF lifecycle operations (create domain, expand cluster, upgrade stack) are coordinated from here.Tenant workloads do not run here (by design): No tenant VMs No tenant Kubernetes workloads No customer apps This protects: Stability Security Upgrade safety It is not: A tenant cluster A workload execution environment A shared resource pool for apps Optional or replaceable Treating it like a general-purpose cluster is a serious anti-pattern.This separation ensures: Predictable upgrades (no tenant interference) Clear blast-radius control Strong security boundaries Operational sanity at scale It’s the same pattern used by: Kubernetes (control plane vs worker nodes) Public clouds (provider plane vs customer plane) Management Cluster → Kubernetes control plane nodes Workload Clusters → Kubernetes worker nodes SDDC Manager → Cluster lifecycle operator You wouldn’t run apps on the Kubernetes control plane; same rule applies here. Management Cluster is typically: Small (minimum viable size) Highly available Strictly protected If it fails: Existing workloads keep running You lose management, scaling, and upgrades until restored The Management Cluster runs the cloud, not the workloads It is part of the Management Domain It hosts SDDC Manager, vCenter, NSX Managers It is isolated, mandatory, and high-blast-radius Treat it as sacred infrastructure If you want, next we can: Compare Management Cluster vs Supervisor Cluster Walk through failure scenarios and recovery Discuss why tenants should never land here Map this to VCF Day-0 / Day-1 / Day-2 flows Management Cluster
Guest Cluster ← merge this article into “guest cluster”


In VMware Cloud Foundation, a Workload Cluster is a cluster dedicated to running tenant workloads—VMs or Kubernetes-backed workloads—as opposed to running the platform itself.It lives inside a Workload Domain (VI Domain) and is where actual business applications execute.In plain terms: Workload Clusters run applications; Management Clusters run the cloud. VCF Platform │ ├── Management Domain │ └── Management Cluster (platform services only) │ └── Workload Domain (VI Domain) ├── Workload Cluster A ← tenant workloads ├── Workload Cluster B ← tenant workloads └── Workload Cluster C ← tenant workloads A Workload Domain can contain multiple Workload Clusters Each cluster is an operational and failure boundary Tenants never see the Management Cluster, but they consume resources from Workload Clusters Depending on how VCF is used, a Workload Cluster may host: Traditional virtual machines App servers, databases, legacy systems Managed via vCenter Governed via VCF Automation (orgs, projects, policies) Supervisor-backed workloads Guest clusters (e.g., TKG) PodVM-based workloads Namespaces mapped to projects The cluster itself is workload-agnostic; policy determines what lands there.This split is critical: Tenants use clusters Platform Admins operate clusters This is where: CPU, memory, storage are consumed Network traffic flows Availability and performance matter most Each Workload Cluster provides: Fault isolation Upgrade isolation Security boundaries A problem in one cluster should not affect others.Clusters are upgraded: Under SDDC Manager control In a controlled, validated sequence Independently of other clusters (within constraints) It is not: A management plane A place for SDDC Manager or NSX Managers A tenant abstraction by itself A free-for-all environment A Workload Cluster is shared infrastructure, not a tenant.Important nuance: Tenancy does not equal cluster Multiple tenants can share: The same Workload Cluster While remaining isolated via: Organizations Projects Namespaces NSX micro-segmentation Clusters are capacity and fault boundaries, not business boundaries. Workload Cluster → Kubernetes worker node pool Management Cluster → Kubernetes control plane Namespaces / Projects → Tenant isolation VCF Automation → Policy and governance layer You scale, isolate, and govern above the cluster. Strong fault isolation Predictable lifecycle Flexible placement strategies Supports mixed workload types More moving parts Requires capacity planning Requires clear cluster placement policy VCF optimizes for enterprise-scale control, not minimal topology. Workload Clusters are where applications run They live inside Workload (VI) Domains They are operated by Platform Admins They can host VM and Kubernetes workloads They are shared but strongly governed If you want, next we can: Contrast Workload Cluster vs Supervisor Cluster Explain how projects map to clusters Walk through placement and scheduling decisions Discuss anti-patterns (overloading a single cluster) Workload Cluster
A VCF Domain is a core VMware Cloud Foundation platform construct.
It is defined and lifecycle-managed by VCF itself (via SDDC Manager).
VCF Automation consumes it for tenant self-service and provisioning.
VCF Operations observes it for monitoring, health, and capacity.
A VCF Domain is an isolated SDDC unit inside VCF with its own full stack:Each domain is independently lifecycle-managed (upgrade cadence, patch windows, scaling).
A VCF Domain in a VCF Instance consists of the following components:
One vCenter instance.
One or more vSphere Clusters with vSphere HA and vSphere DRS enabled.
At least one vSphere Distributed Switches per cluster for system traffic and NSX Segments for workloads.
Dedicated NSX Manager instance, either specifically for the VCF Domain or shared between VCF Domains, for configuring and implementing software-defined networking.
Optional: One or more NSX Edge Clusters, added after you create the Workload Domain, that connects the workloads in the Workload Domain for logical switching, logical dynamic routing, and load balancing. One or more shared storage allocations as principal or supplemental storage. There are two types of VCF Domains:
Management Domain is created during the deployment or convergence process.
Workload Domain runs consumer workloads on Day 2.
Management Domain and Workload Domain gives further context about VCF Domains.
You might also want to check out VMware Cloud Foundation’s fleet and domain model by looking at VCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF Domains.VCF Domain![[workload-domain-b8d5ddd7-899b-4c34-8947-4acbd57f8f72.webp]
The Management Domain is created during the deployment or convergence process by the VCF Installer. It contains the management components of the VCF Instance and, for the first VCF Instance, VCF Operations and VCF Automation.In addition to the components that are common for each VCF Domain, the management domain includes the 
SDDC Manager Appliance and the Fleet Management Appliance, that adds workflows for infrastructure management automation to the VCF Operations instance for the VCF Fleet. Management Domain: is created first hosts VCF Control Plane components:
SDDC Manager
vCenter
NSX Manager
VCF Operations
VCF Automation
You might want to check out VMware Cloud Foundation’s fleet and domain model by looking at VCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF Domains.Management Domain

You create Workload Domains in VCF Operations to run consumer workloads.
For the first workload domain in your environment, VCF Operations deploys a vCenter instance and an NSX Manager instance in the Management Domain. For each additional workload domain, VCF Operations deploys an additional vCenter instance.New Workload Domains can share the same NSX Manager cluster with an existing Workload Domain or you can deploy a new NSX Manager cluster.
Workload domains cannot use the NSX Manager cluster for the Management Domain.A Workload Domain (or VI (virtual infrastructure) Workload Domain)
is created after Management Domain hosts customer workloads Typical separation: Prod vs non-prod Regulated vs unregulated Performance-sensitive vs general A VCF Domain is to VCF what a Kubernetes cluster is to Kubernetes-based platforms.It gives you: Failure domain isolation Security boundary Upgrade blast-radius control Operational independence Without VCF Domains, everything would be patched, upgraded, and potentially broken together.
In VCF Automation: A VCF Domain is a backing infrastructure boundary It is mapped to:
Organizations
Projects
Supervisor Namespaces VCF Automation never creates or upgrades domain: It only consumes them.
In VCF Operations: A VCF Domain is an observed object Used for: Capacity planning Health scoring Performance analytics Alerting Operations has zero authority over its lifecycle. VCF Domain is a foundational VCF concept Defined and lifecycle-managed by SDDC Manager Not a VCF Automation concept Not a VCF Operations concept BUT both products depend on it, yet neither owns it Primary purpose: isolation, lifecycle control, and scalability
You might want to check out VMware Cloud Foundation’s fleet and domain model by looking at VCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF Domains.Workload Domain
VCF management components are the platform control-plane services responsible for lifecycle management, networking, security, observability, and automation of the entire VCF instance, and are deployed exclusively in the Management Domain.
Here are the management components of VCF:
vCenter Server Inventory Cluster logic Resource scheduling API surface for everything else
ESX hosts (management cluster) Run the Management VMs Often capacity-isolated
NSX (NSX Manager + control plane) Networking for management workloads Overlay, routing, firewalling Required even if workload domains use different topologies
SDDC Manager Lifecycle orchestration Domain creation Upgrade coordination Configuration drift control These are management components even though they feel “optional”:
VCF Operations (formerly vRealize / Aria Operations) Telemetry ingestion Capacity planning Health modeling Alert correlation VCF Operations for Logs (if deployed) Centralized logging Audit & forensic workflows
These belong in the Management Domain because: They observe everything They are trusted with cross-domain data They are not tenant-scoped
VCF Automation (formerly vRealize / Aria Automation)
Tenant abstraction (Organization / Project) Approval flows Policy enforcement
Blueprint execution Self-service APIs Even though it models consumer behavior, it is still a management component because: It enforces platform policy It brokers infrastructure authority It is not itself a tenant workload Often overlooked, but these are part of the management plane too: Identity Integration AD / LDAP
OIDC (vIDB, external IdP) Certificates Internal PKI Trust distribution Secrets and credentials Platform credentials Not tenant secrets These may not be a single product, but they are a functional plane of the management domain.A good litmus test: If a tenant can delete it without breaking the cloud, it is not a management component.
Other topological constructs such as Workload Cluster, Management Cluster, or VCF Edge are all good options to dive from here.VCF Management Components
VCF Instance is the compute, storage, networking virtual infrastructure that runs business workloads. A VCF Instance consists of VCF Domains: a Management Domain and Workload Domains.The components of a VCF Instance are:
SDDC Manager
NSX
vCenter
ESX
VCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF Domains nicely compares and contrasts how Fleet, Domain, and Instances relate to each other.VCF Instance
In VMware Cloud Foundation, these three terms describe different scopes of control, stacked hierarchically from largest (fleet) to smallest (domain).
If you only remember one thing: Fleet → Instance → Domain Management across clouds → One cloud → Parts of that cloud
A VCF Fleet is a logical grouping of multiple VCF Instances that are managed, observed, or governed together.It is a meta-layer, not a runtime construct. Multiple data centers Multiple regions Core + Edge Possibly different purposes (prod, DR, sovereign, etc.) Fleet-wide visibility Cross-instance posture (versions, compliance, drift) Centralized operations and governance Consistent policies and standards Fleet = “My private cloud estate”
A VCF Instance is one deployed VCF system:
One SDDC Manager
One Management Domain One lifecycle authority This is the unit of deployment and lifecycle. Independently installed Independently upgraded Independently failed / recovered Self-contained control plane Examples: One on-prem private cloud One regional cloud One large edge aggregation site
A Domain is a logical partition inside a VCF Instance, used to separate management concerns, workload types, or failure domains.There are two major kinds: Created first Hosts:
SDDC Manager
Management vCenter
NSX Managers Runs the platform itself One or more per instance Host: Tenant workloads
Application clusters (i.e., Guest Clusters) Independently scalable and isolatable Domain = “A major subsystem within a Cloud” VCF Fleet │ ├── VCF Instance (DC-West) │ ├── Management Domain │ ├── Workload Domain – Prod │ └── Workload Domain – Dev │ ├── VCF Instance (DC-East) │ ├── Management Domain │ └── Workload Domain – Prod │ └── VCF Instance (Edge-Region-1) ├── Management Domain └── Workload Domain – Edge Each level has different responsibilities and blast radius. Fleet → Multiple clusters managed centrally Instance → One cluster + control plane Domain → Node pools / system vs workload separation Because customers now have: Many private clouds Many edge clouds
A need for consistent Governance at scale So VMware had to separate: Where lifecycle happens (instance) Where workloads run (domains) Where governance is coordinated (fleet)
VCF Fleet = multi-cloud / multi-site management scope
VCF Instance = one complete VCF deployment
VCF Domains = functional partitions inside an instance Lifecycle authority lives at the instance Isolation and scale happen via domains
Governance and visibility roll up to the fleet
You might want to look at VCF Advanced Services.VCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF DomainsVCF Fleet is an environment that is managed by a single set of fleet-level management components: 
VCF Operations
and VCF Automation
A VCF Fleet contains one or more VCF Instances and might contain one or more standalone vCenter instances, managed by the VCF Operations instance for the fleet.The components of a VCF Fleet are:
VCF Instances
vCenter Instances
VCF Operations
VCF Automation
VCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF Domains nicely compares and contrasts how Fleet, Domain, and Instances relate to each other.VCF Fleet

#tenancy
In vSphere Supervisor a tenant is namespace-bound. There is no separate tenant object inside Kubernetes.
A Supervisor Namespace is the tenant boundary at the vSphere-Kubernetes interface. If you assume: Tenant = Project → you’ll design the wrong thing Tenant = Kubernetes namespace → you’ll under-secure Tenant = Supervisor Namespace → things line up “tenant namespace” is an informal shorthand for supervisor namespace. Organizations and Projects are governance overlays. They do not define the tenant.Kubernetes namespaces inside guest clusters are secondary scopes.
In vSphere Supervisor each tenant is realized as one (or more) Supervisor Namespaces.
VCF Automation sits above, provides governance (Organizations, Projects, quotas) and self-service, but does not define tenancy by itself.This is sometimes “informally” expressed as “tenant namespaces”. What is meant by it is a Supervisor Namespace.Or more precisely: In a Supervisor Cluster tenant == supervisor namespace (there is a 1-1 relationship).
In vSphere Supervisor, tenancy is realized through Supervisor Namespaces, which serve as the execution and isolation boundary for tenants.When people say: “tenant namespace” “project namespace” “customer namespace” They almost always mean: A Supervisor Namespace allocated to that tenant. Kubernetes does not have a separate construct for this: It is a vSphere concept, projected as a namespace.A Supervisor Namespace can contain: Pods VMs Entire guest Kubernetes clusters Tenant └── Supervisor Namespace ├── VM workloads ├── Pod workloads └── Guest K8s Cluster └── many Kubernetes namespaces VCF Environment └── vSphere (vCenter) └── Supervisor Cluster └── Supervisor Namespace ← TENANT BOUNDARY At this layer: Supervisor Namespace Has: Resource limits Storage policies Network segments RBAC bindings Is created and owned by vCenter Maps to: Resource pools NSX constructs Datastore permissions This is where hard multitenancy lives.

#tenancyThis is logical tenancy, not execution tenancy.It is the automation and consumption layer.Organization └── Project └── Deployment / Blueprint └── (Targets a Supervisor Namespace) Organization Business / administrative grouping Project Quota + governance container These map downwards, but they don’t execute workloads themselves.
Supervisor Namespace defines a tenant from a runtime and security perspective.
At VCF Automation, Organizations and Projects define: Ownership Billing
Governance Access workflows But not execution boundaries. VCF Environment (Rackspace) └── Supervisor Cluster ├── ns-cocacola ← Tenant: Coca-Cola ├── ns-pepsi ← Tenant: Pepsi └── ns-pizzahut ← Tenant: Pizza Hut Each tenant is a supervisor namespace.
For Coca-Cola (example): Fixed CPU / memory quota Dedicated or isolated NSX segment Approved storage policies RBAC scoped to Coca-Cola admins Ability to run: Pods VMs Guest Kubernetes clusters That namespace is the tenant boundary. Layer VCF automation on top of this:Organization: Coca-Cola └── Project: Coke-Prod └── Deployments → targets ns-cocacola Organization: Pepsi └── Project: Pepsi-Shared └── Deployments → targets ns-pepsi Organizations and Projects map to Supervisor Namespaces — they do not replace them.Automation gives: Self-service catalogs Approval workflows Policy as code Lifecycle orchestration But the tenant still “lives” at the Supervisor Namespace.Scope vCenter Supervisor Cluster NSX Storage policies Responsibilities Create Supervisor Namespaces Set quotas Attach networks Bind tenant identities Enforce platform guardrails Power level God-mode Not visible to customers Scope One Supervisor Namespace (e.g., ns-cocacola) Kubernetes API within that namespace Responsibilities Manage workloads Deploy guest clusters Configure service Delegate access internally Cannot See other tenants Modify quotas Escape namespace This is who you hand the kubeconfig to. Scope Kubernetes RBAC inside tenant (supervisor) namespace Possibly inside guest clusters Responsibilities Deploy apps Manage services Consume secrets No infrastructure privileges Scope Automation policies Catalogs Projects Approvals This role: Often held by Rackspace Sometimes delegated partially to tenants
#secrets Secrets do not cross Supervisor Namespaces Identity trust roots often terminate there Network policy enforcement happens there Audit logs are scoped there So when you say tenant == Supervisor Namespace, then: Security Compliance Billing Automation all align clearly. Tenants in SupervisorvSphere Supervisor is a control plane built in vSphere that integrates desired state and a single consistent API directly in the hypervisor. vSphere Supervisor enables native deployment and management of Kubernetes clusters, declarative virtual machines, and vSphere Pods alongside traditional workloads. It transforms vSphere to an extendable platform by providing a declarative API for self-service provisioning of modern infrastructure services in a resource boundaries enabled by vSphere Namespaces.
Supervisor Namespace
The vSphere Supervisor lives as a set of Kubernetes control-plane VMs running on ESX hosts, instantiated, wired, and governed by vCenter Server.

Runs on: ESX Created and managed by: VMware vCenter Server Implemented as: Kubernetes control-plane VMs
Distributed across ESX hosts
Backed by vSAN / datastores
Networked via NSX (or VDS in simpler setups) When you “enable Supervisor” in vCenter: vCenter: Creates a special-purpose Kubernetes cluster Instantiates its control plane as VMs Pins it tightly to: Cluster membership Networking Storage Treats it as part of the infrastructure, not a tenant workload So the Supervisor is: Not a workload cluster Not user-managed Kubernetes Not a vSphere product you install It is an infrastructure service owned by vCenter.Physical Hosts └─ ESX └─ vCenter Server (control plane) └─ Supervisor Cluster (Kubernetes control plane VMs) ├─ Supervisor Namespaces ├─ vSphere Pods └─ Guest / Workload Clusters The vSphere Supervisor is a Kubernetes control plane deployed as system-managed VMs on ESX, whose lifecycle is owned entirely by vCenter Server and whose purpose is to expose Kubernetes semantics directly on vSphere infrastructure. The vSphere Supervisor physically lives as vCenter-managed Kubernetes control-plane VMs running on ESX hosts inside a vSphere cluster.
vSphere Supervisor is the foundation of VCF consumption and can be enabled during workload domain creation or directly in vCenter.

Use NSX Virtual Private Clouds (VPC) workload networks. This configuration is a requirement for using VCF Automation
Determine if a Single-Zone Supervisor or Multi-Zone Supervisor deployment is required: In VCF 9.0, a Supervisor deployed in a single-zone configuration cannot be converted to a multi-zone deployment after enablement. You must determine the target deployment model before initiating the Supervisor enablement process.
#todo what is single-zone versus multi-zone? Single-Zone Deployment: A Single-Zone Supervisor deployment uses a single vSphere cluster to host both workloads and Supervisor management components.
Additional vSphere Zones can be added after initial enablement. However, these zones are used exclusively for workload placement and do not host Supervisor control plane components.
#todo what are Supervisor control plane components?
Multi-Zone Deployment: A Multi-Zone Supervisor deployment uses three vSphere Clusters, placing each cluster into a vSphere Zone. vSphere Zones are used by workloads and Supervisor management components to deliver high availability and expose each cluster as an independent, consumable availability zone. This configuration provides a resilient, HA-capable platform. Additional vSphere Zones can be added after initial enablement. However, these additional zones are available for workload consumption only, not for Supervisor control plane components. Single Host: Also a Single-Zone Supervisor with a single Control Plane VM deployed to a single ESX host, with vSphere HA disabled. While it shares the same characteristics as other single-zone deployments, in this configuration, any host failure results in downtime for the Supervisor Control Plane and potentially for associated workloads.
Easy Supervisor: This is a Single-Zone simplified deployment that uses workload networking on top of vSphere Distributed Switch, designed as a fast and simple starting point for proof-of-concept environments and production deployments leveraging vSphere Distributed Switch. An Easy Supervisor deployment consists of: One Supervisor Control Plane VM A shared network for both workload and management traffic No load balancer

It is vSphere running in special Kubernetes-enabled mode.
VCF Automation consumes what Supervisor exposes.
You can think of Supervisor as vSphere with Kubernetes fused into its control plane.


When you enable Supervisor on a vSphere Cluster, you are activating a capability inside vSphere.
Supervisor runs inside ESX.
Uses vCenter as the control plane.
Creates Supervisor Namespaces. Exposes Kubernetes APIs, backed by native vSphere primitives. So conceptually, Supervisor is vSphere operating in "Kubernetes-native mode".
Supervisor Namespaces are not Kubernetes namespaces.If classic vSphere is "run VMs", Supervisor vSphere is "Run anything (VMs, Pods, services)" with the same primitives.
Supervisor runs on ESX. It enables Kubernetes semantics backed by vSphere primitives.
VCF Automation is optional and sits above Supervisor.
Supervisor Namespaces look like Kubernetes namespace on purpose.vSphere (authoritative substrate) └── Supervisor ├── Kubernetes API (authoritative for some things) └── vSphere API/UI (authoritative for others) There is no promise that: every UI action has a YAML equivalent or that YAML is the “source of truth” for all infra Instead: some things are Kubernetes-first some things remain vSphere-first Kubernetes manifest → vSphere policy enforcement. Create VMs via VirtualMachine CRDs (VM Operator) Create Pods / Deployments Attach storage Attach networks (within guardrails) PVCs backed by vSphere storage policies Datastore selection via StorageClasses Policy-based placement Declare “I need this secret” Injector materializes it VCF Secret Service enforces access
Pods/VMs attach to NSX-backed segments Load balancers exposed via K8s Service abstractions You don’t manage NSX topology in YAML, but you consume it declaratively. Infrastructure topology Tenancy and Governance constructs (Organization, Projects, Quoatas at Provider level, Approval, Chargeback) Those live in VCF Automation / vSphere UI, not Kubernetes. So: vSphere Supervisor exposes a Kubernetes-native API surface for workload consumption (pods, VMs, storage, networking), while infrastructure topology, tenancy, and governance remain vSphere- and Automation-controlled.


vSphere Supervisor
ESX is the virtualization platform where you create and run Virtual Machines and Virtual Appliances, Kubernetes workloads, and AI/ML Workloads.  ESX is a Type-1 (bare-metal) hypervisor Runs directly on hardware Owns: CPU scheduling Memory management Device virtualization Does not coordinate clusters by itself You can run standalone ESX without vCenter, but: No clustering
No HA
No DRS
No vMotion orchestration ESX is a hypervisor, it is not a traditional Linux OS.In ESX, there is no general-purpose userland like you’d expect in Linux or Windows.ESX is a purpose-built, bare-metal hypervisor operating system whose kernel (VMKernel) directly manages hardware resources and runs virtual machines.
Exploring the relationship between vSphere, ESX, and vCenter may clarify some of of the dangling question marks, if you have any.ESX
see also: vCenter Server, ESX, Supervisor Cluster A vSphere Cluster (or Supervisor Cluster) is a logical grouping of ESX hosts that vCenter treats as a single resource pool and failure domain. It exists only in vCenter ESX hosts do not know they are “in a cluster”. When you create a cluster in vCenter Server, you are telling: “*These ESX hosts agree to be scheduled, balanced, and failed over together.”This enables cluster-level logic, such as DRS (Distributed Resource Scheduler): vCenter decides which host should run which VM. When to rebalance the load.
Uses vMotion to move VMs between hosts. HA (High Availability) Hosts run a lightweight HA agent. If a host dies: Other hosts detect it vCenter (or preconfigured HA logic) restarts VMs elsewhere. Shared resource abstraction Instead of thinking: Host A: 64 cores Host B: 64 cores vCenter presents Cluster: 128 cores VM placement and limits are logical, not physical.A vSphere Cluster is not:Because from an operator’s perspective: Hosts act like a pool Failures are absorbed Workloads move transparently But architecturally: The cluster is an illusion created by vCenter.
A vSphere cluster is a vCenter-defined scheduling and failure domain over multiple ESX hosts,[ Physical Servers ] ↓ ESX (many hosts) ↓ vCenter Server ↓ vSphere features & automation vSphere ClustervCenter is the service through which you manage multiple hosts connected in a network pool host resources.
vCenter Server runs as a Virtual Appliance (VCSA) — a prebuilt VM — on ESX.Concretely: vCenter is not bare metal It is deployed as an OVA That OVA becomes one VM (sometimes functionally “a group of services”, but still a single VM) Internally, that VM runs: A hardened Linux-based OS vCenter services Database (embedded or external, depending on scale) Physical hardware └── ESX └── vCenter Server Appliance (VM) └── vCenter services vCenter Server is the centralized control plane Manages:
ESX hosts
vSphere Clusters
Resource Pools Policies Orchestrates:
vMotion
DRS
HA Lifecycle

vCenter Server does not run workloads: it tells ESX what to do instead.vCenter Server
Connects many ESX hosts. Maintains inventory and state
Enforces cluster-level logic. Orchestrates features that require coordination.
vMotion between hosts
DRS placement decisions
Cluster HA
Supervisor Cluster (for Kubernetes / VCF) vCenter Server is a set of backend services: Inventory (hosts, clusters, VMs) State and configuration database
Scheduling logic (DRS)
HA coordination
vMotion orchestration RBAC, roles, permissions APIs (REST, SOAP)
