A vSphere Namespace sets the resource boundaries where vSphere Pods, VMs, and VKS clusters, and Supervisor Services can run. As a vSphere administrator, you create and configure vSphere Namespaces through the vSphere Client.When initially created, a vSphere Namespace has unlimited resources within the Supervisor. As a vSphere administrator, you can set limits for CPU, memory, storage, as well as the number of Kubernetes objects that can run within the vSphere Namespace. Storage limitations are represented as storage quotas in Kubernetes. A resource pool is created in vSphere per each vSphere Namespace on the SupervisorYou can map up to three vSphere Zones to a vSphere Namespace for running workloads on them. The vSphere Namespace spreads across all vSphere clusters that are part of the vSphere Zones. The resources utilized to a vSphere Namespace are taken from all the underlying vSphere clusters on equal parts. For example, if you dedicate 300 MHz of CPU, 100 MHz are taken from each vSphere cluster.To provide workload isolation, you should use vSphere Zones marked as management only for running the Supervisor conrol plane on these zones.Differences Between a vSphere Namespace and Kubernetes NamespaceAlthough in its core a vSphere Namespace serves the same function as a Kubernetes namespace, a vSphere Namespace is specific to the vSphere Supervisor. You should not confuse a vSphere Namespace with a Kubernetes namespace.A vSphere Namespace is implemented as an extension to a vSphere resource pool and its function is to provide resources to workloads running in the Supervisor. A vSphere Namespace has a direct mapping to a Kubernetes namespace through which object and storage quotas are enforced upon workloads.Another difference with a regular Kubernetes namespace is that the vSphere administrator manages the user access to vSphere Namespaces, as mentioned from above. The vSphere administrator can also associate VM classes and Content Libraries containing VM templates that DevOps engineers can use to self-service VMs.These are not Kubernetes namespaces in the usual sense. They are: Resource-governed containers Backed by:
vSphere Networking (NSX)
vSphere Storage (vSAN) vSphere RBAC A tenant can have more than one Supervisor Namespace; however, those namespaces are not individual tenants. Tenancy is a business/trust concept. Supervisor Namespaces are execution slices that implement tenancy. vCenter / API / UI ↓ Supervisor Namespace created ↓ Namespace appears in Kubernetes ↓ kubectl can now interact with it ^ This is the opposite of upstream Kubernetes.In a vSphere Supervisor cluster, tenant namespaces are created and owned by vSphere as Supervisor Namespaces. Kubernetes users cannot create namespaces directly; kubectl is used only to interact with namespaces after vSphere has provisioned them. Supervisor Namespaces are created by vSphere
kubectl create ns is not how tenancy is established. This will be explicitly denies on the Supervisor Cluster. There is no concept of a regular tenant namespace on Supervisor Kubernetes reflects what vSphere creates Namespace lifecycle is deliberately centralized for safety In a Supervisor cluster, Kubernetes cluster-admin privileges do not grant authority over physical resource allocation. Namespace creation and resource envelopes are owned by vSphere, and Kubernetes operates strictly within those bounds.Tenant: Coca-Cola ├── ns-coke-prod ├── ns-coke-stage └── ns-coke-dev Tenant: Coca-Cola ├── ns-coke-us ├── ns-coke-eu └── ns-coke-apac ## VCF Automation Representation Organization: Coca-Cola ├── Project: Coke-Prod → ns-coke-prod ├── Project: Coke-Stage → ns-coke-stage └── Project: Coke-Dev → ns-coke-dev ^ One organization, multiple projects, Each project maps to (ideally) one Supervisor Namespace. But this is also possible: Organization: Coca-Cola └── Project: Coke ├── ns-coke-dev ├── ns-coke-stage └── ns-coke-prod The only inverant is one supervisor namespace cannot belong to multiple projects. Namespaces are unique per supervisor cluster. Supervisor clusters are *isolation domains*, so global uniqueness enforcement would have been 1) artificial and 2) painful. Organization └── Project └── Supervisor Namespace(s) From vSphere's perspective, a Pod, VM, or VM-based Pod is just scheduled compute.Project is an automation construct. Defined by Automation Admin persona. Mapped to one or more Supervisor Namespaces. Invisible to vSphere / Kubernetes. Their purpose is to govern requests, not execution.
From the Guest Cluster’s perspective, Organizations and Projects do not exist; similarly there is no concept of an organization or project inside the Supervisor Cluster either.Supervisor namespaces intentionally mimic Kubernetes semantics:From the developer's laptop, they feel like ordinary Kubernetes namespaces.Here is where they differ though (mostly around ownership and LCM)in Supervisor namespaces, resource governance is outside Kubernetes.In Kubernetes: CPU/memory limits = ResourceQuota Storage = StorageClass + PVC Network = CNI rules In Supervisor: CPU/memory = vSphere resource pools Storage = datastore policies Network = NSX segments Limits are hard boundaries, not advisory So when you say: "This namespace gets 8 vCPU and 64 GB RAM" That's not a Kubernetes promise---that's vSphere enforcing physics.Security model is in vSphere, not in KubernetesKubernetes RBAC applies inside the box vSphere already drew.That’s why certain Kubernetes admin actions are silently blocked even when RBAC says “allowed”.From Kubernetes’ POV: It looks like a CNI plugin In reality: NSX owns: L2/L3 segments Firewall rules Load balancers Kubernetes asks politely. NSX decides.This matters for: NetworkPolicy Ingress behavior Multi-tenant isolation In vanilla K8s: PVC requests storage Cluster tries to satisfy it In Supervisor: PVC must map to pre-approved storage policies Datastore capabilities are enforced externally StorageClass ≈ view of vSphere policy, not a free-form construct.The goal of this abstraction is to: Let Kubernetes users feel at home Let infrastructure teams retain determinism Avoid “Kubernetes ate my datacenter” chaos So Supervisor namespaces are: Kubernetes-compatible interfaces to vSphere-owned sandboxes Supervisor namespaces intentionally impersonate Kubernetes namespaces Kubernetes sees them as native; operations are externally enforced vSphere owns: lifecycle resource limits security boundaries Kubernetes operates within those constraints Supervisor Namespace names are unique only within a Supervisor cluster, and every Supervisor Namespace is governed by exactly one Project; Organizations do not directly own namespaces.Supervisor Namespace names are not globally unique, nor organization-wide unique.
They are unique per Supervisor Cluster.
Supervisor Namespaces are always associated with a Project.Organization └── Project └── Supervisor Namespace(s) Namespace names are: ❌ not global ❌ not org-unique ❌ not project-unique ✅ unique per Supervisor cluster Namespace: belongs to exactly one Project indirectly belongs to one Organization never floats independently Here’s a concrete example:Org: Verizon Project: West-Coast - Supervisor Cluster: sjc-01 - Namespace: edge-prod - Supervisor Cluster: lax-01 - Namespace: edge-prod ← same name, totally fine Project: East-Coast - Supervisor Cluster: iad-01 - Namespace: edge-prod ← also fine
Namespace names are Supervisor Cluster-scoped Projects are mandatory governance owners Organizations are containers of projects, not namespaces Any apparent contradiction is UI simplification, not platform behavior Supervisor NamespaceSaying “vSphere is ‘‘ESX and vCenter’’” is colloquially common, but technically incomplete.Because vSphere is a platform, it is NOT a single product.Or, to put more simply: There is nothing you can curl called vSphere; similar to there is nothing that you can curl called AWS or Azure.
vSphere is VMware’s virtualization platform built on ESX hosts managed by vCenter Server, together providing cluster-level services such as HA, DRS, and Kubernetes integration.But still, that term is mostly, contextually “good enough” because, in practice: You never run production vSphere without vCenter ESX alone is just a hypervisor, not a platform; and it is very limited vCenter alone does nothing
vSphere includes:
ESX is the bare-metal hypervisor.
vCenter Server provides centralized management. Platform features:
vMotion (live VM migration)
HA / DRS
Resource Pools
Distributed Virtual Switches Storage policies
Fault Tolerance
You cannot have vSphere without ESX.
You can have ESX without vCenter (but it will be very limited).
For more information about what vSphere controls and manages, you might want to see vSphere Constructs and vSphere Cluster. After that, your next step could be to check out vSphere Supervisor and see how it enables declarative management of these constructs.
Exploring vSphere Constructs might be the next logical area to navigate from here.vSphere, ESX, and vCenter


HA (High Availability) in VCF is the vSphere-native mechanism that automatically restarts workloads when a physical host fails.It is not a single VCF feature; rather, VCF relies on and standardizes HA across its managed infrastructure.HA is not invented by VCF. It comes from vSphere and is enforced consistently by VCF.VMware Cloud Foundation └── vSphere └── Cluster └── HA (enabled at cluster level) └── VM restart on host failure Implemented by: VMware vSphere Configured in: VMware vCenter Server Consumed by: All VMs running in VCF-managed clusters VCF ensures HA is correctly configured, validated, and lifecycle-managed as part of its opinionated design. Detect host failure → restart affected VMs on surviving hosts ESXi hosts exchange heartbeats A host stops responding Remaining hosts declare it failed vCenter selects new hosts VMs are restarted from disk ⚠️ Important: VMs are restarted, not live-migrated Physical ESXi host failure Power loss to a host PSOD / host crash Host isolation scenarios Guest OS crashes Application-level failures Storage corruption Network partition inside the VM Data loss between last write and crash HA answers “Is the VM running?”, not “Is the app healthy?”In VCF, every workload domain cluster is typically: HA-enabled DRS-enabled Validated against design rules Example:Workload Domain └── Cluster ├── HA: Enabled ├── DRS: Fully Automated └── Admission Control: Enabled VCF expects HA to be on; disabling it usually breaks design assumptions.HA includes Admission Control, which prevents you from powering on too many VMs.Purpose: Ensure enough spare capacity exists to restart VMs after a failure. If Admission Control says “no”: Nothing is broken You are overcommitted beyond your failure tolerance This is HA doing its job, not being restrictive.VCF HA is infrastructure HA, not cloud-native app HA.❌ Turning off HA to “fit more VMs” → Silent loss of failure guarantees❌ Expecting HA to replace app clustering → Wrong layer❌ Confusing HA with zero downtime → There is always a restart HA in VCF = vSphere HA, standardized and enforced It restarts VMs after host failure It does not provide zero-downtime or app-level resilience It is a non-optional baseline for VCF design assumptions If you want, next we can connect this to DRS, Admission Control math, or how HA interacts with Supervisor / Kubernetes workloads—those nuances matter a lot in VCF discussions.HA


Fault Tolerance (FT) is a vSphere feature that provides zero-downtime protection for a single VM by running a lockstep secondary copy of that VM on another host. If the primary host fails, the secondary immediately takes over with no reboot and no data loss.VCF inherits FT from vSphere; it does not redefine it.VMware Cloud Foundation └── vSphere └── Cluster └── Fault Tolerance (per-VM feature) ├── Primary VM └── Secondary VM (lockstep) Implemented by: VMware vSphere Configured in: VMware vCenter Server Applies to: Individual VMs (opt-in) Executes the same CPU instructions on two VMs simultaneously Streams execution state over a dedicated FT logging network On host failure → instant switchover, no restart HA restarts VMs. FT never restarts them. FT is about continuity, not balancing or recovery speed.FT is powerful but expensive. Limited VM sizes (CPU / memory caps) No snapshots No suspend No Storage vMotion Requires identical CPU features across hosts Heavy network & CPU overhead Because of this, FT is typically reserved for: Legacy apps that cannot tolerate any downtime Single-instance workloads with no clustering option VCF environments usually prefer: HA + DRS for infrastructure resilience Application-level HA (clusters, replicas, quorum) Kubernetes controllers for pod-level restart Site-level DR for disasters FT remains available, but it is not a default design assumption in VCF. HA: “If the server crashes, reboot it elsewhere” DRS: “Move servers around to keep things fair” FT: “Run two brains in sync at all times” FT is like live brain mirroring — effective, but costly.❌ Using FT as a substitute for application HA ❌ Enabling FT broadly “just in case” ❌ Forgetting FT network requirements ❌ Expecting FT to scale like Kubernetes replicas FT provides true zero-downtime VM failover It is a vSphere feature, inherited by VCF High overhead and strict limits make it niche In modern VCF designs, FT is the exception, not the rule If you want, next we can compare FT vs app-level clustering vs Kubernetes replicas — that’s usually where architectural trade-offs become obvious.Fault Tolerance


DRS (Distributed Resource Scheduler) is the vSphere cluster service that continuously balances CPU and memory load by automatically placing and live-migrating VMs (via vMotion) across hosts.In VCF, DRS is foundational, not optional.VMware Cloud Foundation └── vSphere └── Cluster ├── HA → “Can the VM run?” └── DRS → “Where should it run?” Implemented by: VMware vSphere Executed via: VMware vCenter Server Acts on: VMs inside a cluster VCF assumes DRS is enabled and automated for predictable behavior. Initial Placement – chooses the best host when a VM powers on Continuous Balancing – monitors CPU & memory pressure Live Migration – moves VMs using vMotion Rule Enforcement – respects affinity / anti-affinity constraints If HA answers “Can the VM run?”, DRS answers “Where should the VM run right now?” VCF designs assume Fully Automated DRS.DRS continuously evaluates: Host CPU utilization Host memory pressure VM demand & entitlements Resource Pool shares & limits Affinity / anti-affinity rules When imbalance exceeds a threshold: → vMotion is triggered → No VM restartDRS is performance & fairness, not failure recovery.DRS can enforce rules such as: “These VMs must stay together” “These VMs must never share a host” Typical use cases: App + cache locality HA for clustered apps Licensing constraints ⚠️ Over-constraining rules reduces DRS effectiveness.DRS respects: Resource Pool shares Resource Pool reservations Resource Pool limits Meaning: DRS balances within the rules you define — it does not override governance. In VCF, clusters are typically:Cluster ├── HA: Enabled ├── DRS: Fully Automated ├── Admission Control: On └── vMotion: Required If DRS is disabled: Initial placement degrades Load hotspots form HA restarts may fail due to poor placement ❌ Not a tenant boundary ❌ Not a scaling mechanism ❌ Not application-aware ❌ Not Kubernetes scheduling DRS operates strictly at the VM + host layer.❌ Disabling DRS for “predictability” → Creates hotspots and manual ops❌ Overusing VM-Host affinity rules → Breaks automatic balancing❌ Expecting DRS to fix under-provisioning → It redistributes; it does not create capacity DRS is the brain of a vSphere cluster It continuously optimizes where VMs run VCF assumes DRS is enabled and automated HA + DRS together provide resilience + efficiency If you want, next we can stack these side-by-side as a HA vs DRS vs vMotion vs Admission Control matrix — that’s often the “aha” moment in VCF mental models.DRSIaaS (infrastructure as a service) is a cloud computing model where you rent fundamental IT infrastructure—instead of owning and managing physical hardware.IaaS provides fundamental computing resources where the consumer can deploy and run arbitrary software, including operating systems and applications.In plain terms: IaaS = someone else runs the data center; you control the machines. The cloud provider gives you raw building blocks: Compute → virtual machines (VMs) Storage → block, object, file storage Networking → virtual networks, IPs, load balancers, firewalls You decide: Which OS to run How to configure the machine What software to install How to secure and scale it Analogy: Owning hardware → buying a house IaaS → renting an empty apartment (walls and plumbing are there; furniture and rules are up to you) Amazon Web Services → EC2 Microsoft Azure → Virtual Machines Google Cloud → Compute Engine All of these give you VMs, networks, and storage—but no application opinion.Example: IaaS → “Give me a Linux box” PaaS → “Run my app” SaaS → “Just let me use the app” Maximum control and flexibility Works for legacy apps Fine-grained networking & security Familiar mental model for infra engineers You manage OS patching and security Higher operational burden Easier to misconfigure Less opinionated guardrails
vSphere-style VM workloads map very naturally to IaaS VCF abstracts hardware, but still exposes infra
Kubernetes-on-VCF starts moving you away from pure IaaS toward PaaS-like models
That’s why a workload is a workload is a workload: From the platform’s perspective, VMs and pods are both just scheduled consumers of infrastructure. IaaS = rented infrastructure You control the OS and above Most flexible, most responsibility Foundation layer beneath PaaS and SaaS Conceptually closest to traditional virtualization
From here, going back to the beginning and exploring VMware Cloud Foundation with an understanding of what IaaS is, is not a bad choice.IaaS
In VMware Cloud Foundation, “VCF SDK APIs and CLIs” are programmable control surfaces that expose VCF capabilities for automation, integration, and at-scale operations. They sit above the infrastructure components (vCenter, NSX, vSAN) and below higher-level portals, giving you deterministic, supportable ways to drive the platform.┌──────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ Portals / UIs │ │ - VCF Automation UI │ │ - SDDC Manager UI │ ├──────────────────────────────────────────────┤ │ SDK APIs & CLIs ← YOU ARE HERE │ │ - REST APIs │ │ - Official CLIs │ │ - Language SDKs (where provided) │ ├──────────────────────────────────────────────┤ │ Platform Control Planes │ │ - SDDC Manager │ │ - VCF Automation │ ├──────────────────────────────────────────────┤ │ Product APIs │ │ - vCenter / NSX / vSAN │ └──────────────────────────────────────────────┘
VCF APIs abstract platform intent (*domains, lifecycle, tenancy**), not raw hypervisor knobs.SDDC Manager REST APIs expose everything SDDC Manager knows and controls: Bring-up and expansion
Workload Domain lifecycle Host add/remove
Cluster creation End-to-end upgrades (LCM) Inventory, versions, and health These APIs are the authoritative way to automate VCF without breaking supportability. If it changes VCF topology or lifecycle, it goes through SDDC Manager APIs. CI/CD pipelines Infrastructure-as-Code tools
Day-2 automation frameworks Internal platforms and runbooks
These are about consumption and Governance.APIs for tenant-facing operations such as:
Organizations and Projects Policies and approvals
Blueprints / templates Workload provisioning (VMs, Kubernetes-backed services) These APIs sit closer to business intent than infrastructure detail. SDDC Manager APIs → Build and maintain the cloud VCF Automation APIs → Consume the cloud These are both human and also script friendly.Used for: Diagnostics Operational workflows Automation-friendly scripting Break-glass scenarios It is a thin wrapper over SDDC Manager APIs, with guardrails.This is: A faster iteration than REST during ops An easier integration into shell scripts Provides consistent auth and context handling CLIs are not separate systems — they are API clients.These are language bindings.Where available, VMware/Broadcom provides SDKs that wrap REST APIs in native language constructs: Object models Typed requests/responses Auth helpers Pagination, retries, error handling These SDKs are ideal when: You are building a platform or product You need maintainable, testable code Shell scripts are no longer enough They do not:
Replace vCenter or NSX APIs Provide low-level tuning knobs Allow unsupported lifecycle paths Let you bypass validation logic
This is by design. VCF optimizes for predictability and supportability over raw flexibility. Git declares desired domains / versions Pipeline calls SDDC Manager APIs Platform converges safely Internal UI talks to VCF Automation APIs End users never see infrastructure details Health checks Controlled upgrades Capacity expansion All API-driven, no UI clicks. VCF SDK APIs are the supported automation surface SDDC Manager APIs control lifecycle and topology VCF Automation APIs control consumption and governance CLIs are just API clients Using these APIs preserves VCF invariants and supportability
Since it’s related to APIs, you might want to check out what a Gated SDK is.VCF SDKs, APIs, and CLIs

VCF Installer is the one-time (or rare-use) bootstrap and bring-up tool for VMware Cloud Foundation.
VCF Installer’s sole purpose is to stand up the very first VCF environment and hand control over to SDDC Manager.
If SDDC Manager is the factory control system, VCF Installer is the factory construction crew that builds the factory in the first place.
VCF Installer exists to answer a very specific question: “Given raw hardware, how do I get to a fully functional VCF Management Domain with SDDC Manager running?” Once that answer is executed successfully, VCF Installer is done.VCF Installer is responsible for: Validating hardware readiness Validating network configuration Validating DNS / NTP / IPAM Validating credentials and certificates Orchestrating the initial deployment of:
ESX on hosts
vCenter Server
NSX
SDDC Manager itself
Management Domain components
This is Day-0 only work.Before anything is deployed, VCF Installer runs extensive prechecks, including: Hardware compatibility (HCL alignment) Network reachability MTU consistency IP pool correctness Time synchronization DNS forward/reverse lookup Credential access Think of it as a fail-fast safety gate: Better to stop early than build a broken cloud.VCF Installer typically operates with: Structured input (JSON / guided wizard) Explicit topology definitions Explicit IP assignments You declare what you want, and the installer executes a deterministic build.There is no concept of “incremental evolution” here: That belongs to SDDC Manager.It is not: A lifecycle manager A long-running control plane A tenant or consumption interface A policy engine An operations tool After bring-up: It is not used daily It does not manage upgrades It does not manage workload domains
Those responsibilities move entirely to the SDDC Manager.Once installation completes:
SDDC Manager becomes the authoritative owner VCF Installer steps out of the picture You can think of it as: VCF Installer creates SDDC Manager; SDDC Manager creates and manages everything else. A natural question is: “Why not just use SDDC Manager from the start?”Because: SDDC Manager itself must be deployed That deployment requires validated sequencing That sequencing must run before SDDC Manager exists VCF Installer solves this bootstrapping paradox. VCF Installer → kubeadm init
SDDC Manager → Kubernetes control plane (after init)
VCF Automation → Higher-level UX / APIs for consumers You don’t run kubeadm init every day, and you don’t run VCF Installer every day either. VCF Installer is a Day-0 tool It bootstraps the Management Domain
It deploys the SDDC Manager itself It performs strict prechecks and validation After success, it is effectively retired
Why not look into VCF Fleet Deployment?VCF InstallerVCF Operations Orchestrator provides a library of workflows that perform common management tasks. VCF Operations Orchestrator also provides libraries of the individual actions that the workflows perform.Workflows combine actions, decisions, and results that, when performed in a particular order, finish a specific task or a specific process in a virtual environment.Workflows perform tasks such as provisioning virtual machines, backing up, performing regular maintenance, sending emails, performing SSH operations, managing the physical infrastructure, and other general utility operations. Workflows accept inputs according to their function.You can create workflows that run according to defined schedules, or that run if certain anticipated events occur.Information can be provided by you, by other users, by another workflow or action, or by an external process such as a Web service call from an application.Workflows perform some validation and filtering of information before they run.Workflows can be chained. That is, they can call upon other workflows. For example, you can have workflow that calls up another workflow to create a new virtual machine.You create workflows by using the VCF Operations Orchestrator’s integrated development environment (IDE), that provides access to the workflow library and the ability to run workflows on the workflow engine.The workflow engine can also take objects from external libraries that you plug in to the VCF Operations Orchestrator. This allows you to customize processes or implement functions that third-party applications provide.
Why not check out Running VCF Operations Orchestrator Workflows?VCF Operations Orchestrator
See also: vSphere ClusterYes’nt.
A vSphere Cluster and a Supervisor Cluster are not the same thing. However, they are so tightly-related in a Supervisor-enabled Namespace, you can “colloquially” say that they are the same.Yet, they sit at different abstraction layers.This is the base construct.A vSphere Cluster is a classic virtualization construct: A group of [[ESX] hosts
Managed by vCenter Provides: [DRS] (scheduling) [HA] (failover) Resource Pooling (CPU / memory) Shared storage and networking However, vSphere Cluster alone does not imply Any Kubernetes Any namespaces Any tenants Any container workloads You can run only VMs, forever, and never enable anything Kubernetes-related.This is the layer on top.A Supervisor Cluster is not a separate cluster of hosts.It is:
A Kubernetes control plane embedded into a vSphere Cluster
When you enable the Supervisor feature on vSphere:
vSphere deploys Kubernetes control plane VMs
ESX hosts become Kubernetes worker nodes vSphere exposes:
Supervisor Namespaces
Pod Workloads
Guest Clusters (e.g., VKS)
vSphere becomes Kubernetes-aware
The key point is: The same ESX hosts of the same vSphere Cluster are used, but now they serve two schedulers**:
vSphere (VMs) Kubernetes (pods / guest clusters) So the formal relationship is: A Supervisor Cluster is a capability of a vSphere Cluster, not a different cluster type. But, it walks like a duck, talks like a duck, and it surely is a very-sophisticated duck: Operationally, and practically, it is the same thing.
A Supervisor Cluster is a Kubernetes control plane that runs on and transforms a vSphere Cluster into a Kubernetes-aware platform.For the ontology-enthusiasts out there:This matters a lot. vSphere cluster failure → everything dies
Supervisor control plane failure → VMs keep running Although subtle, this distinction becomes very important when discussing: Security boundaries Upgrade paths Failure isolation Scheduling semantics
VCF Automation mappings
In a Supervisor-enabled vSphere, the Supervisor Cluster and the vSphere Cluster are co-resident and inseparable operationally, but they remain distinct architectural constructs with different control planes and failure domains.
After clarifying this subtle distinction, vSphere Supervisor could be something worth exploring.Supervisor Cluster

about-me/my-mental-model.html.title: My Mental Model
about-me/my-mental-model.html.description:
I think of mental models as compression algorithms for reality.A mental model is an internal, simplified representation of how something works in the real world. It’s the framework the mind uses to understand, predict, and decide—often without conscious awareness.It is a map, not the territory.In my view, a mental model is: A conceptual structure in the mind Built from experience, learning, and assumptions Used to explain cause → effect and anticipate outcomes It answers questions like: “If I do X, what will probably happen?” “Why did that fail?” “What matters here—and what doesn’t?” Imagine driving in a foreign city. The actual city is reality: complex, messy, and full of detail Your mental model is a rough subway map in your head That map: Omits small streets Distorts distances Focuses only on what helps you get from A → B It is useful precisely because it ignores detail—even if it’s inaccurate in places.That is what this (mostly) directed acyclic graph of documents (with occasional—intentional—loops) is trying to establish for VMware Cloud Foundation: A navigable mental map, not an exhaustive representation of reality.The goal is not to describe everything, but to surface the abstractions that help me (and you, dear reader) reason correctly.Mental models exist because the human brain cannot process full reality in real time.Mental models: Reduce cognitive load Enable faster decisions Allow generalization from experience A single concept can be viewed through multiple overlapping mental models.For example, a database can be seen as: A storage engine A consistency system A failure domain A political boundary (ownership and control) Each model is incomplete on its own. Taken together, they are powerful. This document intentionally favors some mental models over others—not because they are “more correct,” but because they are more useful for the problems at hand.
← Back to Index

vcf/concepts/background-and-context/iaas.title: IaaS
vcf/concepts/background-and-context/iaas.description:
IaaS (infrastructure as a service) is a cloud computing model where you rent fundamental IT infrastructure—instead of owning and managing physical hardware.IaaS provides fundamental computing resources where the consumer can deploy and run arbitrary software, including operating systems and applications.In plain terms: IaaS = someone else runs the data center; you control the machines. The cloud provider gives you raw building blocks: Compute → virtual machines (VMs) Storage → block, object, file storage Networking → virtual networks, IPs, load balancers, firewalls You decide: Which OS to run How to configure the machine What software to install How to secure and scale it Analogy: Owning hardware → buying a house IaaS → renting an empty apartment (walls and plumbing are there; furniture and rules are up to you) Amazon Web Services → EC2 Microsoft Azure → Virtual Machines Google Cloud → Compute Engine All of these give you VMs, networks, and storage—but no application opinion.Example: IaaS → “Give me a Linux box” PaaS → “Run my app” SaaS → “Just let me use the app” Maximum control and flexibility Works for legacy apps Fine-grained networking & security Familiar mental model for infra engineers You manage OS patching and security Higher operational burden Easier to misconfigure Less opinionated guardrails vSphere-style VM workloads map very naturally to IaaS VCF abstracts hardware, but still exposes infra
Kubernetes-on-VCF starts moving you away from pure IaaS toward PaaS-like models
That’s why a workload is a workload is a workload: From the platform’s perspective, VMs and pods are both just scheduled consumers of infrastructure. IaaS = rented infrastructure You control the OS and above Most flexible, most responsibility Foundation layer beneath PaaS and SaaS Conceptually closest to traditional virtualization
From here, going back to the beginning and exploring VMware Cloud Foundation with an understanding of what IaaS is, is not a bad choice.

vcf/concepts/governance-and-compliance/p.title: Policy
vcf/concepts/governance-and-compliance/p.description:
#tenancy

A Policy in VCF is a Governance Rule that defines what is allowed, constrained, or enforced across infrastructure and workloads.
It exists across multiple layers of VCF, but it becomes a first-class, user-visible construct in VCF Automation.
If you think of VMware Cloud Foundation as a city: Infrastructure → roads, power, zoning Policies → zoning laws, speed limits, building codes
VCF Automation → city planning office that enforces them before you build
VCF Operations → inspectors that check compliance after things exist
These are foundational, implicit, and exist below VCF Automation, often enforced automatically.Examples: Storage policies (SPBM): RAID, availability, performance tiers
Network policies: NSX security groups, microsegmentation rules
Host policies: DRS, HA, admission control These are:
Defined in vSphere / NSX Consumed transparently by higher layers Not tenant-facing by default This is usually what people mean when they say “policy”.This is where Policy becomes a named, explicit, governable object.
In VCF Automation, policies define constraints and guardrails for consumers.Examples: Who can deploy what Where workloads can land What sizes, images, or networks are allowed Lease durations and approval requirements Typical policy categories: Placement policies: Which clusters, regions, zones Sizing policies: CPU, memory, storage limits Image policies: Approved OS images only Network policies: allowed networks / isolation Approval policies: manual gates for certain actions Lease policies: TTL and reclamation rules These policies are evaluated before provisioning.
In VCF Automation, policies are usually scoped to:
- Organizations
- or ProjectsThey act as guardrails, not implementation detailsExample: “In Project Prod, only Gold storage, max 16 vCPU, and approval required.” This is where policy intersects with consumption abstraction.
In **VCF Operations, policy ≠ enforcement.VCF Operations uses policy indirectly.
In VCF Operations: Policies become: Alerts Compliance checks Drift detection Optimization rules
VCF Operations answers: “Is reality still compliant with the policy?”
VCF Automation answers: “Should this action be allowed at all, in the first place?”
A Policy in VMware Cloud Foundation is a governance rule, not a single product feature
VCF Automation is where policies are: Explicit Named Scoped Evaluated before action
VCF Operations observes and reports compliance Infrastructure layers actually enforce the low-level mechanics
STIG can be an interesting topic that can complement policies.
You might also want to check out VCF Roles and Permissions.
vcf/concepts/governance-and-compliance/p.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/concepts/governance-and-compliance/p.title: Policy as Code
vcf/concepts/governance-and-compliance/p.description:
#tenancy
Policy as Code (PaC) in VMware Cloud Foundation means defining, enforcing, and validating cloud governance rules using version-controlled code, rather than ad-hoc UI settings or manual procedures. Policies become executable, testable artifacts that are evaluated automatically as part of provisioning, configuration, and ongoing operations.
PaC is “guardrails expressed in code” that continuously shape what is allowed in your VPC.
Policy as Code is not a single product in VCF—it is a cross-cutting pattern implemented across multiple layers:This is where PaC is most explicit and visible.
Policies are applied to:
Organizations
Projects
Blueprints Deployments Examples: Who can deploy what Which regions, clusters, or storage types are allowed Maximum CPU / memory / cost Required approvals before deployment Policies are: Evaluated before provisioning Enforced during lifecycle actions Stored and versioned
At the Kubernetes layer (vSphere Supervisor + Guest Clusters):
Policies are expressed using tools like Open Policy Agent) Enforced as admission controls Prevent non-compliant workloads from being created Examples: Pods must not run as root Images must come from approved registries Network policies are mandatory Resource limits must be defined This is PaC in its purest form: Declarative rules evaluated at runtime.VCF PaC complements Terraform, Ansible, and CI/CD pipelines: Policies validate IaC plans before apply Prevent drift and unsafe configurations Align infra provisioning with governance rules Who can deploy Where they can deploy What resources they can consume Encryption requirements Network isolation Image provenance
STIG / CIS alignment Resource quotas Budget limits Placement constraints Approval Workflows Lease durations Auto-decommission rules Without Policy as Code “Please remember not to deploy large VMs in prod.” With Policy as Code “Deployments violating this rule are automatically rejected.” PaC the difference between: Guidelines vs guarantees Human memory vs machine enforcement Audit after the fact vs prevention by design
From VMware’s perspective, PaC is critical because VCF serves: Regulated industries (telco, finance, gov) Multi-tenant private clouds Platform teams supporting many consumers So, Policy as Code enables: Consistency at scale
Auditable Governance Safe self-service Policy as Code in VCF = governance expressed as executable rules Most visible in VCF Automation, but spans infra, Kubernetes, and security Enables guardrails, not gates Essential for multi-tenant, regulated private clouds A foundational concept, not a single feature
STIG might be a related concept to explore from this point.

headers.heading: Where Does PaC Live in VCF
What Does the Policy Code Govern

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: User Roles
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
Roles assigned to users and groups are an essential part to identity and access management in VCF Automation.
You can leverage identity providers with Organizations to enable single sign-on to provision users and groups. Once the users and groups are added to the Organization, they must be assigned roles to enable specific permissions and access to different features within  VCF Automation.
VCF Automation has several levels of user roles. These different levels control access to the Organization, the Projects that produce or consume the Blueprints, Catalog Items, access to IaaS Services, and the ability for users to use or see individual parts of the user interface. These different levels give Organization Administrators different tools to apply any level of granularity that is required by their operational needs.
Here are the predefined user roles in **VCF Automation. You can visit each link to see more details about them. Organization Roles
Organization Administrator
Organization User
Organization Auditor Project Roles
Project Administrator
Project Auditor
Project Advanced User
Project User
Defer to Identity Provider User permissions can also be determined based on information received from the identity provider for the Organization.
Organization Management could be a good area to explore after getting acquainted with the user roles here. Additionally, you can find a more detailed listing of what permissions these roles have in VCF Roles and Permissions.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.title: Virtual Machine
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.description: A virtual machine (VM) is a software-defined computer that behaves like a physical machine but runs on top of a virtualization layer rather than directly on hardware.You can think of it as a full computer implemented in software.Each VM: Has its own CPU, memory, disk, and network Runs its own operating system Is isolated from other VMs Believes it owns real hardware (even though it doesn’t) The key component is the hypervisor.The hypervisor: Intercepts CPU instructions Schedules CPU time Maps virtual memory → physical memory Virtualizes I/O (disk, NIC, GPU, etc.) From the VM’s perspective: “I am running on bare metal.” From reality: “You are one of many guests sharing a host.” A VM is not just an OS. It consists of: Virtual hardware vCPU(s) vRAM Virtual disk(s) Virtual NIC(s) Firmware BIOS or UEFI Operating system Linux, Windows, BSD, etc. Applications Databases, web servers, middleware, etc. Even though the term VM is generic, VCF treats the VM as a first-class workload unit: A VM is: A managed workload Governed by policies Scheduled onto clusters Subject to lifecycle operations (create, move, snapshot, delete) VCF doesn’t care why the VM exists It cares how to place, secure, move, and operate it A VM is a full computer implemented in software It runs an OS and applications like a physical machine The hypervisor provides isolation and resource sharing VMs remain foundational—even in modern cloud platforms In VCF, a VM is a core workload primitive, not a legacy artifact

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: What is a VKS Cluster
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
A VKS cluster is a Kubernetes cluster that is built and supported by VMware and that runs your application workloads. VKS clusters are part of a vSphere Kubernetes Service ( VKS ) deployment. You use VKS cluster management to manage VKS clusters. Their life cycle, however, is handled by the native Supervisor APIs.Relation Between VKS and VCF AutomationVKS provides self-service life cycle management of Kubernetes workload clusters. VKS is an implementation of the open-source Cluster API project that defines a set of custom resources and controllers to manage the life cycle of Kubernetes clusters. VKS is a component of Supervisor. The Supervisor is a source of compute resources that can be registered to VCF Automation. System administrators allocate the Supervisor resources to the organizations in VCF Automation. The Supervisor itself does not belong to any organization. Project acministrators request vSphere Namespaces for projects, and VCF Automation allocates vSphere Namespaces matching the request.A single Supervisor can provide resources for multiple VCF Automation organizations.Within a single organization, you can move vSphere Namespaces from one project to another.For more information about organizations and projects within the context of VKS cluster management, see Hierarchy of the Resources That VKS Cluster Management Works With.For more information about VKS
, see vSphere Supervisor Platform and the Managing vSphere Kubernetes Service with vSphere Supervisor documentation.Agents and Extensions Installed on the VKS ClusterTo function properly, VKS cluster management depends on a set of agents and extensions that run in all VKS clusters. When a VKS cluster is attached to VKS cluster management, the Supervisor auto-attach service installs a set of extensions and cluster resource definitions to the cluster nodes.The agents configuration contains information about the correct VKS cluster management endpoint, the image registry that provides the images, and the proxy configuration.Cluster HealthThe overall health of a cluster is an aggregation of the health of the components and nodes in the cluster.The health status of the cluster can be one of the following values: Healthy A cluster is healthy when all nodes and components are healthy, and a heartbeat for the cluster is received every minute. Unhealthy A cluster is unhealthy if either of the following is reported as unhealthy: One or more of the cluster’s control plane nodes One or more of the cluster’s components Warning A cluster can have a warning status if any of its worker nodes are in an unhealthy or unknown state. A cluster can also have a warning status if any nodes (worker or control plane) are in a warning state. Unknown The health status of a cluster in unknown if either of the following is reported as unknown: One or more of the cluster’s control plane nodes One or more of the cluster’s components Disconnected A cluster is considered disconnected if no heartbeat is received from the cluster for more than 3 minutes. Node HealthThe information received for a node consists of the NodeReady condition, and a number of other conditions like MemoryPressure, DiskPressure, and OutOfDisk. VKS cluster management uses the value of these conditions to discover the health of the node. The status of each condition is assumed to be unchanged until the node reports a change.Based on the reported conditions, the health status of a node can be one of the following: Healthy If  NodeReady  is  True  and all other conditions are healthy, the node is healthy. Unhealthy The node is unhealthy if  NodeReady  is  False . The node is also unhealthy if  NodeReady  is  True , but more than half of the other conditions are in an unhealthy state. Warning The warning status indicates that  NodeReady  is  True , and less than half of the other conditions are in an unhealthy state. Unknown If  NodeReady  has any value other than  True  or  False , the health status of the node is  Unknown . The node can also have an unknown status if  VKS  cluster management receives no heartbeat from the cluster for more than three minutes. Component HealthVKS cluster management monitors the health of the following components running in the cluster: The  kube-apiserver The  scheduler The  controller-manager One or more  etcd  components ( etcd-0 ,  etcd-1 ,  etcd-2 , and so on) The component status event reports the Healthy condition for each of these components every 45 seconds.The health status of each component can be one of the following: Healthy If the last reported value of the  Healthy  condition of the component is  True , the component is  Healthy . Unhealthy If the last reported value of the  Healthy  condition of the component is  False , the component is  Unhealthy . Unknown If the last reported value of the  Healthy  condition of the component is  Unknown  or it is something other than  True  or  False , the health status of the component is  Unknown . The component can also be in this state if  VKS  cluster management receives no heartbeat from the cluster for more than three minutes

vcf/concepts/tenancy-in-vcf/administrati.title: Administrative Roles in VCF
vcf/concepts/tenancy-in-vcf/administrati.description:
#tenancy
In VMware Cloud Foundation, Platform Admin and Tenant Admin are useful conceptual terms, but not official role names in VCF.VCF defines explicit, documented roles such as:
Organization Administrator
Project Administrator (and related Auditor / User roles) This page uses Platform Admin as a conceptual responsibility boundary, and Organization / Project Administrator as the official tenant-facing roles defined by VCF.The distinction is intentional and fundamental.
VCF separates infrastructure ownership from consumption governance: platform infrastructure is operated outside VCF Automation, while Organization Administrators and Project Administrators govern what runs within tenant boundaries.
Organization Administrator has Tenant-level authority.
An Organization Administrator represents the tenant boundary in VCF Automation.They manage: Organization-level configuration Tenant users and role assignments Organization-wide quotas and policies Governance within the organization They cannot: Modify platform topology Upgrade core infrastructure Affect other organizations Bypass platform guardrails
The Project Administrator is a Project-scoped operational authority.
A Project Administrator manages consumption and operations within a single Project, which maps to one (typical, but can be more than one) Supervisor Namespace.
The Project Administrator can create Projects, assign users and groups, and allocate quotas to restrict the configurations available to the tenants. |
By creating Projects, you can isolate security and networking objects across tenants in a single NSX deployment. Project Administrators manage: Project users and access Workload provisioning (VMs, Kubernetes clusters, services) Project-scoped quotas and approvals Day-to-day operational policies Their authority is strictly bounded by:
The Organization Platform-defined constraints Without this separation: Tenants could break upgrade paths Platform consistency would erode Supportability would collapse One tenant could impact others VCF deliberately trades tenant flexibility for platform predictability, safety, and lifecycle integrity. Organization Administrator is the true tenant administrator in VCF 9 Project Administrator governs consumption within a tenant The separation protects multi-tenancy, lifecycle management, and supportability This boundary is foundational to VCF’s architecture
VCF Roles and Permissions is the logical follow-up to this section, which dives into more details of predefined roles and privileges in **VMware Cloud Foundation.

headers.heading: What Organization and Project Administrators Own

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: Running VCF Operations Orchestrator Workflows
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description:
VCF Operations Orchestrator workflows run according to a logical flow of events.When you run a workflow, each schema element in the workflow runs according to the following sequence. The workflow binds the workflow token variables and input parameters to the input parameters of the schema element. The schema element runs. The output parameters of the schema element are copied to the workflow token variables and workflow output parameters. The workflow token variables and workflow output parameters are stored in the database. The next schema element starts running. This sequence repeats for each schema element until the end of the workflow.
When a workflow runs, each schema element is a check point. After each schema element runs, VCF Operations Orchestrator stores workflow token variables in the database, and the next schema element starts running.If the workflow stops unexpectedly, the next time the Orchestrator Server restarts, the currently active schema element runs again, and the workflow continues from the start of the schema element that was running when the interruption occurred.
That being said, VCF Operations Orchestrator does not implement transaction management or a rollback function.The workflow ends if the current active schema element is an end element.After the workflow reaches an end element, other workflows or applications can use the output parameters of the workflow.
You might like to check out Fleet Management or VMware Data Services Manager, or VMware Skyline as they tangentially relate to workflows.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Platform Operations and Services/Platform Services and Management/Workflow Management/Running VCF Operations Orchestrator Workflows.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: VCF Operations Orchestrator
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description: VCF Operations Orchestrator provides a library of workflows that perform common management tasks. VCF Operations Orchestrator also provides libraries of the individual actions that the workflows perform.Workflows combine actions, decisions, and results that, when performed in a particular order, finish a specific task or a specific process in a virtual environment.Workflows perform tasks such as provisioning virtual machines, backing up, performing regular maintenance, sending emails, performing SSH operations, managing the physical infrastructure, and other general utility operations. Workflows accept inputs according to their function.You can create workflows that run according to defined schedules, or that run if certain anticipated events occur.Information can be provided by you, by other users, by another workflow or action, or by an external process such as a Web service call from an application.Workflows perform some validation and filtering of information before they run.Workflows can be chained. That is, they can call upon other workflows. For example, you can have workflow that calls up another workflow to create a new virtual machine.You create workflows by using the VCF Operations Orchestrator’s integrated development environment (IDE), that provides access to the workflow library and the ability to run workflows on the workflow engine.The workflow engine can also take objects from external libraries that you plug in to the VCF Operations Orchestrator. This allows you to customize processes or implement functions that third-party applications provide.Why not check out Running VCF Operations Orchestrator Workflows?
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Platform Operations and Services/Platform Services and Management/Workflow Management/VCF Operations Orchestrator.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: Workflow
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description:
Workflows consist of a schema, workflow variables, and input and output parameters.The workflow schema is the main component of a workflow as it defines all the workflow elements and the logical connections between them. The workflow variables and parameters are the properties that workflows use to transfer data.

In VMware Cloud Foundation, there isn’t a single “workflow engine” owned by only one product. Different parts of VCF create/execute different kinds of workflows:
VCF Automation is the place where you typically design and run “day-1” style workflows tied to requests (catalog items, provisioning, configuration, approvals, extensibility, etc.). Its value prop explicitly includes orchestration and extensibility.
Under the hood, these workflows commonly leverage an Orchestrator (formerly vRealize Orchestrator) integrated/embedded with the automation stack. It is executed by VCF Operations Orchestrator which is a part of the VCF Operations stack.
VCF Operations is primarily the ops brain: monitoring, alerting, capacity, compliance, etc.. It can run actions (and sometimes chain remediation) in response to alerts.
Actual workflow automation is done through VCF Operations Orchestrator, which is explicitly described as a “workflow automation solution” and can create and run workflows.
VCF Operations Orchestrator saves a workflow token every time a workflow runs, recording the details of that specific workflow run.Workflows receive input parameters and generate output parameters when they run.Most workflows require a certain set of input parameters to run. An input parameter is an argument that the workflow processes when it runs. The user, an application, another workflow, or an action passes input parameters to a workflow for the workflow to process when it runs.For example, if a workflow resets a virtual machine, the workflow requires the name of the virtual machine as an input parameter.A workflow's output parameters represent the result from the workflow run. Output parameters can change when a workflow or a workflow element runs. During a workflow run, the workflow can receive the output parameters of other workflows as input parameters.For example, if a workflow creates a snapshot of a virtual machine, the output parameter for the workflow is the resulting snapshot.Workflow elements process data that they receive as input parameters, and set the resulting data as workflow variables or output parameters.Read-only workflow variables act as global constants for a workflow. Writable variables act as a workflow’s global variables.You can use variables to transfer data between the elements of a workflow.You can obtain variables in the following ways: Define variables when you create a workflow. Set the output parameter of a workflow element as a workflow variable. Inherit variables from a configuration element. A workflow schema is a graphical representation that shows the workflow as a flow diagram of interconnected workflow elements. The workflow schema is the most important element of a workflow as it determines its logic.When users run a workflow, they provide the values for the input parameters of the workflow in the workflow presentation.A workflow token represents a workflow that is running or has finished running.A workflow is an abstract description of a process that defines a generic sequence of steps and a generic set of required input parameters. When you run a workflow with a set of input parameters, you receive an instance of this abstract workflow that behaves according to the specific input parameters you give it. This specific instance of a finished or a running workflow is called a workflow token.Workflow Token Attributes are the specific parameters with which a workflow token runs.The workflow token attributes are an aggregation of the workflow's global variables and the specific input and output parameters with which you run the workflow token.
Next, you might want to look into Running VCF Operations Orchestrator Workflows, or you can check out VCF Operations Orchestrator.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Platform Operations and Services/Platform Services and Management/Workflow Management/Workflow.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Supervisor Administrator
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
In VMware Cloud Foundation, Supervisor Administrator is a new, platform-level role introduced to formalize control over the Supervisor Cluster itself, and it sits orthogonally to— not above or below—the traditional Organization / Project roles.
Supervisor Administrator manages the platform that hosts tenants, while Organization Administrator manages the tenants themselves, and Project Administrator manages what runs inside those tenants. VCF separates responsibilities cleanly into three distinct administrative planes, each with its own roles:→ “How the Kubernetes substrate itself is operated”This is where the Supervisor Cluster lives.→ “Who consumes the infrastructure and how”
This is where Organizations, Projects, and quotas live.→ “What runs on top of it”
This is where Kubernetes workloads, namespaces, and apps live.
Scope: Supervisor Cluster (platform level)Primary responsibility:
Operates and governs the Supervisor Cluster itself Manages cluster-level capabilities that all tenants depend on Typical responsibilities:
Configure and manage Supervisor Cluster lifecycle Control Supervisor services (e.g., Kubernetes control plane, CSI, CNI, storage integrations)
Define which Organizations can exist
Enable or disable platform features available to Organizations Maintain host, networking, and storage alignment required for Kubernetes workloads Supervisor Administrator does not manage application workloads or tenant namespaces.From the Supervisor Administrator’s point of view: “I run the Kubernetes platform that everyone else builds on.”
Organization Administrator is the tenant-level authority.
Scope: Organization (tenant boundary)Role type: Consumer / tenant administratorResponsibilities:
Create and manage Projects Assign users to projects and roles Define quotas and usage limits Control access within their organization Govern how their organization consumes platform capacity They do not manage the Supervisor Cluster itself.
From the Organization Administrator’s perspective: “I manage my organization’s slice of the platform.”
Project Administrator has workload-level control over the project they have access to.
Scope: Single Project within an OrganizationResponsibilities: Manage Kubernetes workloads (clusters, namespaces, services) Manage users within the project Configure project-level policies and resources
They operate inside boundaries defined by the Organization Admin and enforced by the Supervisor.
From Project Administrator’s point of view: “I manage workloads, not the platform.” Supervisor Administrator │ ├── Organization Administrator │ ├── Project Administrator │ │ └── Application / Workload Operators │ └── Project Users │ └── (Multiple Organizations) Supervisor Admin ≠ Super Org Admin They operate at different abstraction layers Historically, roles like this were blurry or implicit (vSphere Admin, Cloud Admin, etc.).VCF introduces clear separation of concerns:This aligns VCF with cloud provider models (for, i.e., AWS control plane vs account admins).
← Back to User Roles

headers.heading: The Three Different Control Planes in VCF

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: Cloud Services Console
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description:
Cloud Services Console is VMware’s SaaS control plane for identity, organizations, subscriptions, and service access across VMware cloud offerings.
If vCenter answers “what is running?”, CSC answers: “Who are you, what are you entitled to, and which VMware services can you access?”
VMware SaaS Layer └── Cloud Services Console (CSC) ├── Identity and Org management ├── Subscriptions & entitlements └── Access to VMware cloud services On-prem / Private Cloud └── VCF ├── vSphere / NSX / vSAN └── SDDC Manager CSC: Runs as: VMware-hosted SaaS Audience: Org owners, platform leads, service-provider admins Does not touch datapaths or place workloads Defines Organizations Manages users, roles, and access Integrates with enterprise IdPs (SSO)
This is business identity, not vCenter RBAC. Shows what your org is entitled to: VCF subscriptions Optional VMware services Central place to view contracts → services CSC does not meter usage—that’s elsewhere.From CSC you access: Support portals VMware cloud SaaS Management consoles (where applicable) CSC is the front door, not the engine room.CSC ≠ BSC CSC is VMware-global; BSC is VCF-specific. CSC knows about your subscriptions
VCF consumes those entitlements CSC does not: Provision domains Run LCM Enforce quotas Observe performance
That work stays on-prem with VCF components. Not part of the VCF runtime Not an ops or automation tool Not a billing/metering engine Not a tenant boundary for workloads If VCF is: “Your private cloud platform” Then CSC is: “Your VMware account and service access hub” Cloud Services Console = SaaS identity and entitlement layer Global across VMware services
Adjacent to VCF, not embedded in it
Often confused with VCF Business Services Console—they serve different roles Why not check out Day-N Operations:
VCF Day 0 Tasks
VCF Day 1 Tasks
VCF Day 2 Tasks

headers.heading: Entry point to VMware cloud services
How Does CSC and VCF Relate

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: Fleet Management
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description:
Fleet management in VMware Cloud Foundation is the centralized, policy-driven governance of many infrastructure instances (hosts, clusters, domains, appliances) across their entire lifecycle—from onboarding and entitlement to upgrades, credentials, certificates, configuration drift, and metadata.A fleet typically includes:
Multiple Workload Domains
Multiple vCenter Servers
NSX Managers & NSX Edge Clusters
ESX hosts (often hundreds or thousands)
Supporting appliances (SDDC Manager, vSAN, etc.) Fleet management answers: “How do we keep all of these consistent, compliant, secure, and up-to-date over years?” Central license inventory Assignment to:
vCenter / ESX
NSX
vSAN Alignment with subscription usage
SDDC Manager
VCF Usage Meter
VCF Business Services Console Licenses are fleet-level entitlements, not per-host snowflakes. VCF ensures: No silent overuse No orphaned entitlements Auditable usage
SDDC Manager
Bring-up (VCF Day 0 Tasks)
Patching and upgrades (VCF Day 2 Tasks) Version skew prevention
Compatibility matrices (vSphere, NSX, firmware) VCF Ensures: Upgrades are coordinated across domains Versions are locked as a bill of materials Drift is actively prevented You upgrade the fleet, not “a vCenter here and there.”
vCenter SSO External IdPs (AD / LDAP / OIDC) Role-based access (RBAC)
VCF Automation Organizations and Projects VCF Ensures Consistent role models Central auth sources Separation of duties across domains IAM is federated but standardized across the fleet. No bespoke admin models per domain.
vCenter Server
ESX hosts
NSX Managers & VCF Edges Internal APIs Trust relationships Certifacate Challenges: Certificate sprawl Expiration risk Manual rotation = outage risk VCF Ensures: Centralized visibility via SDDC Manager Supported rotation workflows Integration with enterprise CAs Certificates are fleet-scale secrets, not local files. Appliance passwords Service accounts Inter-component credentials Bootstrap secrets Reality Password rotation must be: Coordinated Non-disruptive Auditable VCF: Tracks credentials centrally Rotates safely Prevents “unknown admin password” scenarios This is operational hygiene at scale. Cluster settings (HA, DRS, admission control) NSX transport & policies Storage policies Network constructs Domain-level invariants Configuration is declared once and enforced everywhere. VCF: Applies opinionated defaults Detects unsupported deviations Blocks actions that would break fleet integrity Automation targeting Chargeback / showback Compliance classification Ownership & environment labeling Tags provide metadata across the entire fleet. Tags provide horizontal metadata across: Domains Clusters VMs Datastores “The control plane’s labeling system for infrastructure objects.” Without tags, automation becomes brittle.Fleet Management in VCF ├── SDDC Manager │ ├── Lifecycle (LCM) │ ├── Credentials │ ├── Certificates │ ├── Configuration invariants │ ├── Business Layer │ ├── Usage Meter │ └── Business Services Console │ ├── Identity & Access │ ├── vCenter SSO │ └── External IdP │ └── Metadata └── Tags & policies Fleet management is the core value proposition of VCF It spans license, lifecycle, identity, secrets, certs, config, and metadata Centralization + opinionation is the feature, not a limitation VCF treats infrastructure as a long-lived, governed fleet, not pets
You might want to check VMware Data Services Manager.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Platform Operations and Services/Platform Services and Management/Managing the Cloud/Fleet Management.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: VMware Data Services Manager
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description:
VMware Data Services Manager (DSM) is a Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) control plane that lets platform teams offer databases as a managed service on top of VCF infrastructure—while keeping infrastructure, security, and lifecycle control centralized.
DSM answers: “How do we provide self-service databases without giving users raw VM access?” VCF ├── vSphere / vSAN / NSX ├── SDDC Manager (infra lifecycle) │ └── VMware Data Services Manager ├── Control Plane (policies, APIs, UI) └── Data Plane └── Database VMs (Postgres, MySQL, etc.) DSM: Runs on: VCF infrastructure
Consumes: vSphere, NSX, storage policies Exposes: A database service interface to users DSM is above infrastructure, below applications. Provision databases in minutes Automated: Day-0 setup Day-1 operations Day-2 patching and upgrades Consistent configurations every time No more hand-built “special” DB VMs. Platform team controls: VM templates Storage policies Network placement Backup and security posture Application teams control: DB provisioning Scaling (within limits) Credentials (scoped)
This maps cleanly to enterprise governance models.Databases are deployed with: Approved VM shapes Approved storage classes
Approved NSX Segments
Approved HA / backup models Users pick “what”, not “how”.DSM automates: Database-aware backups Snapshots Restore workflows Optional replication patterns This is database lifecycle, not just VM lifecycle.DSM targets enterprises modernizing gradually, not cloud-native purists.This distinction is important. SDDC Manager:
Patches ESX, NSX, vCenter DSM: Patches databases Manages DB templates Controls DB version drift They are complementary, not overlapping.If VCF is: “Infrastructure as a managed fleet” Then DSM is: “Databases as a managed service on that fleet” Comparable to: AWS RDS (conceptually) Azure SQL (conceptually) …but on-prem / private cloud, with enterprise control.Enterprises want: Self-service databases Fewer snowflake DB VMs Safer operations Faster delivery Without:
Giving developers vCenter access Losing compliance control Rewriting everything for Kubernetes DSM provides the perfect middle ground. VMware Data Services Manager = DBaaS control plane Runs on, but is not part of, VCF core Enforces policy, separation of duties, and lifecycle automation Best for VM-based enterprise databases Optional, but powerful for platform teams
Maybe you might want to check out Cloud Services Console too.

headers.heading: Where Does DSM Fit in VCF

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Platform Operations and Services/Platform Services and Management/Managing the Cloud/VMware Data Services Manager.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: VMware Skyline
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description:
VMware Skyline is a proactive support and health intelligence service that continuously analyzes your VMware environment and surfaces: Configuration risks Known issues Upgrade blockers Security advisories Best-practice deviations It answers: “What is likely to break, and what should I fix before it does?”
VCF Environment ├── vCenter / ESXi ├── NSX ├── vSAN ├── SDDC Manager │ └── Skyline ├── Telemetry collection ├── Health & risk analysis └── Proactive recommendations Skyline observes the fleet — it does not control it. Skyline is VCF-adjacent, not VCF-core.
In VCF: Skyline supports:
vSphere
NSX
vSAN
SDDC Manager Skyline findings are especially valuable for: LCM readiness Upgrade prechecks Fleet hygiene Skyline correlates your environment against: Known VMware issues Field advisories Support KB patterns This is knowledge you cannot replicate locally.Before you run LCM in VCF: Skyline can flag: Unsupported configs Known bad upgrade paths Latent drift issues You can think of it as: “Support’s brain looking at your fleet before you upgrade.” Skyline shines when:
You have many domains
You have many vCenters You want a single risk posture view
This aligns naturally with VCF Fleet management.Skyline is insight, not control.Skyline is the supportability lens.If SDDC Manager is: “The mechanic that performs maintenance” Then Skyline is: “The service engineer who tells you what will fail next month.” VMware Skyline Provides proactive, VCF-global intelligence Is best viewed as a support copilot for VCF fleets Is especially valuable for LCM and large environments
VMware Data Services Manager and Cloud Services Console are other adjacent tools that you might want to explore.

headers.heading: Where Skyline Sits Relative to VCF

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/i.title: Supervisor Cluster
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/i.description:
See also: vSphere ClusterYes’nt.
A vSphere Cluster and a Supervisor Cluster are not the same thing. However, they are so tightly-related in a Supervisor-enabled Namespace, you can “colloquially” say that they are the same.Yet, they sit at different abstraction layers.This is the base construct.A vSphere Cluster is a classic virtualization construct: A group of [[ESX] hosts
Managed by vCenter Provides: [DRS] (scheduling) [HA] (failover) Resource Pooling (CPU / memory) Shared storage and networking However, vSphere Cluster alone does not imply Any Kubernetes Any namespaces Any tenants Any container workloads You can run only VMs, forever, and never enable anything Kubernetes-related.This is the layer on top.A Supervisor Cluster is not a separate cluster of hosts.It is:
A Kubernetes control plane embedded into a vSphere Cluster
When you enable the Supervisor feature on vSphere:
vSphere deploys Kubernetes control plane VMs
ESX hosts become Kubernetes worker nodes vSphere exposes:
Supervisor Namespaces
Pod Workloads
Guest Clusters (e.g., VKS)
vSphere becomes Kubernetes-aware
The key point is: The same ESX hosts of the same vSphere Cluster are used, but now they serve two schedulers**:
vSphere (VMs) Kubernetes (pods / guest clusters) So the formal relationship is: A Supervisor Cluster is a capability of a vSphere Cluster, not a different cluster type. But, it walks like a duck, talks like a duck, and it surely is a very-sophisticated duck: Operationally, and practically, it is the same thing.
A Supervisor Cluster is a Kubernetes control plane that runs on and transforms a vSphere Cluster into a Kubernetes-aware platform.For the ontology-enthusiasts out there:This matters a lot. vSphere cluster failure → everything dies
Supervisor control plane failure → VMs keep running Although subtle, this distinction becomes very important when discussing: Security boundaries Upgrade paths Failure isolation Scheduling semantics
VCF Automation mappings
In a Supervisor-enabled vSphere, the Supervisor Cluster and the vSphere Cluster are co-resident and inseparable operationally, but they remain distinct architectural constructs with different control planes and failure domains.
After clarifying this subtle distinction, vSphere Supervisor could be something worth exploring.

headers.heading: Is It the Same Thing as **vSphere Cluster

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar
